tgt_text.1271: As on the hands, they are distri. buted upon the tarsus of the foot, and from thence to the toes.
tgt_text.1273: A number of small veins are distributed on the stomach and the lungs.
tgt_text.1274: Those that extend to the head, through the jugular region, appear large in the neck.
tgt_text.1275: From the extremity of each of these many veins are distributed upon the head, some on the right side to the left, others on the left side to the right, they all end near the ear.
tgt_text.1276: And there is a second vein upon the neck on each side, some­ what less than the other, to which the principal veins of the neck are united.
tgt_text.1277: These pass inwards, through the neck, and from each of them veins pass beneath the shoulder-blade and to the hands ;
tgt_text.1278: and near the splenetic and hepatic veins there appear others a little less, which they divide when any disease attacks the skin;
tgt_text.1279: but the hepatic and splenetic veins are divided for any disease in the neigh­ bourhood of the stomach.
tgt_text.1281: Other veins pass from these, beneath the breasts;
tgt_text.1282: and there are other small ones, which proceed from each of these through the spinal marrow to the testicles, and others beneath the skin, through the flesh, reach the kidneys;
tgt_text.1283: in men they terminate upon the testicles, in women on the uterus.
tgt_text.1284: The first veins from the stomach are wider, and afterwards become smaller, until they pass over from the right to the left, and from the left to the right;
tgt_text.1285: these are called the spermatic veins.
tgt_text.1286: The thickest blood is beneath the flesh, but that which is in excess in these places be­ comes thin, and warm, and frothy."
tgt_text.1287: These are the opinions of Syennesis and Diogenes.8.
tgt_text.1290: There are four pair of veins, one from the back of the head through the neck, on the outside, near the spine on either side, as far as the thighs and the legs, afterwards through the legs to the ancles, on the out­ side, and to the feet.
tgt_text.1291: Wherefore, in complaints of the back and thigh, they divide the veins upon the poplitic region, or ancles, on the outside.
tgt_text.1292: Another pair of veins pass from the, head, by the ears, through the neck, these are called the.
tgt_text.1294: and others within, near the spine, lead by the loins to the testicles and the thighs, and through the poplitic region on the inside, and through the leg to the inner part of the ancle, and the feet;
tgt_text.1295: wherefore, in complaints of the loins and testicles, they bleed in the poplitic region and ancles.9.
tgt_text.1297: The third pair of veins, from the temple through the;
tgt_text.1298: neck, and beneath the scapula, reach the lungs;
tgt_text.1299: those from the right to the left, under the breast, to the spleen and.
tgt_text.1301: and those from the left to the right side, from the lungs, under the breast, and liver, and kidney ;
tgt_text.1302: and both end beneath the testicles.
tgt_text.1303: The fourth pair from the forepart of the head and the eyes, under the neck and collar-bones;
tgt_text.1304: from thence they extend through the humerus to the elbow, and through the cubitus to the wrist and the fingers, and through the lower part of the arm to the arm-pits, and the upper part of the lungs.
tgt_text.1305: The one reaches as far as the spleen, the other to the liver;
tgt_text.1306: afterwards they both pass over the abdomen to the pudendum.
tgt_text.1307: "1. THE opinions of other persons are nearly these;
tgt_text.1308: and there are other physiologists, but they have not treated so accurately of the veins.
tgt_text.1309: But all agree in placing their origin in the head and brain, in which they are incorrect.
tgt_text.1310: But, as I have remarked before, it is difficult to discern the course of the veins;
tgt_text.1311: indeed, it is impossible to understand them unless a person will examine animals which, after emaciation, have been killed by strangulation.
tgt_text.1312: The follow­ ing is the nature of the veins :
tgt_text.1313: There are two veins in the interior of the chest, near the spine ;
tgt_text.1314: the larger of these is placed forward, the smaller is behind;
tgt_text.1315: the larger is inclined to the right side, the smaller to the left;
tgt_text.1316: and this by some persons is called the aorta, from the sinewy portion which is seen in dead animals.
tgt_text.1318: These veins have their origin in the heart, for they pass completely through the other intestines, and always preserve the character of veins.
tgt_text.1319: The heart is, as it were, a part of them, and especially of the more forward and larger one, for these veins are above and below, and the heart is in the middle of them.
tgt_text.1320: The heart of all animals contains cavi­ ties, but in the heart of very small animals the largest cavity is scarcely perceptible, in moderately sized animals the second cavity is scarcely visible, but in large animals they are all three distinct enough.
tgt_text.1321: And when the apex of the heart is turned forwards, as I have observed, the principal cavity is on the right side, and above it the least is on the left side, and the middle-sized one is between them;
tgt_text.1322: the two smaller are far less than the greater.
tgt_text.1324: All these are perforated towards the lungs, but im­ perceptibly so from the minuteness of the passage, except in one place.
tgt_text.1325: The great vein is suspended from the upper portion of the principal cavity;
tgt_text.1327: after­ wards through the cavity a vein extends again, as if the vein were a part of the cavity in which the blood stagnates.
tgt_text.1328: The aorta has its origin from the middle cavity, but in a dif­ ferent manner from the vein, for it communicates with the heart by a much narrower past age, and the vein is continued through the heart.
tgt_text.1329: But the aorta passes from the heart, and the great vein is membranous and like skin, but the aorta is narrow and very sinewy, and as it is continued towards the head and the lower parts of the body, it becomes narrow and quite sinewy.
tgt_text.1331: A portion of the great vein is first of all extended up­ wards from the heart to the lung, and to the junction of the aorta, this vein being undivided and large;
tgt_text.1332: from this place it divides into two branches, the one towards the lung, and the other to the spine and the lowest vertebra of the neck.
tgt_text.1333: The branch which goes to the lungs is first divided into two branches, and afterwards it is continued upon every tube and passage of the lungs, greater to the greater, and less to the less, so as to leave no part in which there is not a passage and a small vein.
tgt_text.1334: These last are invisible from their minute size, so that the whole lung seems to be full of blood.
tgt_text.1336: And the passages from the vein are above the tubes which extend from the trachea.
tgt_text.1337: And the vein which is continued upon the vertebra of the neck, and upon the spinal column, returns again to the spine, asHomer writes in his poems :
tgt_text.1338: He cut off the whole vein which passes up the back and returns again to the neck;
tgt_text.1339: ”1 and from this vein branches extend to each rib and to each vertebra;
tgt_text.1340: but that which is upon the vertebra near the kidneys branches in two directions.
tgt_text.1341: These branches, then, of the great vein are subdivided in this manner.
tgt_text.1343: And above these, from that part which is continued from the heart, the whole is again divided into two directions, for some reach to the sides and the clavicles, and afterwards through the armpits to the arms, in the human subject, but in quadrupeds to the fore-legs, to the wings in birds, and to the pectoral fins in fishes.
tgt_text.1344: The commencements of these veins, when they are first of all divided, are called jugular veins;
tgt_text.1345: and having branched off in the neck from the great vein, they are continued to the trachea of the lungs.
tgt_text.1346: And if these veins are held on the outside, men fall down dead with in.
tgt_text.1347: sensibility, with closed eyes, but without choking.
tgt_text.1349: Extending in this manner, and receiving the trachea between them, they reach the place where the jaws unite with the head;
tgt_text.1350: and again from this point they are divided into four veins, one of which bends backwards and descends through the neck and shoulder, and meets the first division of the vein by the joint of the arm;
tgt_text.1351: the other portion ter­ minates in the hand and fingers;
tgt_text.1352: and another branch ex­ tends from each part near the ear to the brain, where it is divided into many small branches upon the membrane which surrounds the brain.
tgt_text.1354: The brain never contains blood in any animal, nor does any vein, small or great, terminate upon it;
tgt_text.1355: but some of the other branches that extend from this vein surround the brain in a circle, and others, end upon the organs of sense and the teeth in very small veins.
tgt_text.1356: In the same manner, also, the branches of the smaller vein, which is called the aorta, are divided:
tgt_text.1357: they are continued beside those of the great vein, but the tubes are smaller and the branches less than those of the great vein.1.
tgt_text.1358: THE veins, then, are thus distributed in the parts above the heart, but the part of the great vein which is below the heart passes through the middle of the diaphragm, and is united to the aorta and spinal column by membranous flaccid passages.
tgt_text.1359: From this a short and wide vein passes through the liver, from which many similar branches extend to the liver, and disappear upon it.
tgt_text.1360: There are two branches of the vein, one of which terminates upon the diaphragm, and what is called the praecordia, the other returns through the arm- pit to the right arm, and unites with the other veins near the interior part of the elbow.
tgt_text.1361: For this reason physicians treat certain diseases of the liver by venesection in this vein.
tgt_text.1363: From the left of this there is a short and wide vein, which reaches to the spleen, and the branches of this vein are lost upon this organ, and another portion branching off in the same way from the left the great vein passes up to the left arm, except that the last-mentioned pass through the liver, but this one through the spleen.
tgt_text.1364: Other branches also separate from the great vein, the one to the omentum, the other to the pancreas;
tgt_text.1365: and from this many veins extend through the mesenterium, and all end there in one great vein, which passes through the whole intestine and the stomach, as far as the oesophagus;
tgt_text.1366: and many veins branch off from them around these parts.
tgt_text.1368: Both the aorta and the great vein continue as far as the kidney each as a single duct;
tgt_text.1369: from this point they are more closely united to the spinal column, and are each di­ vided into two parts, like the letter lambda (A), and the great vein is placed farther back than the aorta.
tgt_text.1370: The aorta is more closely united to the spinal column, near the neart, and the junction is formed by small sinewy veins.
tgt_text.1372: The aorta leaves the heart as a large hollow passage, but as it advances it becomes narrower and more sinewy.
tgt_text.1373: From the aorta, veins extend also to the mesenterium, like those from the great vein, but far inferior in size, for they are narrow and muscular.
tgt_text.1374: They terminate in small hollow muscular veins.
tgt_text.1375: No branch of the aorta extends to the liver and the spleen, but the branches of either vein extend to each hip, and both touch upon the bone.
tgt_text.1376: Branches reach the kidney both from the great vein and the aorta;
tgt_text.1377: they do not, however, enter the cavity, but are taken up in the substance of the kidney.
tgt_text.1379: Two other strong and continuous passages reach from the aorta to the bladder, and others from the cavity of the kidney;
tgt_text.1380: but these do not communicate with the great vein.
tgt_text.1381: From the centre of each kidney a hollow sinewy vein passes through the other veins to the spinal column;
tgt_text.1382: first of all they disappear upon each hip, and then appear again in branches towards the hip;
tgt_text.1383: their ex­ tremities are distributed upon the bladder and penis in the male, and upon the uterus in the female;
tgt_text.1384: no branch of the great vein passes to the uterus, but many and thick ones reach it from the aorta.
tgt_text.1386: From the aorta and great vein branches are distributed to the nates;
tgt_text.1387: at first they are large and hollow, afterwards they pass through the legs, ending upon the feet and toes ;
tgt_text.1388: and others again pass through the nates and thighs, alter­ nately from right to left, and they join with other veins below the knees.
tgt_text.1390: The nature and origin of the veins are evident from this description.
tgt_text.1391: In all sanguineous animals, the nature and origin of the principal veins are the same, but the multitude of smaller veins is not alike in all, for neither are the parts of the same nature, nor do all possess the same parts.
tgt_text.1392: Nor are the veins equally apparent in all animals;
tgt_text.1393: but they are more manifest in those which have most blood, and in the largest creatures;
tgt_text.1394: but in those animals which are small, and have not much blood, either by nature or from excess in fat, they are not so easily investigated, for some of the passages are confused, like rivulets that are lost in beds of mud;
tgt_text.1395: and there are some animals which have but few, and these fibres instead of veins.
tgt_text.1396: The great vein is very conspicuous in all, even the smallest animals.
tgt_text.1398: THE following is the nature of the sinews of animals.
tgt_text.1399: The origin of these, also, is in the breast, for there is a sinew in the principal cavity of the heart itself;
tgt_text.1400: and that which is called the aorta is a sinewy vein, for its termina­ tions are always sinewy, for they are not hollow, and are extensible, like the sinews which end upon the bending of the bones:
tgt_text.1401: for it is not the nature of sinews to be con­ tinuous from one origin, like the veins, for the veins have the whole form of the body as in outline sketches, so that in emaciated subjects the whole mass appears full of veins, for the same place is occupied by veins in lean persons that in fat ones is flesh.
tgt_text.1403: The sinews are drawn round the joints and flexures of the bones;
tgt_text.1404: but, if their nature were continuous, the con­ tinuation would be evident in emaciated persons.
tgt_text.1405: The principal parts of the sinews are around the part of the body appropriated to leaping, and this is called the poples.
tgt_text.1406: Another double sinew is the tendon of the neck, and the epi­ tonus and the sinew of the shoulder, which aid in the support of the body.
tgt_text.1407: The sinews around the joints have not re­ ceived any name, for all the bones where they are contiguous are bound together by the sinews.
tgt_text.1409: And there are many sinews round all the bones ;
tgt_text.1410: there are none in the head;
tgt_text.1411: but the sutures of the skull are adapted to each other.
tgt_text.1412: It is the nature of sinew to tear readily lengthwise, but across the fibre it is indivisible, and it is very extensible.
tgt_text.1413: The sinews are surrounded by a mucous, white, and gelatinous fluid, by which they are nourished, and from which they seem to derive their origin.
tgt_text.1414: The vein does not alter its form by combustion, but the sinew is entirely destroyed.
tgt_text.1415: Neither does it unite after division.
tgt_text.1416: 4. Numbness does not take place in those parts of the body which contain no sinews.
tgt_text.1417: The sinews are most abund­ ant on the hands and feet, and on the ribs and shoulder- blades, and round the neck and arms.
tgt_text.1419: but in those which have not jointed limbs, and are without feet and hands, the sinews are small and inconspicuous, so that in fishes they are most distinct near the fins.
tgt_text.1421: THE fibres are between the sinews and the veins;
tgt_text.1422: but some of them are moistened with serum, and they extend from the sinews to the veins, and from the veins to the sinews.
tgt_text.1423: There is also another kind of fibre, which is pro­ duced in the blood of most, but not of all animals.
tgt_text.1424: When this is extracted from the blood, it does not coagulate, but if it is not taken out of the blood it coagulates.
tgt_text.1425: These fibres are present in the blood of most animals, but not in that of the stag, prox,1 and bubalis,2 and some others;
tgt_text.1426: so that their blood does not coagulate like that of other animals:
tgt_text.1427: the blood of stags is very like that of hares;
tgt_text.1428: for in both of these coagulation takes place;
tgt_text.1429: not firm, as in other animals, but trembling, like that of milk, if no co­ agulating substance is put into it.
tgt_text.1430: The blood of the bubalis coagulates more thickly, only a little less so than that of sheep.
tgt_text.1431: This is the nature of veins, sinews, and fibres.
tgt_text.1433: THE bones of animals depend upon one bone, and are connected with each other, like the veins;
tgt_text.1434: and there is no such thing as a separate bone.
tgt_text.1435: In all animals with bones the spinal column is their origin.
tgt_text.1436: The spinal column is I made up of vertebrae, and extends from the head to the hips.
tgt_text.1438: the upper part of the head is a bone joined to the last vertebra, and is called the skull, the saw-like part is the suture.
tgt_text.1440: This is not alike in all animals, for the cranium of some consists of a single bone, as in the dog;
tgt_text.1441: in others it is compound, as in the human subject.
tgt_text.1442: The female has one suture, in a circle;
tgt_text.1443: the male has three, meeting at the top of the head, like a triangle ;
tgt_text.1444: and human skulls have been seen without sutures.
tgt_text.1445: The head is not composed of four bones, but of six ;
tgt_text.1446: two of these are placed above the ears, and are small compared with the rest.
tgt_text.1448: From the head the jaw-bones descend.
tgt_text.1449: All other ani­ mala move the lower jaw, the river-crocodile alone moves the upper jaw.
tgt_text.1450: In the jaws are the order of the teeth, which are bony, in some parts they are perforated, in others they are not.
tgt_text.1451: These are the only bones too hard to be engraved.
tgt_text.1453: From the spinal-column, which is the point of union, ori­ ginate the clavicles and ribs;
tgt_text.1454: the breast also is placed upon the ribs, and some of these are united, others are not, for no animal has a bone round the stomach.
tgt_text.1455: There are also the scapulæ upon the shoulders, and these are conti­ nued upon the arms, and those again to the hands;
tgt_text.1456: and in all animals with fore legs the nature of the bone is the same.
tgt_text.1458: At the extremity of the lower part of the spinal co­ lumn, and next to the hip, is the socket, and the bones of the lower extremity, with those of the thigh and leg, which are called the colenes.
tgt_text.1459: The ancles form a portion of these, and the part called the spur in all creatures with ancles.
tgt_text.1460: Continuous with these are the bones of the feet.
tgt_text.1461: Viviparous animals with blood and feet do not differ much in their bones, but rather by analogy, in hardness, softness, and size.
tgt_text.1462: Again, some of the bones contain marrow, whilst others, in the same animal, have none.
tgt_text.1464: Some animals do not appear to have any marrow at all in their bones, as the lion, whose bones are very small and slight:
tgt_text.1465: or there may be marrow in a few of its bones, as in those of the thigh and fore leg;
tgt_text.1466: otherwise, in the lion, the bones are particularly solid, for they are sufficiently hard to emit fire like stones on concussion.
tgt_text.1467: The dolphin also has bones, but it has no spine, like fish.
tgt_text.1468: Some sanguineous ani­ mals differ partially from these, as the class of birds.
tgt_text.1469: In others, as fish, the bones are only analogous, for viviparous fish have a cartilaginous spine, like those which are called selachea;
tgt_text.1470: the oviparous fish have a spine, which is like the backbone of quadrupeds.
tgt_text.1472: It is a peculiarity in fish that some species have small spines in the flesh separated from each other.
tgt_text.1473: Serpents are like fish, for their back-bone is spinous;
tgt_text.1474: among oviparous quadrupeds the greater animals have a bony vertebral column;
tgt_text.1475: the lesser have a spinous one.
tgt_text.1477: For all sanguineous animals have either a bony, or a spinous column.
tgt_text.1478: The remainder of the bones exist in some animals, but not in others, for if they have the limbs, they have the bones belonging to them ;
tgt_text.1479: for those that have not hind and fore legs have not hams, nor are they present in those animals which possess limbs unlike those of quad­ rupeds, for in these they vary in size and proportion.
tgt_text.1480: This is the nature of the bones of animals.
tgt_text.1482: CARTILAGE is of the same nature as bone, but it differs .
tgt_text.1483: in the greater and less, and neither bone nor cartilage are reproduced if they are cut off.
tgt_text.1484: In sanguineous and vivi­ parous animals living on the land the cartilage is imper­ forate, and does not contain marrow, like the bones;
tgt_text.1485: but the flat selachea, which have a cartilaginous spine, have a carti­ lage analogous to bone containing a liquid marrow.
tgt_text.1486: Vivi­ parous animals, with feet, have cartilage about their ears, nostrils, and extremities of their bones.
tgt_text.1488: THERE is another class of parts, which, though not the same as these, are not very different, as nails, hoofs, claws, and horns, and besides these, the beak of birds which alone possess this part.
tgt_text.1489: For these are both flexible and fissile.
tgt_text.1490: But bone is neither flexible nor fissile, but brittle;
tgt_text.1491: and the colour of horns, nails, claws, and hoofs follow the colour of the skin and the hair:
tgt_text.1492: for in black animals the horns are black, and so are the claws and hoofs in those with claws;
tgt_text.1493: in white animals they are white.
tgt_text.1494: There are also intermediate colours, the nails also are of the same nature.
tgt_text.1495: 2. But the teeth are like bones;
tgt_text.1496: wherefore, in black men, Ethiopians, and such like, the teeth and the bones are white, but the nails are black, like the rest of the skin.
tgt_text.1497: The horns of most animals are hollow at their base, and surround a bony process on their heads;
tgt_text.1498: but at the ex­ tremity the horn is solid and single.
tgt_text.1499: The stag's horns are solid throughout, and divided;
tgt_text.1500: and these animals alone cast their horns;
tgt_text.1501: this is done annually, if they are not cut off.
tgt_text.1502: Concerning those that are cut off, we shall speak here­ after.
tgt_text.1504: The horns are more nearly allied to skin than to bone, so that in Phrygia and elsewhere there are oxen which have the power of moving their horns, as they do their ears;
tgt_text.1505: and of those which have nails (and all that have toes have nails, and those that have feet have toes, except the elephant, which has its toes undivided, and scarcely distinguished, and no nails at all)—and of those with nails, some have straight nails, like men, others crooked, as the lion among beasts, and the eagle amongst birds.
tgt_text.1507: THIS is the nature of hair and its analogues and skin.
tgt_text.1508: All viviparous animals, with feet, have hair;
tgt_text.1509: oviparous animals, with feet, have scaly plates;
tgt_text.1510: and those fish alone which produce friable ova are covered with scales;
tgt_text.1511: for the conger and muræna among long fish have not such ova, and the eel produces no ova.
tgt_text.1512: The hair differs in thickness, thin­ ness, and size, according to its situation, both in the parts of the body which it occupies, and the nature of the skin, for upon thick skins the hair is generally harsh and thick, the hair is both thicker and longer in the hollow and moist parts of the body, if they are such as to be covered with hair.
tgt_text.1514: And the case is similar in those animals which are covered with plates or scales.
tgt_text.1515: If animals covered with soft hair are placed in good pastures their hair will become coarser ;
tgt_text.1516: and, on the contrary, it becomes finer and less in those that have coarse hair.
tgt_text.1517: Warm and cold situations also make a difference, for the hair of natives of warm climates is harsh, but it is soft in those of colder climates.
tgt_text.1518: Straight hair is soft, crisped hair is harsh.
tgt_text.1519: 3. It is the nature of hair to split;
tgt_text.1520: and different kinds of hair are dissimilar in excess and deficiency;
tgt_text.1521: some are so changed by harshness as to bear slight resemblance to hair, and are more like spines, as in the hedgehog, wherein they resemble nails.
tgt_text.1522: So again the nails in some animals are not different from bones in point of hardness.
tgt_text.1523: 4. Man has the thinnest skin in proportion to his size.
tgt_text.1524: There is a mucous, glutinous fluid in the skin of all animals, less in some, more in others, as in the skins of oxen, from which glue is made;
tgt_text.1525: and sometimes glue is made from fishes.
tgt_text.1526: When the skin alone is cut it is insensible, especially that upon the head, from the absence of flesh between that and the bone.
tgt_text.1527: Wherever the skin is without flesh it does not unite again after being cut, as the thin part of the cheek, the prepuce, and the eyelid.
tgt_text.1528: In all animals the skin is continuous, and it is only wanting in places where there are natural passages for exudation, and at the -mouth and nails.
tgt_text.1529: All sanguineous animals have a skin:
tgt_text.1530: all, however, have not hair, but those which are described above.
tgt_text.1532: The colour of the hair changes in men as they grow old, and the hair becomes grey.
tgt_text.1533: This takes place in other animals, but not so remarkably as in the horse.
tgt_text.1534: The hair begins to grow white from the extremity.
tgt_text.1535: Most white animals are white from their birth, wherefore it is plain that whiteness does not arise from dryness, as some persons suppose, for no animal is born dry.
tgt_text.1536: In the exanthematous disease, called whiteness, all the hair becomes hoary;
tgt_text.1537: and some patients, who have suffered from illness, after the hair has fallen off on recovery, have regained their dark-coloured hair.
tgt_text.1538: Hair which is covered up becomes white more readily than that which is exposed to the air;
tgt_text.1539: in man the temples are the first to grow grey, and the fore part of the head before the hind part, and last of all the hair on the pubes.
tgt_text.1541: Some of the hair exists on the body at the period of birth, and some appears afterwards.
tgt_text.1542: In man alone the hair on the head, eyelashes, and eyebrows exist at birth.
tgt_text.1543: The hair on the pubes, in the armpits, and on the chin ap­ pear successively after birth, so that the parts on which the hair appears at birth, and those on which it grows after­ wards are the same in number.
tgt_text.1544: In old age the hair on the bead especially is the first to fail, and falls off.
tgt_text.1545: This is only in front, for no one ever becomes bald on the back of the head.
tgt_text.1546: The smoothness on the crown of the head is called baldness, that upon the eyebrows depilation;
tgt_text.1547: neither of these takes place before the commencement of puberty.
tgt_text.1549: Children, women, and eunuchs never become bald.
tgt_text.1550: If a person be castrated before puberty, the hair which grows after birth never makes its appearance;
tgt_text.1551: if after puberty these alone fall off, except the hair on the pubes.
tgt_text.1552: Women have no hair upon the chin, excepting a few of those in whom the catamenia have ceased, and the priestesses in Caria :
tgt_text.1553: and this appears ominous of future events.
tgt_text.1554: Women also have other hair, but not much.
tgt_text.1555: There are some persons, both male and female, who from their birth are without the hair which grows after birth;
tgt_text.1556: but those per­ sons are barren who have not hair on the pubes.
tgt_text.1558: The rest of the hair grows proportionally, either more or less.
tgt_text.1559: That upon the head grows the most, then that on the chin, and thin hair most of all.
tgt_text.1560: The eyebrows grow so thick upon some aged persons as to be cut off, for they are placed upon the symphysis of the bone;
tgt_text.1561: and this being separated in old persons, a more abundant moisture exudes.
tgt_text.1562: Those on the eyelids do not grow, but they fall off, when persons come to puberty, and especially in those off warm sexual desires;
tgt_text.1564: If the hair is plucked out during the period of growth, it comes again, but not after it has done growing.
tgt_text.1566: Every hair has at its root a glutinous moisture, which will adhere to anything with which it comes in contact, soon after it is drawn out.
tgt_text.1567: In spotted animals the spots exist both in the hair and upon the skin, and upon the skin of the tongue.
tgt_text.1568: As for the beard, some persons have a thick one, both beneath the chin and upon it;
tgt_text.1569: in others, these parts are smooth, and the beard is on the cheeks.
tgt_text.1570: Those who have smooth chins are least likely to become bald.
tgt_text.1571: The hair grows in some diseases, as in phthisis especially, and in old age, and upon dead bodies, and the hair becomes harder instead of softer.
tgt_text.1572: The same is the case with the nails.
tgt_text.1573: In persons of strong passions, the hair that is born with them decreases, while that which comes after birth in­ creases.
tgt_text.1575: Those who suffer from enlarged veins are less likely to become bald;
tgt_text.1576: and if they have this disease after they are bald, the hair sometimes grows again.
tgt_text.1578: does not grow again from the extremity, but in­ creases by growth from the root.
tgt_text.1579: The scales of fishes become harder and thicker, and in those that are growing thin and old they become still harder.
tgt_text.1580: The hair and wool of old animals becomes thicker, though the quantity de­ creases ;
tgt_text.1581: and the hoofs and claws enlarge as they grow old, and the beaks of birds.
tgt_text.1582: And the claws grow in the same way as the nails.
tgt_text.1583: 11. Feathered animals, like birds, do not change their colour by age, excepting the crane, for this bird is ash- coloured, and becomes black by age.
tgt_text.1584: But from the change of season, when it becomes cold, some of those having but one colour, black or grey, become white, as the crow, sparrow, and swallow ;
tgt_text.1585: but none of those which are white become black.
tgt_text.1586: At different seasons of the year many birds change the colour of their plumage, so as to render it difficult for those who are not acquainted with them to recognise them.
tgt_text.1588: And many animals change their colour with a change of water;
tgt_text.1589: for in one place they are black, and in another white ;
tgt_text.1590: and the same thing takes place at the season of co­ ition.
tgt_text.1591: There are many waters of such a nature that if sheep drink of them before sexual intercourse, they produce black lambs ;
tgt_text.1592: as at that which is called the cold river in the Thracian Chalets (in Astyritis).
tgt_text.1593: And in Antandria there are two rivers, one of which turns the sheep white, the other black ;
tgt_text.1594: and the Scamander appears to make the sheep yellow, wherefore some people think that Homer called the Scamander the Xanthus.
tgt_text.1596: Other animals have no hair internally, nor upon the bottom of their feet, though it is on the upper part.
tgt_text.1597: The hare alone has hair on the inside of its cheeks, and upon its feet, and the mysticetus1 has no teeth in its mouth, but hairs, like hog's bristles.
tgt_text.1598: The hair, if it is cut off, increases below, but not above.
tgt_text.1599: Feathers do not grow either above or below, but fall out.
tgt_text.1600: The wing of the bee, if it is plucked off, does not grow again, nor that of any other creature which has an undivided wing;
tgt_text.1601: nor does the sting of the bee grow after it is plucked out, but the animal dies.
tgt_text.1603: THERE are membranes in all sanguineous animals.
tgt_text.1604: Mem­ brane is like a dense thin skin, but it differs in kind, for it is neither divisible nor extensible.
tgt_text.1605: There is a membrane round every bone and every intestine, both in the greater and smaller animals;
tgt_text.1606: they are inconspicuous in small ani­ mals, owing to their thinness and small size.
tgt_text.1607: The principal membranes are two, which surround the brain, one round the bones of the head, and this is stronger and thicker than that round the brain itself;
tgt_text.1608: and after these, the membrane which surrounds the heart.
tgt_text.1609: A thin membrane does not unite after it has been cut asunder, and the bones, when de­ prived of their membranes, become inflamed.
tgt_text.1612: All sanguineous ani­ mals have an omentum ;
tgt_text.1613: in some it is fat, in others it con­ tains no fat.
tgt_text.1614: In viviparous animals, with cutting teeth in both jaws, it has its origin and is suspended from the middle of the stomach, where it appears like a suture of this organ.
tgt_text.1615: In those that have not teeth in both jaws, it is suspended in the same way from the principal stomach.
tgt_text.1617: The bladder also is membranous, but its character is different, for it is extensible.
tgt_text.1618: All animals have not a bladder, but all viviparous animals have this organ, and the tortoise alone of oviparous animals.
tgt_text.1619: When the bladder is cut it does not re-unite, except at the very origin of the urethra, or only very rarely, for it has happened sometimes.
tgt_text.1620: No moisture passes into the bladder of dead animals ;
tgt_text.1621: but in living creatures there are dry compounds, from which are formed the stones that are found in persons labouring under this disease;
tgt_text.1622: sometimes they are of such a nature in the bladder as to differ in nothing from shells.
tgt_text.1623: This, then, is the nature of veins, sinews, and skins, and of muscle and membrane;
tgt_text.1624: and of hair, nails, claws, hoofs, horns, teeth and beaks, and of cartilage, bone, and their analogues.1.
tgt_text.1625: IN all sanguineous animals, flesh, and that which is like flesh, is between the skin and the bone, or what is analogous to bone:
tgt_text.1626: for the same relation which a spine bears to a bone, is also borne by flesh to that which is like flesh, in animals possessing bones and spines.
tgt_text.1627: The flesh can be divided in every direction, and so is unlike sinews and veins, which can only be divided in their length.
tgt_text.1628: The flesh disappears in emaciated animals, giving place to veins and fibres.
tgt_text.1629: Those animals which can obtain abundance of good food have fat instead of flesh.
tgt_text.1631: Those that have much flesh have smaller veins and redder blood, and their intestines and stomachs are small;
tgt_text.1632: but those which have large veins and dark blood, and large intestines and great stomachs, have also less flesh, for those that have fat flesh have small intestines.
tgt_text.1634: ADEPS and fat differ from each other, for fat is always brittle, and coagulates upon cooling, but adeps is liquid, and does not coagulate;
tgt_text.1635: and broths made from animals with adeps do not thicken, as from the horse and hog, but that made from animals with fat thickens, as from the sheep and goat.
tgt_text.1636: These substances also differ in situation, for the adeps is between the skin and the flesh ;
tgt_text.1637: but the fat only exists upon the extremity of the flesh.
tgt_text.1638: In adipose animals the omentum is adipose, in fat animals it is fatty:
tgt_text.1639: for the animals with cutting teeth in both jaws are adipose, those that have not cutting teeth in both jaws are fat.
tgt_text.1641: Of the viscera in some animals the liver is full of adeps, as in the cartilaginous fishes, for oil is procured from these during the process of decomposition, the cartilagi.
tgt_text.1642: nous fish are particularly free from adeps on their flesh, but the adeps is separated on the stomach.
tgt_text.1643: The fat also of fishes is adipose, and does not coagulate;
tgt_text.1644: and some animals are furnished with adeps on the flesh, and others apart from the flesh;
tgt_text.1645: and those creatures in which the adeps is not separated from the flesh have less of this substance on the stomach and omentum, as the eel:
tgt_text.1646: for these creatures have little fat on the omentum.
tgt_text.1647: In most animals the adeps collects principally upon the abdomen, especially in those which take little exercise.
tgt_text.1649: The brain of adipose animals is unctuous, as in swine ;
tgt_text.1650: that of fatty animals is dry.
tgt_text.1651: Of all the viscera the kidneys are surrounded by the greatest quantity of adeps in all ani.
tgt_text.1653: that on the right side is always the least adipose;
tgt_text.1654: and let there be ever so much adeps, there is always a space left between the kidneys.
tgt_text.1655: They are also the most fatty of the viscera, and especially in sheep, for this animal some­ times dies from the entire concealment of its kidneys in fat.
tgt_text.1656: This excessive fat around the kidneys arises from good pasture, as in the Leontine territory of Sicily;
tgt_text.1657: wherefore also in the evening they drive away the sheep which have been feeding during the day, in order that they may take less food.
tgt_text.1659: The fat around the pupil of the eye is common to all animals;
tgt_text.1660: for all have fat in this part, that possess it, and are not hard-eyed.
tgt_text.1661: Fat animals, both male and female, are more inclined to be barren, and all old animals become fat more readily than young ones, especially when they increase in depth, having obtained their proper width and length.
tgt_text.1663: THE following is the nature of the blood.
tgt_text.1664: This is most essential and common to all sanguineous animals, and is not superadded, but exists in all animals that are not in a perish­ ing condition.
tgt_text.1665: All the blood is in a vessel called the veins, but in no other part of the body, except the heart.
tgt_text.1666: The blood of all animals has no sense of touch, nor has the excre­ mentitious matter in the stomach;
tgt_text.1667: neither have the brain, nor the marrow, any sensation of touch ;
tgt_text.1668: but wherever the flesh is divided, the blood flows in the living subject, unless the flesh is perishing.
tgt_text.1669: It is the nature of the blood to have a sweet juice, as long as it is healthy and a red colour, and that is bad which either by nature or disease is black.
tgt_text.1670: The best kind of blood is neither very thick nor thin, unless it is vitiated either by nature or disease.
tgt_text.1672: In living animals it is always warm and moist, but when taken out of the animal the blood of all creatures co­ agulates, except that of the stag and deer, and perhaps some others of the same nature.
tgt_text.1673: The blood of all other creatures coagulates, unless the fibre is taken out of it.
tgt_text.1674: Bullock's blood coagulates faster than that of any other animals.
tgt_text.1675: Amongst sanguineous animals, those which are both inter- Dally and externally viviparous, have the most blood, and after them the oviparous sanguineous animals;
tgt_text.1676: those which are well disposed, either by nature or by health, have not a great deal of blood, as in those that have just drank;
tgt_text.1677: nor a very little, as in those which are very fat.
tgt_text.1678: Fat animals have pure blood, though the quantity is small;
tgt_text.1679: as they be­ come more fat they lose a portion of their blood, for fat is free from blood.
tgt_text.1680: Fat is not corruptible, but blood and the parts that contain blood are very corruptible;
tgt_text.1681: of these the parts surrounding the bones are most corruptible.
tgt_text.1683: Man has the thinnest and purest blood, that of the ox and ass is the thickest and blackest of all viviparous ani­ mals.
tgt_text.1684: The blood is thicker and blacker in the lower than in the upper part of animals.
tgt_text.1685: The blood palpitates in the veins alike in all animals ;
tgt_text.1686: this alone of all the fluids exists in every part of the body of living subjects, and as long only as they are alive.
tgt_text.1687: The blood first of all exists in the heart of all animals before it is distributed through the body.
tgt_text.1688: When de­ prived of their blood, or if the greater part escapes, they faint away ;
tgt_text.1689: but when a very great deal is lost, they die.
tgt_text.1690: When the blood becomes very much liquefied, illness ensues, for it becomes like serum, and flows through in such a manner, that some have perspired blood;
tgt_text.1691: and when taken out of the body, it does not coagulate into a mass, but into separate and divided portions.
tgt_text.1693: In sleeping animals, the blood in the extremities is diminished, so that it does not flow freely when they are pricked.
tgt_text.1694: Blood is formed from serum, and fat from blood.
tgt_text.1695: When the blood becomes diseased, haemorrhoids are produced, either in the nose or anus, and a disease called ixia.
tgt_text.1697: When the blood becomes corrupted in the body, pus is formed, and from pus a scab.
tgt_text.1698: The blood in females differs from that of males, for it is more thick and black in females of similar health and age.
tgt_text.1699: In the whole of the body the quantity of blood is less in females, but internally they are more full of blood.
tgt_text.1700: Of all females, women have the most blood, and the catamenia are more abundant in them than in other females.
tgt_text.1702: When this blood is diseased, it is called a flooding.
tgt_text.1703: Women have a less share in other diseases;
tgt_text.1704: but a few are afflicted with ixia, and with hæmorrhoids and bleeding from the nose ;
tgt_text.1705: when any of these take place, the catamenia decrease.
tgt_text.1706: The blood differs in proportion to the age in quan­ tity and appearance, for when very young, it is more like serum, and very abundant;
tgt_text.1707: in the aged it is thick, black,.
tgt_text.1709: in those in the prime of life it is be­ tween these.
tgt_text.1710: In aged persons the blood coagulates quickly in the body, or on the surface;
tgt_text.1711: but in young persons this does not take place.
tgt_text.1712: Serum is imperfect blood, because it has not ripened, or because it has become more fluid.
tgt_text.1714: CONCERNING marrow, for this is one of the fluids which exist in some animals.
tgt_text.1715: All the natural fluids of the body are contained in vessels, as the blood in the veins, and the marrow in the bones, and others in membranes, skin, and cavities.
tgt_text.1716: The marrow is- always full of blood in young ani­ mals ;
tgt_text.1717: but when they grow older, in the adipose it becomes adipose, in fat animals fatty.
tgt_text.1718: There is not marrow in all the bones, but only in those that are hollow, and not even in some of these, for some of the bones of the lion have no marrow, others but little;
tgt_text.1719: wherefore some persons say the lion has no marrow at all, as was before observed.
tgt_text.1720: In the bones of swine there is very little marrow, in some none at all.
tgt_text.1721: 1. THESE fluids are nearly always co-existent with animal.
tgt_text.1723: but milk and the spermatic fluid are produced after­ wards.
tgt_text.1724: Of these the milk is always secreted in those ani­ mals in which it is present.
tgt_text.1725: The spermatic fluid is not secreted in all, but in some as in fishes are what are called melts.
tgt_text.1726: All animals having milk have it in the mammae.
tgt_text.1727: All animals that are both internally and externally vivi­ parous have mammæ, that is, all that have hair, as man, and the horse, the cetacea, as the dolphin, seal, and whale, for these also have mammæ and milk.
tgt_text.1729: Those animals that are only externally viviparous, and oviparous animals, have neither mammæ nor milk, as fish, and birds.
tgt_text.1730: All milk has a watery serum, which is called whey, and a substantial part called curds;
tgt_text.1731: the thicker kinds of milk have the most curds.
tgt_text.1732: The milk of animals without cutting teeth in both jaws, coagulates, wherefore cheese is made from the milk of domestic animals.
tgt_text.1733: The milk of those with cutting teeth in both jaws does not coagulate, but re­ sembles their adeps, and is thin and sweet;
tgt_text.1734: the milk of the camel is the thinnest of all, next is that of the horse;
tgt_text.1735: in the third place that of the ass.
tgt_text.1737: 3. Under the influence of cold, milk does not coagu­ late, but becomes fluid;
tgt_text.1738: by heat it is coagulated, and be­ comes thick.
tgt_text.1739: There is no milk in any animal before it has conceived, or but rarely;
tgt_text.1740: but, as soon as it has con­ ceived the milk is produced;
tgt_text.1741: the first and last milk are useless.
tgt_text.1742: Sometimes milk has come in animals not with young, from partaking of particular kinds of food;
tgt_text.1743: and even in aged females it has been produced so freely when sucked, as to afford nourishment for an infant.
tgt_text.1744: And the shepherds round Æta, when the shegoats will not endure the approach of the males, cut their udders violently against a thorn, so as to cause pain;
tgt_text.1745: at first, when milked, they produce bloody, and afterwards putrid milk, but at last their milk is as good as that of those which have young ones.
tgt_text.1747: The males, both of man and other animals, rarely pro­ duce milk;
tgt_text.1748: nevertheless, it is found in some cases:
tgt_text.1749: for in Lemnos, a he-goat has given from the two nipples, which are always found on the penis, so much milk, that cakes of cheese were made from it.
tgt_text.1750: The same thing happened to another he-goat, which was produced from this one;
tgt_text.1751: but such things as these are considered ominous:
tgt_text.1752: for, on inquiry being made of the god of Lemnos, he replied that there should be an additional supply of cattle.
tgt_text.1753: A small quantity of milk has been forced from some men after puberty;
tgt_text.1754: from others a great quantity has been produced by suction.
tgt_text.1756: There is a fatness in milk which becomes oily when it is cooked.
tgt_text.1757: In Sicily, and other countries, when there is an abundant supply of goat's milk, they mix ewe's milk with it, and it coagulates readily, not only because it con­ tains abundance of curd, but also because it is of a drier nature.
tgt_text.1758: Some animals have more milk than enough for the support of their offspring, and this is useful for making cheese, and for putting aside.
tgt_text.1759: The best is that of the sheep and goats, and next, that of the cow.
tgt_text.1760: Mare's milk and ass's milk are combined with the Phrygian cheese.
tgt_text.1761: There is more cheese in the milk of the cow than of the goat:
tgt_text.1762: for the shepherds say, from an amphora of goat's milk they can make nineteen cakes of cheese, each worth an obolus, and thirty from cow's milk.
tgt_text.1763: Other creatures have only enough for their young, and no superabundance useful for making cheese, as all those animals which have more than two mam­ mæ, for none of these have a superabundance of milk, nor will their milk make cheese.
tgt_text.1765: Milk is coagulated by the juice of figs, and by rennet;
tgt_text.1766: the juice is placed upon wool, and the wool is washed in a little milk ;
tgt_text.1768: The rennet is a kind of milk, which is found in the body of sucking animals.
tgt_text.1769: This rennet is milk, containing cheese, for the milk be­ comes cooked by the heat of the body.
tgt_text.1770: All ruminating ani­ mals contain rennet, and the hare among those with cutting teeth in both jaws.
tgt_text.1771: The older coagulum is the better, for such rennet is useful in diarrhoea, and so is that of the hare.
tgt_text.1772: The rennet of the fawn is the best.
tgt_text.1773: 7. The greater or less quantity of milk drawn from those animals which have milk, differs in the size of the body, and the variety of the food.
tgt_text.1774: In Phasis there are very small cows, each of which gives a great deal of milk;
tgt_text.1775: and the large cows of Epirus give an amphora and half of milk from each of their two mammæ;
tgt_text.1776: and the person who milks them stands up, or only leans a little, because he cannot reach them sitting down.
tgt_text.1777: The other animals of Epirus are large except the ass, but the largest are the cows and the dogs.
tgt_text.1778: These large cattle require more pas­ ture ;
tgt_text.1779: but the country has a great deal so excellent, that they can be changed to fit places every hour.
tgt_text.1780: The oxen are the largest, and the sheep, called Pyrrhic;
tgt_text.1781: they have received this name from king Pyrrhus.8.
tgt_text.1782: Some kinds of food check the milk, as the medic grass, especially in ruminating animals.
tgt_text.1783: The cytisus and oro­ bus have a very different effect;
tgt_text.1784: but the flower of the cytisus is unwholesome, and causes inflammation;
tgt_text.1785: the orobus does not agree with pregnant cattle, for it causes difficulty of parturition.
tgt_text.1786: On the whole, those animals which are able to eat the most food, as they are better adapted for parturition, will also give the most milk, if they have enough food.
tgt_text.1787: Some of the flatulent kinds of food, when given to animals, increase the quantity of milk, as beans given freely to the sheep, goat, ox, and chimoera,' for they cause the udder to be distended ;
tgt_text.1788: and it is a sign that there will be plenty of milk when the udder is seen below before parturition.
tgt_text.1790: The milk lasts a long time in those that have it, if they remain without sexual intercourse, and have proper food;
tgt_text.1791: and in sheep it lasts longer than in any other animals, for the sheep may be milked for eight months.
tgt_text.1792: Altogether the ruminating animals produce milk in greater abundance, and more fitted for making cheese.
tgt_text.1793: Around Torona the cows fail in their milk a few days before calving, but give milk all the rest of the time.
tgt_text.1794: In women dark-coloured milk is better for the children than that which is white ;
tgt_text.1795: and black women are better nurses than white women.
tgt_text.1796: The most nutritious milk is that which contains the most cheese, but that which contains less cheese is better for infants.
tgt_text.1798: ALL sanguineous animals eject the spermatic fluid;
tgt_text.1799: the office it performs in generation, and how it is performed, will be treated of in another place.
tgt_text.1800: In proportion to his size man ejects more than other animals.
tgt_text.1801: This fluid, in ani­ mals covered with hair, is glutinous, in others it is not glu­ tinous ;
tgt_text.1802: in all it is white, so that Herodotus is mistaken when he says that the Ethiopians have black semen.
tgt_text.1804: The semen comes out white and thick if it is healthy, but after ejection it becomes thin and black ;
tgt_text.1805: it does not thicken with cold, but becomes thin and watery, both in colour and den-, sity.
tgt_text.1806: By heat it coagulates and thickens, and when it has been ejected for any time into the uterus, it comes out more thick, and sometimes dry and twisted together.
tgt_text.1807: That which is fruitful sinks in water, but the barren mixes with it.
tgt_text.1808: All that Ctesias said about the semen of the elephant is false.1.
tgt_text.1809: WE have hitherto treated of sanguineous animals, the parts possessed by all as well as those which are peculiar to each class, and of their heterogeneous and homogeneous, their external and internal parts.
tgt_text.1810: We are now about to treat of ex-sanguineous animals.
tgt_text.1811: There are many classes of these, first of all the mollusca.
tgt_text.1813: These are ex-sanguineous animals, which have their, fleshy parts external, and their hard parts internal, like sanguineous animals, as the whole tribe of cuttle-fish.
tgt_text.1814: Next the malacostraca, these are animals which have their hard parts external, and their in­ terior parts soft and fleshy;
tgt_text.1815: their hard parts are rather liable to contusion than brittle, as the class of carabi and cancri.
tgt_text.1817: Another class is that of the testacea.
tgt_text.1818: These are ani­ mals which have their internal parts fleshy, and their ex­ ternal parts hard, brittle, and fragile, but not liable to contusion.
tgt_text.1819: Snails and oysters are instances of this class.
tgt_text.1820: 3. The fourth class is that of insects, which includes many dissimilar forms.
tgt_text.1821: Insects are animals which, as their name signifies, are insected either in their lower or upper part, or in both;
tgt_text.1822: they have neither distinct flesh nor bone, but something between both, for their body is equally hard internally and externally.
tgt_text.1823: There are apterous insects, as the julus and scolopendra;
tgt_text.1824: and winged, as the bee, cockchafer, and wasp;
tgt_text.1825: and in some kinds there are both winged and apterous in­ sects ;
tgt_text.1826: ants, for example, are both winged and apterous, and so is the glowworm.
tgt_text.1828: These are the parts of animals of the class mollusca (ma­ lacia) ;
tgt_text.1829: first the feet, as they are called, next to these the head, continuous with them ;
tgt_text.1830: the third part is the abdomen, which contains the viscera.
tgt_text.1831: Some persons, speaking incor­ rectly, call this the head.
tgt_text.1832: The fins are placed in a circle round this abdomen.
tgt_text.1833: It happens in many of the malaria that the head is placed between the feet and the abdomen.
tgt_text.1835: All the polypi, except one kind, have eight feet, with a double row of suckers.
tgt_text.1836: The sepia,1 teuthis,2 and teuthos1 possess as a characteristic part two long proboscidiform mem­ bers, which have rough suckers at their extremities, with which they seize their food and bring it to their mouth;
tgt_text.1837: and when a storm arises they weather it out, fastening these members upon a rock, like an anchor.
tgt_text.1838: They swim by means of the fin-like members which are attached to the abdomen.
tgt_text.1839: There are suckers upon all their feet.
tgt_text.1841: The polypus4 uses its tentacula both as feet and hands, for it brings its food to its mouth with the two that are above the mouth, and it uses the last of its tentacula, which is the sharpest of all, in the act of coition ;
tgt_text.1842: this is the only one which is at all white, and it is divided at the extre­ mity, it is placed upon the back;
tgt_text.1843: and the smooth part, in front of which are the acetabula, is called the back.
tgt_text.1844: In front of the abdomen, and above the tentacula, they have a hollow tube, by which they eject the sea-water which they have received into the abdomen, if any enters through the mouth.
tgt_text.1845: This part varies in position, and is sometimes on the right side, sometimes on the left, and by this its ink is ejected.
tgt_text.1847: It swims sideways upon the part called the head, stretching out its feet;
tgt_text.1848: as it swims it is able to see forwards, for the eyes are upwards, and the mouth is placed behind.
tgt_text.1849: As long as it is alive the head is hard, as if it were inflated;
tgt_text.1850: it touches and holds with its tentacula bent downwards, a membrane is extended 'throughout, between the feet, if it falls into the sand, it can no longer hold by it.8.
tgt_text.1851: The polypus and the above-mentioned malacia differ from each other;
tgt_text.1852: the abdomen of the polypus is small, and the feet are large;
tgt_text.1853: but of the others, the abdomen is large, and the feet small, so that they cannot walk upon them.
tgt_text.1854: They have also differences among each other;
tgt_text.1855: the teu­ this is the smallest, the sepia wider;
tgt_text.1856: the teuthos is much larger than the teuthis, for it reaches the length of five cubits.
tgt_text.1857: Some sepiæ are two cubits long, and the tentacula of the polypus are as long, and even larger in size.
tgt_text.1859: The class of the teuthos is rare, and differs in form from the teuthis, for the extremity of the teuthos is wider;
tgt_text.1860: and, again, the fin is placed round the whole abdomen, but it is wanting in the teuthis.
tgt_text.1861: It is a marine animal, as well as the teuthis.
tgt_text.1862: After the feet, the head of all these animals is placed in the middle of the feet, which are called tentacula;
tgt_text.1863: one part of this is the mouth, in which are two teeth ;
tgt_text.1864: above these are two large eyes ;
tgt_text.1865: between these is a small cartilage, containing a small brain.
tgt_text.1867: In the mouth is a small piece of flesh, for these animals have no tongue, but use this instead of a tongue.
tgt_text.1868: After this, on the outside, the abdomen is apparent.
tgt_text.1869: The flesh of this can be divided, not in a straight line, but in a circle.
tgt_text.1870: All the malacia have a skin around this part.
tgt_text.1871: After the mouth, they have a long and narrow oesophagus ;
tgt_text.1872: and con­ tinuous with this is a large round crop, like that of a bird;
tgt_text.1873: this contains the stomach, like a net.
tgt_text.1874: Its form is spiral, like the helix of a whelk;
tgt_text.1875: from this a thin intestine turns back, to the vicinity of the mouth.
tgt_text.1876: The intestine is thicker than the stomach.
tgt_text.1877: 11. The malacia have no viscus, except that which is called the mytis,l and the ink which is upon it.
tgt_text.1878: The most abundant and largest of all is that of the sepia;
tgt_text.1879: all ex­ clude this ink, when alarmed, but especially the sepia;
tgt_text.1880: the mytis lies beneath the mouth;
tgt_text.1881: and through this the œso­ phagus passes;
tgt_text.1882: and where the intestine turns back the ink is beneath, and the same membrane surrounds both the ink and the intestine.
tgt_text.1883: The same orifice serves for the emission of the ink and the foeces.
tgt_text.1885: There are some appearances of hair2 in their bodies ;
tgt_text.1886: the sepia, teuthis, and teuthos, have a hard part upon the forward part of the body;
tgt_text.1887: the one is called septum (the bone of the cuttle-fish), the other xiphus (the pen of the loligo).
tgt_text.1889: for that of the sepia is strong and wide, partaking of the nature of spine and bone, and it contains a spongy, friable substance;
tgt_text.1890: but the pen of the teuthis is thin, and cartilaginous.
tgt_text.1891: In their form also they correspond with the differences of the animals themselves.
tgt_text.1892: The polypus has no hard internal part, but a portion of car­ tilage round the head, which becomes hard as they grow old.
tgt_text.1894: The females also differ from the males, for the latter have a passage beneath the oesophagus, extending from the brain to the lowest part of the body.
tgt_text.1895: That part to which it reaches is like a teat.
tgt_text.1896: In the female there are two such organs, which are placed above.
tgt_text.1897: In both sexes, some small red bodies are placed under these.
tgt_text.1898: The polypus has one capsule of eggs, which is uneven on the surface ;
tgt_text.1900: internally it is all of a white colour, and smooth.
tgt_text.1901: The multitude of the ova is so great as to fill a vessel larger than the head of the polypus.
tgt_text.1902: 14. The sepia has two capsules, and many eggs are in them, like white hailstones.
tgt_text.1903: The position of each of these parts may be seen in anatomical diagrams.
tgt_text.1904: In all these creatures the male differs from the female, and especially in the sepia.
tgt_text.1905: The fore part of the abdomen of the male is always darker than the back;
tgt_text.1906: and more rough than in the female, and variegated wi ch stripes, and the extremity of the body is more acute.
tgt_text.1908: There are many kinds of polypus ;
tgt_text.1909: one, which is the largest of all, is very common.
tgt_text.1910: Those near land are larger than those which are caught out at sea.
tgt_text.1911: There are smaller kinds, which are variegated;
tgt_text.1912: these are not articles of food;
tgt_text.1913: and two others, one of which is called eledone,1 differs in the length of its feet, and is the only one of the malacia with a single row of suckers, for all the rest have two;
tgt_text.1914: the other is called bolitæna,2 and sometimes ozolis.
tgt_text.1916: There are two other kinds which dwell in shells, which some persons call nautilus3 (and nauticus), and others call it the egg of the polypus;
tgt_text.1917: its shell is like that of the hollow pecten, and not like that which has its shells close together:
tgt_text.1919: This animal generally feeds near the land ;
tgt_text.1920: when it is thrown upon the shore by the waves, after its shell has fallen off, it cannot escape, and dies upon the land.
tgt_text.1921: These animals are small in form, like the bolitæna;
tgt_text.1922: and there is another,5 which inhabits a shell like a snail.
tgt_text.1923: This animal never leaves its shell, but remains in it, like the snail, and sometimes stretches out its tentacula.
tgt_text.1924: Let thus much be said about the malacia.1.
tgt_text.1925: OF the malocostraca, there is one genus, of carabi,1 and another, very like it, of astaci these differ from the carabi, which have no claws, and in some other respects.
tgt_text.1926: There is a third genus, of carides,3 and a fourth, of carcini.
tgt_text.1928: There are more genera of carides, and of carcini;
tgt_text.1929: for among the carides are the cyphæ,5 the crangon," and a small species, for these never grow large.
tgt_text.1931: The family of carcini is more various, and not so easily enumerated;
tgt_text.1932: the largest genus is that called maia,7 the next to this the pagurua,8 and the Heracleot carcini;
tgt_text.1933: and, again, those that live in rivers.
tgt_text.1934: The other genera are small, and have not received any name.
tgt_text.1935: On the Phenician coast there are some that they call horsemen, because they run so fast that it is difficult to catch them, and when opened, they are empty, because they have no pasture.
tgt_text.1936: There is another small genus like carcini, but in shape they resemble astaci.3.
tgt_text.1937: All these creatures, as I observed before, have their hard and shelly coats on the outsides of their bodies in the place of skin, the fleshy part is internal.
tgt_text.1938: Their under parts resemble plates, upon which the females deposit their ova;
tgt_text.1939: the carabi have five feet on each side, including the claws;
tgt_text.1940: the carcini, also, have in all ten feet, including the claws, which are last.
tgt_text.1941: Of the carides, the cypha have five on each side;
tgt_text.1942: those near the head are sharp, and five others on each side of the stomach have flat extremities;
tgt_text.1943: they have no plates upon the under part of their body;
tgt_text.1944: those on the upper part are like the carabi.4.
tgt_text.1945: The crangon is different, for it has, first of all, four plates on each side, and, afterwards, three slight ones, con­ tinuous with those on each side, and the greater part of the remainder of its body is apodal;
tgt_text.1946: all the feet are directed outwards to the side, like those of insects;
tgt_text.1947: but the claws, in those that have them, all turned inwards.
tgt_text.1948: The carabus also has a tail, and five fin-like appendages.
tgt_text.1949: The cypha, among the carides, has a tail, with four fin-like appendages.
tgt_text.1950: The crangon has fin-like processes on each side of the tail, and the middle of them is spinous on both sides;
tgt_text.1951: but this part is wide in the crangon, and sharp in the cypha.
tgt_text.1952: The careini alone are without a tail;
tgt_text.1953: the body of the carabi and carides is elongated, that of the carcini is rounded.
tgt_text.1955: The male carabus is different from the female, for the female has the first foot divided;
tgt_text.1956: in the male it is formed of a single claw, and the fin-like process on the lower part is large in the female, and interchanged with each other in the neck ;
tgt_text.1957: in the male they are small and not interchanged.
tgt_text.1958: In the male, also, the last feet are furnished with large and sharp processes like spurs;
tgt_text.1959: in the female these are small and smooth.
tgt_text.1960: They all have two large and rough processes, like horns, before their eyes, and two, smaller and smooth, below.
tgt_text.1962: The eyes of all these animals are hard, and capable of motion, inwards, outwards, and to the side ;
tgt_text.1963: the same is the nature of the carcini, in which they are even more move­ able.
tgt_text.1964: In colour the astacus is all of a dull white, sprinkled with black ;
tgt_text.1965: it has eight small feet, as far as the large ones;
tgt_text.1966: after these the large feet are far greater and wider at the extremity than in the carabus, and they are unequal in size;
tgt_text.1967: for on the right side the broad part at the end is long and smooth, on the left side the same part is thick and round;
tgt_text.1968: they are both divided from the extremity like a jaw, with teeth above and below, only that in those on the right the teeth are all small and sharp, and they are sharp at the extremity of the left side;
tgt_text.1969: in the middle they are like molar teeth;
tgt_text.1970: in the lower part are four close together, but in the upper part three, but not close tpgether.
tgt_text.1972: In both claws the upper part is moved and pressed down upon the lower;
tgt_text.1973: both are placed sideways in position, as if intended by nature for seizure and pressure;
tgt_text.1974: above these large feet are two rough ones, a little below the mouth;
tgt_text.1975: and still lower, the branchial organs around the mouth, which are rough and numerous, and these are con­ tinually in motion;
tgt_text.1976: it bends and approximates its two rough feet towards its mouth;
tgt_text.1977: the feet near the mouth have smooth appendages.
tgt_text.1979: It has two teeth like the carabus, above these the long horns, much shorter and smoother than in the carabus;
tgt_text.1980: four others of the same form as these, but still shorter and smoother;
tgt_text.1981: and above these are placed its eyes, which are small and short, and not large like those of the carabus.
tgt_text.1982: The part above the eyes is acute and rough, as it were a forehead, and larger than in the carabus:
tgt_text.1983: on the whole, the head is sharper and the thorax mach wider than in the carabus, and its whole body is more fleshy and soft:
tgt_text.1984: of its right feet, four are divided at the extremity, and four not divided.
tgt_text.1986: The part called the neck is externally divided into five portions, the sixth and last division is wide and has five plates ;
tgt_text.1987: in the inside are four rough plates, upon which the females deposit their ova.
tgt_text.1988: On the outside of each of these which have been mentioned, there is a short and straight spine, and the whole body, with the part called the thorax, is smooth, and not rough as in the carabus.
tgt_text.1989: On the outside of the large feet there are great spines.
tgt_text.1990: The female does not in any way differ from the male, for whether the male or female have larger claws, they are never both of them equal.
tgt_text.1992: All these animals take in sea-water through their mouths ;
tgt_text.1993: the carcini also exhale a small portion of that which they have taken in, and the carabi do this through the branchiform appendages, for the carabi, have many branchi­ form appendages.
tgt_text.1994: All these animals have two teeth :
tgt_text.1995: the carabi have two front teeth, and then a fleshy mouth in­ stead of a tongue, from this an oesophagus continued on to the stomach.
tgt_text.1996: And the carabi have a small oesophagus before the stomach, and from this a straight intestine is continued.
tgt_text.1997: In the caraboid animals and the carides, this is continued to the tail in a straight passage, by which they eject their excrements, and deposit their ova.
tgt_text.1998: In the carcini this is in the middle of the folded part, for the place wherein they deposit their ova is external in these also.
tgt_text.2000: All the females also, besides the intestines, have a place for their ova, and the part called mytis1 or mecon, which is greater or less, and the peculiar differences may be learned by studying the individual cases.
tgt_text.2001: The carabi, as I have ob­ served, have two large and hollow teeth, in which there is a juice resembling the mytis, and, between the teeth, a piece of flesh resembling a tongue;
tgt_text.2002: from the mouth a short oesophagus extends to a membranous stomach ;
tgt_text.2003: in the part of this nearest the mouth are three teeth, two opposite and one below.
tgt_text.2004: 12. And from the side of the stomach there is a simple intestine, which is of equal thickness throughout, reaching to the anus.
tgt_text.2005: All these parts belong to the carabi, carides, and carcini;
tgt_text.2006: and, besides these, the carabi have a passage sus­ pended from the breast and reaching to the anus ;
tgt_text.2007: in the female this performs the office of a uterus, in the male it contains the spermatic fluid.
tgt_text.2008: This passage is in the cavity of the flesh, so as to appear to be between portions of the flesh, for the intestine is toward the curved part, but the passage towards the cavity in the same way as in quadru­ peds.
tgt_text.2009: In the male this part differs in nothing from the female, for both are smooth and white, and contain an ochre­ ous fluid, and in both sexes it is appended to the breast.
tgt_text.2011: The ova and spirals occupy the same position in the carides.
tgt_text.2012: The male is distinguished from the female by having in the flesh upon the breast two distinct white bodies, in colour and position like the tentacula of the sepia;
tgt_text.2013: these appendages are spiriform, like the mecon of the whelk;
tgt_text.2014: their origin is from the acetabula, which are placed under the last feet.
tgt_text.2015: These contain a red sanguineous flesh, which is smooth to the touch, and not like flesh.
tgt_text.2016: From the whelk­ like appendage there is another spiral fold, about as thick as a thread, below which there are two sand-like bodies appended to the intestine, containing a seminal fluid.
tgt_text.2017: These are found in the male, but the female has ova of a red colour;
tgt_text.2018: these are joined to the abdomen, and on each side of the intestine to the fleshy part of the body, enclosed in a thin membrane.
tgt_text.2019: These are their internal and external parts.
tgt_text.2021: IT happens that all the internal parts of sanguineous ani­ mals have names, for all these have the internal viscera;
tgt_text.2022: but the same parts of exsanguineous animals have no names, but both classes have in common the stomach, oesophagus, and intestines.
tgt_text.2023: I have before spoken of the carcini, and their legs and feet, and how many they have, and in what direc­ tion, and that, for the most part, they have the right claw larger and stronger than the left;
tgt_text.2024: I have also mentioned their eyes, and that most of them are able to see sideways.
tgt_text.2025: The mass of their body is undivided, and so is their head, and any other part.
tgt_text.2027: In some the eyes are placed immediately below the upper part, and generally far apart;
tgt_text.2028: in some they are placed in the middle, and near together, as, in the Heracleot carcini and the maia.
tgt_text.2029: The mouth is placed below the eyes, and contains two teeth, as in the carabus, but they are long and not round, and over these there are two coverings, between which are the appendages, which the carabus also possesses.
tgt_text.2031: They receive water through their mouth, opening the opercula, and emit it again by the upper passage of the mouth, closing the opercula by which it entered;
tgt_text.2032: these are im­ mediately beneath the eyes, and when they take in water they close the mouth with both opercula, and thus eject again the sea-water.
tgt_text.2033: Next to the teeth is a very short oesophagus, so that the mouth appears joined to the sto­ mach, and from this proceeds a divided stomach, from the middle of which is a single thin intestine;
tgt_text.2034: this intestine ends externally beneath the folding of the extremity, as I said before.
tgt_text.2035: Between the opercula there is something resembling the appendages to the teeth of the carabi;
tgt_text.2036: within the abdo­ men is an ochreous chyme, and some small elongated white bodies, and other red ones scattered through it.
tgt_text.2037: The male differs from the female in length and width, and in the abdo­ minal covering, for this is longer in the female, farther from the body, and more thick-set with appendages, as in the female carabi.
tgt_text.2038: The parts of the malacostraca are of this nature.
tgt_text.2039: 1. THE testacea, as cochleæ,1 and cochli,2 and all that are called ostrea, and the family of echini, are composed of flesh, and this flesh is like that of the malacostraci, for it is internal;
tgt_text.2040: but the shell is external, and they have no hard internal part.
tgt_text.2041: But they have many differences amongst themselves, both in regard to their external shells and their internal flesh, for some of them have no flesh at all, as the echinus ;
tgt_text.2042: in others it is entirely internal and out of sight, except the head, as the land snails and those called coccalia,1 and in the sea the purpura and the ceryx,3 the cochlus, and all the turbinated shells.
tgt_text.2044: Of the rest some are bivalves, others univalves.
tgt_text.2045: I call those bivalves which are enclosed in two shells;
tgt_text.2046: the univalves are enclosed in one shell, and the fleshy part is uncovered, as the.
tgt_text.2048: Some of the bivalves can open, as the pectens and mya, for all these are joined on one side, and separated on the other, so as to shut and open.
tgt_text.2049: There are other bivalves which are joined on both sides, as the solen;
tgt_text.2050: others which are entirely enclosed in their shells, and have no external naked flesh, as those which are called tethya.
tgt_text.2052: And there is a great difference amongst the shells themselves, for some are smooth, as the solen, mya, and some conchæ, called by some persons galaces;
tgt_text.2053: 6 other shells are rough, as the limnostrea,7 pinnae, some kinds of conchae, and the whelk;
tgt_text.2054: and of these some are marked with ridges, as the pecten and a kind of concha, others are without ridges, as the pinna and another species of concha.
tgt_text.2055: They also differ in thickness and thinness, both in the whole shell and in certain parts of the shell, as about the edges, for in some the edges are thin, as the mya;
tgt_text.2056: others are thick-edged, as the limnostrea.
tgt_text.2058: Some of them are capable of motion, as the pecten, for some persons say that the pectens can fly, for that they sometimes leap out of the instrument by which they are taken.
tgt_text.2059: Others, as the pinna, cannot move from the point of attachment;
tgt_text.2060: all the turbinated shells can move and crawl;
tgt_text.2061: the lepas (patella) also feeds by going from place to place.
tgt_text.2062: It is common to all those with hard shells to have them smooth in the inside.
tgt_text.2064: Both in univalves and bivalves the fleshy part is united to the shell, so that it can only be separated by force ;
tgt_text.2065: it is more easily separated from the turbinated shells;
tgt_text.2066: it is a characteristic of all these shells, that the base of the shell has the helix directed from the head.
tgt_text.2067: All of them from their birth have an operculum;
tgt_text.2068: all the turbinated testacea are right-handed, and move, not in the direction of the helix, but the contrary way.
tgt_text.2070: The external parts of these creatures are thus distin­ guished ;
tgt_text.2071: the nature of their internal structure is similar in all, especially in the turbinated animals, for they differ in size and in the relations of excess, the univalves and bivalves do not exhibit many differences.
tgt_text.2072: Most of them have but few distinctive marks from each other, but they differ more from the immovable creatures.
tgt_text.2073: This will be more evident from the following considerations.
tgt_text.2074: In na­ ture they are all alike, the difference, as before said, is in excess;
tgt_text.2075: for in larger species the parts are more conspicuous, and less so in those that are smaller.
tgt_text.2076: They differ also in hardness and softness, and such like affections.
tgt_text.2078: For all have on the outside of the shell, in the mouth, a hard piece of flesh, some more, some less;
tgt_text.2079: from the middle of this are the head and the two horns ;
tgt_text.2080: these are large in larger species, in the little ones they are very small.
tgt_text.2081: The head is protruded in the same manner in all of them, and when the creature is alarmed it is again retracted;
tgt_text.2082: some have a mouth and teeth, as the snail, which has small, sharp, and smooth teeth.
tgt_text.2084: They have also a proboscis, like that of the fly, and this organ is like a tongue.
tgt_text.2085: In the ceryx and the purpura this organ is hard, like that of the myops and oestrus, with which they pierce through the skins of quadrupeds;
tgt_text.2086: but this is more powerful in strength, for they can pierce through the shells of the baits.
tgt_text.2087: The stomach is joined quite closely to the mouth ;
tgt_text.2088: the stomach of the cochlus is like the crop of a bird;
tgt_text.2089: below this there are two hard white substances like nipples, which also exist in the sepia, but are much harder.
tgt_text.2091: From the stomach a long, simple intestine reaches as far as the spiral, which is on the extremity of the body.
