tgt_text.2092: These are distinct, and in the purpura and the ceryx are in the helix of the shell.
tgt_text.2093: The bowel is continuous with the intes­ tine.
tgt_text.2094: The intestine and bowels are joined together, and are quite simple, to the anus.
tgt_text.2095: The origin of the bowel is around the helix of the mecon,l and here it is wider.
tgt_text.2096: The mecon is, as it were, a superfluous part in all testacea, afterwards an­ other bend causes it to return to the fleshy part;
tgt_text.2097: the end of the entrail, where the faeces are emitted, is near the head, and is alike in all turbinated shells, whether terrestrial or marine.
tgt_text.2099: In the larger cochli a long white passage, contained in a membrane, and in colour resembling the upper mastoid appendages, is joined from the stomach to the oesophagus, and it is divided into segments like the ovum of the carabus, except that it is white, while the other is red.
tgt_text.2100: It has neither exit nor passage, but it is contained in a thin mem­ brane, which has a narrow cavity.
tgt_text.2101: From the intestine black and rough bodies descend continuously, like those in the tortoise, but they are less black.
tgt_text.2102: 11. Both these and white bodies occur in the marine cochli, but they are less in the smaller kinds.
tgt_text.2103: The univalves and bivalves are in some respects like these, and in others they are different, for they have a head, horns, and mouth, and something like a tongue, though in smaller species these are inconspicuous from their minute size, and they are not discernible when the animals are dead or at rest.
tgt_text.2104: They all contain the mecon, but not in the same position, nor of the same size, nor equally conspicuous.
tgt_text.2105: In the lepas it is in the bottom of the shell, in the bivalves near the hinge.
tgt_text.2107: They all have hair-like appendages placed in a circle, and so have the pectens, and that which is called the ovarium in those that have it;
tgt_text.2108: where it is possessed, it is placed in a circle on the other side of the circumference, like the white portion in the cochli, for this is alike in all.
tgt_text.2109: All these parts, as I have said, are conspicuous in the larger kinds, but in smaller not at all, or scarcely so, wherefore they are most conspicuous in the larger pectens, and these have one valve flat like an operculum.
tgt_text.2111: The anus is placed in the side in some of these crea­ tures, for this is where the excrement passes out.
tgt_text.2112: The mecon, as I have said, is a superfluous part enclosed in a thin mem­ brane in all of them ;
tgt_text.2113: that which is called the ovarium has no passage in any of them, but it swells out in the flesh.
tgt_text.2114: This is not placed upon the intestine, for the ovarium is on the right side and the intestine on the left;
tgt_text.2115: the anus is the same as in others;
tgt_text.2116: but in the wild patella, as some persons call it, or the sea-ear (haliotis), as it is named by others, the excrement passes out below the shell, for the shell is perforated.
tgt_text.2117: The stomach also is distinct behind the mouth, and so is the ova­ rium in this animal.
tgt_text.2118: The position of all these parts may be seen in dissections.
tgt_text.2120: The creature called carcinium1 resembles both the malacostraca and the testacea, for this in its nature is similar to the animals that are like carabi, and it is born naked (not covered with a shell).
tgt_text.2121: But because it makes its way into a shell, and lives in it, it resembles the testacea, and for these reasons it partakes of the character of both classes.
tgt_text.2122: Its shape, to speak plainly, is that of a spider, except that the lower part of the head and thorax is larger.
tgt_text.2124: It has two thin red horns, and two large eyes below these, not within nor turned on one side, like those of the crab, but straight forwards.
tgt_text.2125: Below these is the mouth, and round it many hair-like appendages ;
tgt_text.2126: next to these, two divided feet with which it seizes its prey, and two besides these on each side, and a third pair smaller.
tgt_text.2127: Below the thorax the whole creature is soft, and when laid open is yellow within.
tgt_text.2129: From the mouth is a passage as far as the stomach;
tgt_text.2131: the feet and the thorax are hard, but less so than those of the cancri;
tgt_text.2132: it is not united with the shell like the purpura and ceryx, but is easily liberated from it.
tgt_text.2133: The individuals which inhabit the shells of the strombus are longer than those in the shells of the nerita.
tgt_text.2135: The kind which inhabits the nerita is different, though very like in other respects, for the right divided foot is small, and the left one large, and it walks more upon this than the other;
tgt_text.2136: and a similar animal is found in.
tgt_text.2137: the conchæ, though they are united to their shells very firmly;
tgt_text.2140: The nerita has a smooth, large, round shell, in form resembling that of the ceryx, but the mecon is not black, but red;
tgt_text.2141: it is strongly united in the middle.
tgt_text.2143: In fine weather they seek their food at liberty, and if a storm arises, the carcinia hide themselves under a stone, and the neritæ attach themselves to it like the patella, the hæmorrhois, and all that class, for they become attached to the rock, where they close their operculum, for this re­ sembles a lid ;
tgt_text.2144: for that part which is in both sides in the ;
tgt_text.2145: bivalves is joined to one side in the turbinated shells:
tgt_text.2146: the " interior is fleshy, and in this the mouth is placed.
tgt_text.2147: 19. The nature of the hsemorrhois, the purpura, and all such animals is the same.
tgt_text.2148: But those which have the left foot greater are not found in the shells of the strombus, but in the neritæ.
tgt_text.2149: There are some cochli which contain an ani­ mal like the small astacus, which is found in rivers;
tgt_text.2150: but they differ from them in having the inner part of the shell soft.
tgt_text.2151: Their form may be seen by examining dissections.
tgt_text.2152: 1. THE echini contain no flesh, but this part is peculiar, for they are all of them void of flesh, and are filled with a black substance.
tgt_text.2153: There are many kinds of echinus, one of which is eatable;
tgt_text.2154: in this one the ova are large and eatable, both in the greater and the less.
tgt_text.2156: And there are two other kinds, the spatangus and that called bryttus;
tgt_text.2157: these are inhabitants of the sea, and rare.
tgt_text.2158: Those which are called echinometræ1 are the largest of all.
tgt_text.2159: Besides this, there is another small species, which has long and sharp spines;
tgt_text.2160: this is procured from the sea, in many fathoms water, and some persons use it for stranguary.
tgt_text.2162: Around Torona there are white marine echini, which have shells, and prickles, and ova, and are longer than others;
tgt_text.2163: but the prickle is neither large nor strong, but soft, and the black parts from the mouth are more in number, and united to the outward passage, but distinct among themselves, and by these the animal is as it were divided.
tgt_text.2164: The eatable kinds are particularly and especially active, and it is a sign of them;
tgt_text.2165: for they have always something adhering to their spines.
tgt_text.2167: They all contain ova, but in some they are very small, and not eatable:
tgt_text.2168: that which is called the head and mouth in the echinus is downwards, and the anus placed upwards.
tgt_text.2169: The same thing occurs in the turbinated shells, and the patella;
tgt_text.2170: for their food is placed below them, so that the mouth is towards the food, and the anus at or on the upper part of the shell.
tgt_text.2172: The echinus has five hollow internal teeth, in the midst of these a portion of flesh like a tongue ;
tgt_text.2173: next to this is the oesophagus;
tgt_text.2174: then the stomach, in five divisions, full of fæcu­ lent matter:
tgt_text.2175: all its cavities unite in one, near the anus, where the shell is perforated.
tgt_text.2177: other membrane, are the ova, the same number in all, they are five in number, and uneven.
tgt_text.2179: The black substance is joined above to the origin of the teeth, this black substance is bitter and not eatable;
tgt_text.2180: in many animals there is either this substance or its analogue, for it is found in tortoises, toads, frogs, turbinated shells, and in the malacia;
tgt_text.2181: these parts differ in colour, but are entirely or nearly uneatable.
tgt_text.2182: The body of the echinus is undivided from be­ ginning to end, but the shell is not so when seen through, for it is like a lantern, with no skin around it.
tgt_text.2183: The echinus uses its spines as feet, for it moves along by leaning upon them and moving them.
tgt_text.2185: THE creatures called tethya1 have a most distinct charac.
tgt_text.2186: ter, for in these alone is the whole body concealed in a shell.
tgt_text.2187: Their shell is intermediate between skin and shell, so that it can be cut like hard leather:
tgt_text.2188: this shell-like sub­ stance is attached to rocks;
tgt_text.2189: in it there are two perforations, quite distant from each other, and not easily seen, by which it excludes and receives water, for it has no visible excre­ ment as other testacea, neither like the echinus, nor the substance called mecon.
tgt_text.2191: When laid open, there is first of all a sinewy membrane lining the shell-like substance, within this the fleshy sub­ stance of the tethyon.
tgt_text.2192: Unlike any other creature, its flesh, however, is alike throughout, and it is united in two places to the membrane and the skin from the side, and at its points of union it is narrower on each side;
tgt_text.2193: by these places it reaches to the external perforations which pass through the shell;
tgt_text.2194: there it both parts with and receives food and moisture, as if one were the mouth, the other the anus, the one is thick, the other thinner.
tgt_text.2196: Internally there is a cavity at each end, and a passage passes through it;
tgt_text.2197: there is a fluid in both the cavities.
tgt_text.2198: Be­ sides this, it has no sensitive or organic member, nor is there any excrementitious matter, as I said before.
tgt_text.2199: The colour of the tethyon is partly ochreous, partly red.4.
tgt_text.2201: it adheres to rocks like some of the testacea, but at times it is washed off.
tgt_text.2202: It is not covered with a shell, but its whole body is fleshy;
tgt_text.2203: it is sen­ sitive, and seizes upon the hand that touches it, and it holds fast, like the polypus does with its tentacula, so as to make the flesh swell up.
tgt_text.2204: It has a central mouth, and lives upon the rock, as well as upon shell-fish, and if any small fish falls in its way, it lays hold of it as with a hand, and if any eat­ able thing falls in its way it devours it.
tgt_text.2206: One species is free, and feeds upon anything it meets with, even pectens and echini;
tgt_text.2207: it appears to have no visible excrement, and in this respect it resembles plants.
tgt_text.2208: There are two kinds of acalephe, some small and more eatable, others large and hard, such as are found near Chalcis.
tgt_text.2209: Dur­ ing winter their flesh is compact, wherefore in this season they are caught and eaten;
tgt_text.2210: in summer time they perish, for they become soft;
tgt_text.2211: if they are touched they soon melt down, and cannot by any means be taken away.
tgt_text.2212: When suffering from heat, they prefer getting under stones.
tgt_text.2213: I have now treated of malacia, malacostraca, testacea, and of their exter­ nal and internal parts.
tgt_text.2215: INSECTS must now be treated of in the same manner.
tgt_text.2216: This is a class which contains many forms, and no common name has been given to unite those that are naturally related, as the bee, anthrene,1 and wasp, and such like;
tgt_text.2217: again, those which have their wings enclosed in a case, as the melolontha,2 carabus,3 cantharis, and such like.
tgt_text.2218: The common parts of all insects are three-the head, the abdo­ men, and the third, which is between these, such as in other animals is the breast and back.
tgt_text.2219: In many insects this is one, but in the long insects with many legs, the middle parts are equal to the number of segments.
tgt_text.2221: All insects survive being divided, except those which are naturally cold, or soon become so from their small size, so that wasps live after they are cut asunder;
tgt_text.2222: either the head or the abdomen will live if united to the thorax, but the head will not live alone.
tgt_text.2223: Those which are long, and have many feet, will survive division for a considerable time;
tgt_text.2224: both the extremities are capable of motion, for they walk both upon the part cut off and upon the tail, as that which is called scolopendra.
tgt_text.2225: All of them have eyes, but no other manifest organs of sense, except that some have a tongue.
tgt_text.2226: All the testacea have this organ, which serves the double purpose of tasting and drawing food into the mouth.
tgt_text.2228: In some of them this organ is soft;
tgt_text.2229: in others very strong, as in the purpura;
tgt_text.2230: in the myops and oestrus this member is strong, and in a great many more;
tgt_text.2231: for this mem­ ber is used as a weapon by all those that have no caudal sting.
tgt_text.2233: Those with this weapon have no small external teeth, for flies draw blood by touching with this organ, and gnats sting with it.
tgt_text.2234: Some insects also have stings, which are either internal, as in bees and wasps, or external, as in the scorpion.
tgt_text.2235: This last is the only insect that has a long tail;
tgt_text.2236: it has claws, and so has the little scorpion-like creature1 found in books.
tgt_text.2237: The winged insects, in addition to other parts, have wings.
tgt_text.2238: Some have two wings, as the flies;
tgt_text.2240: none of the diptera have a caudal sting.
tgt_text.2241: Some of the winged insects have elytra on their wings, as the melolontha;
tgt_text.2242: and others no elytra, as the bee.
tgt_text.2243: Insects do not direct their flight with their tail, and their wings have neither shaft nor division.
tgt_text.2245: Some have a horn before their eyes, as the psyche and carabi.
tgt_text.2246: Of the jumping insects, some have their hind-legs larger;
tgt_text.2247: others have the organs of jumping bent backwards, like the legs of quadrupeds.
tgt_text.2248: In all, the upper part is dif­ ferent from the lower, like other animals.
tgt_text.2250: The flesh of their bodies is neither testaceous nor like the internal parts of testacea, but between the two.
tgt_text.2251: Wherefore, also, they have neither spine nor bone, as the sepia;
tgt_text.2252: nor are they surrounded with a shell.
tgt_text.2253: For the body is its own protection by its hardness, and requires no other support;
tgt_text.2254: and they have a very thin skin.
tgt_text.2255: This is the nature of their external parts.
tgt_text.2257: Internally, immediately after the mouth, there is an intestine which in most insects passes straight and simply to the anus, in a few it is convoluted;
tgt_text.2258: these have no bones nor fat, neither has any other exsanguineous animal.
tgt_text.2259: Some have a stomach, and from this the remainder of the intes.
tgt_text.2260: tine is either simple or convoluted, as in the aerial
tgt_text.2261: The tettix (grasshopper) alone of this, or any other class of living creatures, has no mouth ;
tgt_text.2262: but, like those with a caudal sting, it has the appearance of a tongue, long, continuous, and undivided, and with this it feeds upon the dew alone.
tgt_text.2263: There is no excrement in the stomach.
tgt_text.2264: There are many kinds of these creatures, they differ in being greater or less;
tgt_text.2265: those called achetae are divided beneath the diaphragm, and have a conspicuous membrane, which the tettigonia has not.8.
tgt_text.2266: There are many other creatures in the sea which it is not possible to arrange in any class from their scarcity.
tgt_text.2267: For some experienced fishermen say they have seen in the sea creatures like small beams, black and round, and of the same thickness throughout;
tgt_text.2268: others like shields, of a red colour, with many fins ;
tgt_text.2269: others'like the human penis in appearance and size, but instead of testicles they had two fins, and that such have been taken on the extremity of grappling irons.
tgt_text.2270: This is the nature of the internal and external parts of all animals of every kind, both those which are peculiar to cer­ tain species, and-those which are common to all.1.
tgt_text.2271: WE must now treat of the Senses:
tgt_text.2272: for they are not alike in all, but some have all the senses, and some fewer.
tgt_text.2273: They are mostly five in number;
tgt_text.2274: seeing, hearing, smelling, taste, touch, and besides these there are none peculiar to any creatures.
tgt_text.2275: Man, then, and all viviparous animals with feet, besides all sanguineous and viviparous animals, have all these, unless they are undeveloped in any particular kind, as in the mole.
tgt_text.2277: For this creature has no sight, it has no apparent eyes, but when the thick skin which surrounds the head is taken away, in the place where the eyes ought to be on the out­ side, are the undeveloped internal eyes, which have all the parts of true eyes, for they have both the iris of the eye, and within the iris the part called the pupil, and the white;
tgt_text.2278: but all these are less than in true eyes.
tgt_text.2279: On the outside there is no appearance of these parts, from the thickness of the skin, as if the nature of the eye had been destroyed at birth;
tgt_text.2280: for there are two sinewy and strong passages proceeding from the brain, where it unites with the spinal cord, reaching from the socket of the eye, and ending upon the upper sharp teeth.
tgt_text.2282: All other animals are endued with the perception of colours, sounds, smells, and taste.
tgt_text.2283: All animals have the fifth sense, which is called touch.
tgt_text.2284: In some animals the organs of sense are very distinct, and especially the eyes, for they have a definite place, and so has the hearing.
tgt_text.2285: For some animals have ears, and others open perforations:
tgt_text.2286: so also of the sense of smelling, some animals have nostrils, others passages, as the whole class of birds.
tgt_text.2287: In the same way the tongue is the organ of taste.
tgt_text.2289: In aquatic animals and those called fish, the tongue is still the organ of taste, though it is indistinct, for it is bony, and not capable of free motion.
tgt_text.2290: In some fish the roof of the mouth is fleshy, as in some cyprini among river fish, so that, without careful examination, it appears like a tongue.
tgt_text.2291: That they have the sense of taste is quite clear, for many of them delight in peculiar food, and they will more readily seize upon a bait formed of the amia and other fat fishes, as if they delighted in the taste and eating of such baits.
tgt_text.2293: They have no evident organ of hearing and smelling, for the passages which exist about the region of the nostrils in some fish do not appear to pass to the brain, but some of them are blind, and others lead to the gills;
tgt_text.2294: it is evident, however, that they both hear and smell, for they escape from loud noises, such as the oars of the triremes, so as to be easily captured in their hiding-places.
tgt_text.2296: For if the external noise is not loud, yet to all aquatic animals that are capable of hearing, it appears harsh and very loud;
tgt_text.2297: and this takes place in hunting dolphins, for when they have enclosed them with their canoes, they make a noise from them in the sea, and the dolphins, crowded together, are obliged to leap upon the land, and, being stunned with the noise, are easily captured, although even dolphins have no external organs of hearing.
tgt_text.2299: And again in fishing, the fishermen are careful to avoid making a noise with their oars or net when they per­ ceive many fish collected in one place;
tgt_text.2300: they make a signal, and let down their nets in such a place that no sound of the oar or the motion of the waters should reach the place where the fish are collected, and the sailors are commanded to row in the greatest silence until they have enclosed them.
tgt_text.2302: Sometimes, when they wish to drive them together, they proceed as in dolphin catching, for they make a noise with stones that they may be alarmed and collected together, and thus they are enclosed in a net.
tgt_text.2303: Before their inclosure, 'as it was said, they prevent a noise, but as soon as they have enclosed them, they direct the sailors to shout and make a noise, for they fall down with fear when they hear the noise and tumult.
tgt_text.2305: And when the fishers observe large shoals at a dis­ tance, collected on the surface in calm, fine weather, and wish to know their size, and of what kind they are, if they can approach them in silence, they avoid their notice, and catch them while they are on the surface.
tgt_text.2306: If any noise is made before they reach them, they may be seen in flight.
tgt_text.2307: In the rivers, also, there are little fish under the stones, which some persons call cotti :
tgt_text.2308: 1 from their dwelling beneath rocks, they catch them by striking the rocks with stones, and the fishes fall down frightened when they hear the noise, being stunned by it.
tgt_text.2309: It is evident, from these con­ siderations, that fishes have the sense of hearing.
tgt_text.2311: There are persons who say that fish have more acute ears than other animals, and that, from dwelling near the sea, they have often remarked it.
tgt_text.2312: Those fish which have the most acute ears are thecestreus2 (chremps),3 labrax,4 salpe,5 chromis,6 and all such fishes ;
tgt_text.2313: in others the sense of hearing less acute, because they live in the deeper parts of the ocean.
tgt_text.2315: Their nature of smelling is the same, for the greater number of fishes will not take a bait that is not quite fresh;
tgt_text.2317: All fish will not take the same bait, but only particular baits, which they distinguish by the smell;
tgt_text.2318: for some are taken with stinking baits, as the salpe with dung.
tgt_text.2319: Many fish also live in the holes of rocks, and when the fishermen want to entice them out, they anoint (the mouths of these holes with salted scents, to which they readily come.
tgt_text.2321: The eel also is enticed out in this way, for they place a pitcher of salt food, covering the mouth of the pitcher with another vessel pierced with holes, and the eels are quickly drawn forth by the smell of the bait.
tgt_text.2322: Baits made of the roasted flesh of the cuttle fish, on account of its strong smell, attract fish very readily.
tgt_text.2323: They say they put the roasted flesh of the polypus upon their hooks for nothing but its strong smell.
tgt_text.2324: 13. And the fish called rhyades,1 when the washings of fish or of foetid drains are emptied into the water, make their escape as if smelling the foetid odour.
tgt_text.2325: They say that fish soon smell the blood of their own kind;
tgt_text.2326: this is plain from their hastening from any place where the blood of fishes may be.
tgt_text.2327: On the whole, if any one use a putrid bait, the fish will not come near it;
tgt_text.2328: but if a fresh strong-smelling bait is used, they will come to it from a great distance.
tgt_text.2329: 14. This is especially observable in what was said of dolphins, for these creatures have not external organs of hearing, but are captured by being stunned with a noise, as was before observed;
tgt_text.2330: neither have they any external organs of smell, yet their scent is acute.
tgt_text.2331: Therefore, it is evident that all creatures have these senses.
tgt_text.2332: Other kinds of animals are divided into four classes;
tgt_text.2333: and these contain the mul­ titude of remaining animals, namely, the malacia, malaco­ straca, testacea, and insects.
tgt_text.2335: Of these the malacia, the malacostraca, and insects have all the senses, for they can see, smell, and taste.
tgt_text.2336: Insects, whe­ ther they have wings or are apterus, can smell from a great distance, as the bee and the cnips 2 scent honey, for they perceive it from a long distance, as if they discovered it by the scent.
tgt_text.2337: Many of them perish by the fumes of sulphur:
tgt_text.2338: ants leave their hills when origanum and sulphur are sprinkled upon them.
tgt_text.2339: Almost all of them escape from the fumes of burnt stags' horns, but most of all do they avoid the smell of burnt styrax.
tgt_text.2340: 16. The sepia, also, the polypus, and the carabus are caught with baits;
tgt_text.2341: the polypus holds the bait so fast that it holds on even when cut:
tgt_text.2342: if a person hold conyza to them, they let go as soon as they smell it.
tgt_text.2343: So, also, of the sense of taste, for they follow different kinds of food, and do not all prefer the same food, as the bee approaches nothing that is putrid, only sweet things;
tgt_text.2344: the gnat not what is sweet, but what is acid.
tgt_text.2346: As I before observed, the sense of touch belongs to all animals.
tgt_text.2347: The testacea have the senses of smelling and tasting.
tgt_text.2348: This is plain from the baits used, as those for the purpuræ ;
tgt_text.2349: for this creature is caught with putrid substances, and will be attracted from a great distance to such baits, as if by the sense of smell.
tgt_text.2350: It is evident from what follows that they possess the sense of taste;
tgt_text.2351: for whatever they select by smell, they all love to taste.
tgt_text.2353: And all animals with mouths receive pain or pleasure from the contact of food.
tgt_text.2354: But, concerning the senses of sight and hearing, it is not possible to say anything certain, or very distinct;
tgt_text.2355: the solens, if a person touch them, appear to retract themselves, and try to escape when they see an instrument approaching them, for a small portion of them is beyond the shell, the remainder as it were in a retreat;
tgt_text.2356: the pectens, also, if a finger is brought near them, open and shut themselves as if they could see.
tgt_text.2358: Those who seek for neritæ do not approach them with the wind, when they seek them for baits, nor do they speak, but come silently, as if the creatures could both smell and hear;
tgt_text.2359: they say that if they speak, they get away.
tgt_text.2360: Of all testacea, the echinus appears to have the best sense of smell amongst those that can move, and the tethya and balanus in those that are fixed.
tgt_text.2361: This is the nature of the organs of sense in all animals.
tgt_text.2363: THE following is the nature of the voice of animals, for there is a distinction between voice and sound.
tgt_text.2364: Speech, again, is different from these.
tgt_text.2365: Voice is due to no other part except the pharynx, the creatures, therefore, without lungs are also without voice.
tgt_text.2366: Speech is the direction of the voice by the tongue;
tgt_text.2367: the vowels are uttered by the voice and the larynx, the mutes by the tongue and the lips;
tgt_text.2368: speech is made up of these:
tgt_text.2369: wherefore, no animals can speak that have not a tongue, nor if their tongue is confined.
tgt_text.2371: The power of uttering a sound is connected with other parts also;
tgt_text.2372: insects have neither voice nor speech, but make a sound with the air within them, not with that which is external, for some of them breathe not, some of them buzz, as the bee with its wings, and others are said to sing, as the grasshopper.
tgt_text.2373: All these make a noise with the membrane which is beneath the division of their body in those which have a division, as some families of grasshoppers by the friction of the air.
tgt_text.2374: These insects, bees, and all other insects raise and depress their wings in flight, for the sound is the friction of the air within them.
tgt_text.2375: Locusts produce a sound by rubbing themselves with their legs, which are adapted for leaping.
tgt_text.2376: None of the malacia utter any sound or natural voice, nor do the malacostraca.3.
tgt_text.2377: Fish also are mute, for they have neither lungs, trachea, nor pharynx.
tgt_text.2378: Some of them utter a sound and a squeak;
tgt_text.2379: these are said to have a voice, as the lyral and chromic for these utter, as it were, a grunt;
tgt_text.2380: so does the capros, a fish of the Achelous, the chalceus3 and coccyx,4 for the one utters a sound like hissing, the other a noise like that of the cuckoo, from whence also its name is derived.
tgt_text.2381: Some of these utter their apparent voice by the friction of their gills, for these places are spinous, in others the sound is internal, near the stomach.
tgt_text.2382: For each of them has an organ of breathing, which causes a sound when it is pressed and moved about.
tgt_text.2384: Some of the selachea also appear to whistle, but they cannot be correctly said to utter a voice, only to make a sound.
tgt_text.2385: The pectens also make a whizzing noise when they are borne upon the surface of the water, or flying, as it is called;
tgt_text.2386: and so do the sea-swallows,5 for they also fly through the air in the same way, not touching the sea, for they have wide and long fins.
tgt_text.2387: As the sound made by birds flying through the air is not a voice, so neither can either of these be properly so called.
tgt_text.2388: The dolphin also utters a whistle and lows when it comes out of the water into the air, in a different way from the animals above-mentioned-for this is a true voice, for it has lungs and a trachea, but its tongue is not free, nor has it any lips so as to make an articulate sound.
tgt_text.2390: The oviparous quadrupeds, with tongue and lungs, utter a sound, though it is a weak one.
tgt_text.2391: Some of them hiss like serpents;
tgt_text.2392: others have a small weak voice, others, as the tortoise, utter a small hiss.
tgt_text.2393: The tongue of the frog is pe­ culiar, for the fore-part of it is fixed, like that of a fish ;
tgt_text.2394: but the part near the pharynx is free and folded up.
tgt_text.2395: With this it utters its peculiar sound.
tgt_text.2396: The male frogs make a croaking in the.
tgt_text.2397: water when they invite the females to coition.
tgt_text.2398: 6. All animals utter a voice to invite the society and proxi­ mity of their kind, as the hog, the goat, and the sheep.
tgt_text.2399: The frog croaks by making its lower jaw of equal length, and stretching the upper one above the water.
tgt_text.2400: Their eyes ap­ pear like lights, their cheeks being swelled out with the vehemence of their croaking ;
tgt_text.2401: for their copulation is gene­ rally performed in the night.
tgt_text.2402: The class of birds utter a- voice:
tgt_text.2403: those which have a moderately wide tongue have the best voice;
tgt_text.2404: those also in which the tongue is thin.
tgt_text.2405: In some kinds both male and female have the same voice;
tgt_text.2407: the smaller kinds have more variety in their voice, and make more use of it, than the larger tribes.
tgt_text.2409: All birds become more noisy at the season of coition.
tgt_text.2410: Some utter a cry when they are fighting, as the quail;
tgt_text.2411: others when they are going to fight, as the partridge;
tgt_text.2412: or when they have obtained a victory, as the cock.
tgt_text.2413: In some kinds both male and female sing, as the nightingale;
tgt_text.2414: but the female nightingale does not sing while she is sitting or feeding her young:
tgt_text.2415: in some the males alone, as the quail and the cock ;
tgt_text.2417: Viviparous quadrupeds utter dif­ ferent voices;
tgt_text.2418: none can speak-for this is the characteristic of man, for all that have a language have a voice, but not all that have a voice have also a language.
tgt_text.2420: All that are born dumb, and all children, utter sounds, but have no language;
tgt_text.2421: for, as children are not complete in their other parts, so their tongue is not perfect at first;
tgt_text.2422: it becomes more free afterwards, so that they stammer and lisp.
tgt_text.2423: Both voices and language differ in different places.
tgt_text.2425: The voice is most conspicuous in its acuteness or depth, but the form does not differ in the same species of animals;
tgt_text.2426: the mode of articulation differs, and this might be called speech, for it differs in different animals, and in the same genera in different places, as among partridges, for in some places they cackle, in others whistle.
tgt_text.2427: Small birds do not utter the same voice as their parents, if they are brought up away from them, and have only heard other singing birds.
tgt_text.2428: For the nightingale has been observed instructing her young, so that the voice and speech are not naturally alike, but are capable of formation.
tgt_text.2429: And men also have all the same voice, however much they may differ in language.
tgt_text.2430: The elephant utters a voice by breathing through its mouth, making no use of its nose, as when a man breathes forth a sigh;
tgt_text.2431: but with its nose it makes a noise like the hoarse sound of a trumpet.
tgt_text.2433: CONCERNING the sleep and wakefulness of animals.
tgt_text.2434: It is quite manifest that all viviparous animals with feet both sleep and are awake;
tgt_text.2435: for all that have eyelids sleep with the eyes closed;
tgt_text.2436: and not only men appear to dream, but horses, oxen, sheep, goats, dogs, and all viviparous quadrupeds.
tgt_text.2437: Dogs show this by barking in their sleep.
tgt_text.2438: It is not clear whether oviparous animals dream, but it is quite plain that they sleep.
tgt_text.2440: And so it is in aquatic animals, as fish, the malacia, the malacostraca, the carabi, and such like creatures.
tgt_text.2441: The sleep of all these animals is short:
tgt_text.2442: it is plain that they do sleep, though we can form no conclusion from their eyes, for they have no eyelids, but from their not being alarmed;
tgt_text.2443: for if fish are not tormented with lice, and what are called psylli, they may be captured without alarming them, so that they can be even taken with the hand.
tgt_text.2444: And if fish remain at rest during the night a great multitude of these creatures fall upon and devour them.
tgt_text.2446: They are found in such numbers at the bottom of the sea as to devour any bait made of fish that remains any length of time upon the ground;
tgt_text.2447: fishermen frequently draw them out hanging like globes around the bait.
tgt_text.2448: The following con­ siderations will serve still more to confirm our suppositions that fishes sleep ;
tgt_text.2449: for it is often possible to fall upon the fish so stealthily as to take by the hand, or even strike them during this time;
tgt_text.2450: they are quite quiet, and exhibit no signs of motion except with their tails, which they move gently.
tgt_text.2451: It is evident, also, that they sleep, from their starting if anything moves while they are asleep, for they start as if they were waked out of sleep.
tgt_text.2453: They are also taken by torchlight while asleep;
tgt_text.2454: those who are seeking for thynni surround them while asleep;
tgt_text.2455: it is evident that they can be captured from their stillness, and the half-open white (of their eyes).
tgt_text.2456: They sleep more by night than by day, so that they do not more when they are struck;
tgt_text.2457: they generally sleep holding by the ground, or the sand, or a stone, at the bottom, concealing themselves be­ neath a rock, or a portion of the shore.
tgt_text.2458: The flat fishes sleep in the sand;
tgt_text.2459: they are recognized by their form in the sand, and are taken by striking them with a spear with three points.
tgt_text.2460: The labrax, chrysophrys, cestreus, and such-like fish are often taken with the same kind of weapon while asleep in the day time, but if not taken then, none of them can be captured with such a spear.
tgt_text.2461: 15. The selache sleep so soundly that they may be taken with the hand;
tgt_text.2462: the dolphin, whale, and all that have a blow­ hole, sleep with this organ above the surface of the sea, so that they can breathe, while gently moving their fins, and some persons have even heard the dolphin snore.
tgt_text.2463: The ma­ lacia sleep in the same manner as fish, and so do the mala­ costraca.
tgt_text.2464: It is evident from the following considerations that insects sleep ;
tgt_text.2465: for they evidently remain at rest without motion;
tgt_text.2466: this is particularly plain in bees, for they remain quiet, and cease to hum during the night.
tgt_text.2467: This is also evi­ dent from those insects with which we are most familiar, for they not only remain quiet during the night because they cannot see distinctly, for all creatures with hard eyes have indistinct vision, but they seem no less quiet when the light of a lamp is set before them.
tgt_text.2469: Man sleeps the most of all animals.
tgt_text.2470: Infants and young children do not dream at all, but dreaming begins in most at about four or five years old.
tgt_text.2471: There have been men and women who have never dreamt at all;
tgt_text.2472: sometimes such persons, when they have advanced in age, begin to dream ;
tgt_text.2473: this has preceded a change in their body, either for death or infirmity.
tgt_text.2474: This, then, is the manner of sensation, sleep and wakefulness.1.
tgt_text.2475: IN some animals the sexes are distinct, in others they are not so, these are said to beget and be with young by a like­ ness to other creatures.
tgt_text.2476: There is neither male nor female in fixed animals, nor in testacea.
tgt_text.2477: In the malacia and malacostraca there are male and female individuals, and in all animals with feet, whether they have two or four:
tgt_text.2478: which produce either an animal, an egg, or a worm from coition.
tgt_text.2480: In other kinds the sexes are either single or not single ;
tgt_text.2481: as in all quadrupeds there is the male and female, in the testacea it is not so, for as some vegetables are fertile and others barren, so it is in these.
tgt_text.2482: Among insects and fishes there are some that have no differences of this kind, as the eel is neither male nor female, nor is anything produced from them.
tgt_text.2484: But those persons who say that some eels appear to have creatures like worms, of the size of a hair, attached to them, speak without observation, not having seen how they really are;
tgt_text.2485: for none of these creatures are viviparous with­ out being first oviparous, none of them have ever been ob­ served to contain ova;
tgt_text.2486: those that are viviparous have the embryo attached to the uterus, and not to the abdomen, for there it would be digested like food.
tgt_text.2487: The distinction made between the so-called male and female eel that the male has a larger and longer head, and that the head of the female is smaller, and more rounded, is a generic, and not a sexual distinction.
tgt_text.2489: There are some fish called epitragiæ, and among fresh- water fish the cyprinus and balagrus are of the same nature, which never have ova or semen;
tgt_text.2490: those which are firm and fat, and have a small intestine, appear to be the best.
tgt_text.2491: There are creatures, such as the testacea, and plants, which beget, and produce young, but have no organ of coition;
tgt_text.2492: and so also in fishes the psetus,1 erythrhinus,2 and the ehanna.
tgt_text.2493: All these appear to have ova.5.
tgt_text.2494: In sanguineous animals with feet that are not ovipa­ rous, the males are generally larger and longer lived than the females, except the hemionus, but the females of this animal are both larger and longer lived:
tgt_text.2495: in oviparous and viviparous animals, as in fish and insects, the females are larger than the males, as the serpent, phalangium,1 ascala­ botes,2 and frog;
tgt_text.2496: in fish likewise, as in most of the small gregarious selache, and all that inhabit rocks.
tgt_text.2498: It is evident that female fishes have longer lives than males, because females are caught of a greater age than the males;
tgt_text.2499: the upper and more forward parts of all animals are larger and stronger, and more firmly built in the male;
tgt_text.2500: the hinder and lower parts in the female.
tgt_text.2501: This is the case in the human subject, and all viviparous animals with feet:
tgt_text.2502: the female is less sinewy, the joints are weaker, and the hairs finer, in those with hair;
tgt_text.2503: in those without hair, its analogues are of the same nature;
tgt_text.2504: the female has softer flesh and weaker knees than the male, the legs are slighter;
tgt_text.2505: the feet of females are more graceful, in all that have these members.
tgt_text.2507: All females, also, have a smaller and more acute voice than the males, but in oxen the females utter a deeper sound than the males;
tgt_text.2508: the parts denoting strength, as the teeth, tusks, horns, and spurs, and such other parts, are possessed by the males, but not by the females, as the roe-deer has none, and the hens of some birds with spurs have none;
tgt_text.2510: in some animals they exist in both sexes, only stronger and longer in the males, as the horns of bulls are stronger than those of cows.1.
tgt_text.2511: WE have hitherto treated of the external and internal parts of all animals, of their senses, voice, and J the distinctions between the males and females;
tgt_text.2512: it remains to treat of their generation, speaking first of those which come first in order, for they are many, and have numerous varieties, partly dissimilar, and partly like each other.
tgt_text.2513: And we will pursue the same order in considering them as we did before in their division into classes ;
tgt_text.2514: we commenced our consideration by treating of the parts in man, but now he must be treated of last, because he is much more intricate.
tgt_text.2516: We shall begin with the testacea, and after these treat of the malacostraca, and the others in the order of their succession.
tgt_text.2517: These are the malacia and insects, next to these fishes, both viviparous and oviparous;
tgt_text.2518: next to them birds, and afterwards we must treat of animals with feet, whether viviparous or oviparous ;
tgt_text.2519: some viviparous creatures have four feet, man alone has two feet.
tgt_text.2520: The nature of ani­ mals and vegetables is similar, for some are produced from the seed of other plants, and others are of spontaneous growth, being derived from some origin of a similar nature.
tgt_text.2521: Some of them acquire their nourishment from the soil, others from different plants, as it was observed when treat­ in,, of plants.
tgt_text.2523: So also some animals are produced from animals of a similar form, the origin of others is spontaneous, and not from similar forms;
tgt_text.2524: from these and from plants are divided those which spring from putrid matter, this is the case with many insects;
tgt_text.2525: others originate in the animals themselves, and from the excrementitious matter in their parts ;
tgt_text.2526: those which originate from similar animals, and have both the sexes are produced from coition, but of the class of fishes there are some neither male nor female, these belong to the same class among fishes, but to different genera, and some are quite peculiar.
tgt_text.2527: In some there are females but no males, by these the species is continued as in the hypenemia among birds.
tgt_text.2529: All these among birds are barren, (for nature ia able to complete them as far as the formation of an egg,) unless persons suppose that there is another method of 1 communicating the male influence, concerning which we shall speak mere plainly hereafter.
tgt_text.2530: In some fish, after the spontanecus production of the ovum, it happens that living creatures are produced, some by themselves, others by the aid of the male.
tgt_text.2531: The manner in which this is done will be made plain in a future place, for nearly the same things take place in the class of birds.
tgt_text.2533: Whatever are produced spontaneously in living crea­ tures, in the earth, or in plants, or in any part of them, have a distinction in the sexes, and by the union of the sexes something is produced, not the same in any respect, but an imperfect animal, as nits are produced from lice, and from flies and butterflies are produced egg-like worms, from which neither similar creatures are produced, nor any other creature, but such things only.
tgt_text.2534: First of all, then, we will treat of coition, and of the animals that copulate, and then of others, and successively of that which is peculiar to each, and that which is common to them all.
tgt_text.2536: THOSE animals in which there is a distinction of the sexes use sexual intercourse, but the mode of this intercourse is not the same in all, for all the males of sanguineous animals with feet have an appropriate organ, but they do not all approach the female in the same manner, but those which are retromingent, as the lion, the hare, and the lynx, unite backwards, and the female hare often mounts upon the male;
tgt_text.2537: in almost all the rest the mode is the same, for most animals perform the act of intercourse in the same way, the male mounting upon the female;
tgt_text.2538: and birds perform it in this way only.
tgt_text.2540: There are, however, some variations even among birds;
tgt_text.2541: for the male sometimes unites with the female as she sits upon the ground, as the bustard and domestic fowl:
tgt_text.2542: in others, the female does not sit upon the ground, as the crane;
tgt_text.2543: for in these birds the male unites with the female standing up;
tgt_text.2544: and the act is performed very quickly, as in sparrows.
tgt_text.2545: Bears lie down during the act of intercourse, which is performed in the same manner as in those that stand on their feet, the abdomen of the male being placed upon the back of the female:
tgt_text.2546: in the hedgehogs, the abdo­ mens of both sexes are in contact.
tgt_text.2548: Among the large animals, the roe-deer seldom admits the stag, nor the cow the bull, on account of the hardness of the penis;
tgt_text.2549: but the female receives the male by sub­ mission.
tgt_text.2550: This has been observed to take place in tame deer.
tgt_text.2551: The male and female wolf copulate like dogs.
tgt_text.2552: Cats do not approach each other backwards, but the male stands erect, and the female places herself beneath him.
tgt_text.2553: The fe­ males are very lascivious, and invite the male, and make a noise during the intercourse.
tgt_text.2555: Camels copulate as the female is lying down, and the male embraces and unites with her, not backwards, but like other animals.
tgt_text.2556: They remain in intercourse a whole day.
tgt_text.2557: They retire into a desert place, and suffer no one to ap­ proach them but their feeder.
tgt_text.2558: The penis of the camel is so strong, that bowstrings are made of it.
tgt_text.2559: Elephants also retire into desert places for intercourse, especially by the sides of rivers which they usually frequent.
tgt_text.2560: The female bends down and divides her legs, and the male mounts upon her.
tgt_text.2561: The seal copulates like retromingent animals, and is a long while about it, like dogs.
tgt_text.2562: The males have a large penis.
tgt_text.2564: OVIPAROUS quarupeds with feet copulate in the same manner:
tgt_text.2565: in some, the male mounts upon the female, like viviparous animals, as in the marine and land turtle, for they have an intromittent organ by which they adhere toge­ ther, as the trygon and frog, and all such animals.
tgt_text.2567: But the apodous long animals, as serpents and mu­ raenae, are folded together, with the abdomens opposite, and serpents roll themselves together so closely, that they seem to be but one serpent with two heads.
tgt_text.2568: The manner of the whole race of saurians is the same, for they unite together in the same kind of fold.
tgt_text.2570: ALL fish, except the flat selache, perform the act of intercourse by approaching each other with their abdomens opposite:
tgt_text.2571: but the flat fish, with tails, as the batos, trygon, and such like, not only approach each other, but the male applies his abdomen to the back of the female, in all those in which the thickness of the tail offers no impediment.
tgt_text.2572: But the rhinse, and those which have a large tail, perform the act by the friction of their abdomens against each other, and some persons say that they have seen the male selache united to the back of the female, like dogs.
tgt_text.2574: In all those that resemble the selache, the female is larger than the male;
tgt_text.2575: and in nearly all fish the female is larger than the male.
tgt_text.2576: The selache are those which have been mentioned;
tgt_text.2577: and the bos, lamia, æetus, narce, batra­ chus, and all the galeode.
tgt_text.2578: All the selache have been fre­ quently observed to conduct themselves in this way.
tgt_text.2579: In all viviparous creatures the act occupies a longer time than in the oviparous.
tgt_text.2580: The dolphin and the cetacea also perform the act in the same manner, for the male attaches himself to the female for neither a very long, nor a very short time.
tgt_text.2582: The males of some of the fish which resemble the selache differ from the females, in having two appendages near the anus, which the females have not, as in the gale­ odea;
tgt_text.2583: for these appendages exist in them all.
tgt_text.2584: Neither fish nor any other apodal animal has testicles, but the males, both of serpents and of fish, have two passages, which be­ come full of a seminal fluid at the season of coition;
tgt_text.2585: and all of them project a milky fluid.
tgt_text.2586: These passages unite in one, as they do in birds;
tgt_text.2587: for birds have two internal testes, and so have all oviparous animals with feet.
tgt_text.2588: In the act of coition this single passage passes to, and is extended upon the pudendum and receptacle of the female.
tgt_text.2590: In viviparous animals with feet, the external passage for the semen and the fluid excrement is the same:
tgt_text.2591: inter­ nally these passages are distinct, as I said before in descri­ bing the distinctive parts of animals.
tgt_text.2592: In animals which have no bladder, the anus is externally united with the passage of the semen, internally the passages are close together;
tgt_text.2593: and this is the same in both sexes:
tgt_text.2594: for none of of them have a bladder, except the tortoise.
tgt_text.2595: The female of this animal, though furnished with a bladder, has but one passage ;
tgt_text.2598: The sexual intercourse of the oviparous fish is less evident, wherefore many persons suppose that the female is impreg­ nated by swallowing the semen of the male;
tgt_text.2599: and they have been frequently observed to do this.
tgt_text.2600: This is seen at the season of coition, when the females follow the males, and are observed to strike them on the abdomen with their mouths, this causes the males to eject their semen more rapidly.
tgt_text.2601: The males do the same with the ova of the females, for they swallow them as they are extruded, and the fish are born from those ova which remain.
tgt_text.2603: In Phoenicia they use each sex for capturing the other;
tgt_text.2604: for having taken the male cestreus, they entice the females with it, and so enclose them in a net.
tgt_text.2605: They use the females in the same way for catching the males.
tgt_text.2606: The frequent obser­ vation of these circumstances appears to corroborate this manner of intercourse among them.
tgt_text.2607: Quadrupeds also do the same thing, for at the season of coition both sexes emit a fluid, and smell to each other's pudenda.
tgt_text.2609: And if the wind blows from the cock partridge to the hen, these last are impregnated ;
tgt_text.2610: and often, if they hear the voice of the cock when they are inclined for sexual intercourse, or if he flies over them, they become pregnant from the breath of the cock.
tgt_text.2611: During the act of intercourse, both sexes open their mouths, and protrude their tongues.
tgt_text.2612: The true intercourse of oviparous fish is rarely observed, from the rapidity with which the act is accomplished;
tgt_text.2613: for their intercourse has been observed to take place in the manner described.
tgt_text.2615: ALL the malacia, as the polypus, sepia, and teuthis, approach each other in the same manner, for they are united mouth to mouth ;
tgt_text.2616: the tentacula of one sex being adapted to those of the other;
tgt_text.2617: for when the polypus has fixed the part called the head upon the ground, it extends its tentacula, which the other adapts to the expansion of its tentacula, and they make their acetabula answer together.
tgt_text.2618: And some persons say that the male has an organ like a penis in that one of its tentacula which contains the two largest aceta­ bula.
tgt_text.2619: This organ is sinewy, as far as the middle of the ten­ taculum, and they say that it is all inserted into the nostril of the female.
tgt_text.2621: The sepia and loligo swim about coiled together in this way, and with their mouths and tentacula united, they swim in contrary directions to each other.
tgt_text.2622: They adapt the organ called the nostril of the male to the similar organ in the female;
tgt_text.2623: and the one swims forwards, and the other back­ wards.
tgt_text.2624: The ova of the female are produced in the part called the physeter, by means of which some persons say that they copulate.
tgt_text.2626: THE malacostraca, as the carabi, astaci, carides, and such like perform the act of intercourse like the retromingent animals, the one lying upon its back, and the other placing its tail upon it.
tgt_text.2627: They copulate on the approach of spring, near the land;
tgt_text.2628: for their sexual intercourse has often been observed, and sometimes when the figs begin to ripen.
tgt_text.2630: The astaci and the carides perform the act in the same manner;
tgt_text.2631: but the carcini approximate the fore part of their bodies to each other, and adapt also the folds of their tails to _ each other.
tgt_text.2632: First of all, the smaller carcinus mounts from behind, and when he has mounted, the greater one turns on its side.
tgt_text.2633: In no other respect does the female differ from the male, but that the tail, which is folded on the body, is larger and more distant, and more thick set with appendages :
tgt_text.2634: upon this the ova are deposited, and the excre­ ment ejected.
tgt_text.2635: Neither sex is furnished with an intromittent organ.1.
tgt_text.2636: INSECTS approach, each other from behind, and the smaller one subsequently mounts upon the larger.
tgt_text.2637: The male is always the smaller.
tgt_text.2638: The female, which is below, inserts a member into the male, which is above, and not the male into the female, as in other animals.
tgt_text.2639: In some kinds this organ appears large in proportion to the size of the body, especially in those that are small, in others it is less.
tgt_text.2640: The organ may be plainly discerned if two flies are sepa­ rated while in the act of coition.
tgt_text.2641: They are separated from each other with difficulty, for the act of intercourse in such animals occupies a long time.
tgt_text.2642: This may be plainly discerned by common observation, as in the fly and cantharis.
tgt_text.2644: All adopt the same method, the fly, cantharis, spon­ dyla', phalangium, or any other insect that copulates.
tgt_text.2645: All the phalangia that spin a web unite in the following manner.
tgt_text.2646: The female draws a filament from the middle of the web, and then the male draws it back again, and this they do a great many times till they meet, and are united backwards, for this kind of copulation suits them on account of the size of their abdomen.
tgt_text.2647: The copulation of animals is accom.
tgt_text.2648: plished in this manner.1. ALL animals have their proper season and age for coition;
tgt_text.2649: the nature of most creatures requires them to have inter­ course with each other when winter is turning into summer.
tgt_text.2650: This is the spring season, in which all animals with wings, feet, or fins, are incited to coition.
tgt_text.2651: Some copulate and pro­ duce their young in the autumn and winter, as some aquatic and winged creatures.
tgt_text.2652: Mankind are ready at all seasons, and so are many other animals which associate with man ;
tgt_text.2653: this arises from greater warmth, and better food, and is usual among those which are pregnant only for a short time, as the hog, dog, and those birds which have frequent broods.
tgt_text.2654: Many animals appear to adapt the season of coi­ tion to that which they consider the best for the nurture of their young.
tgt_text.2655: 2. Among mankind the male is more disposedforsexual intercourse in the winter, and the female in the summer.
tgt_text.2656: Birds, as I have observed, generally pair in the spring and summer, except the halcyon.
tgt_text.2657: This bird hatches its young about the time of the winter solstice.
tgt_text.2658: Whereupon fine days occurring at this season are called halcyon days, seven before the solstice and seven after it.
tgt_text.2659: As Simonides also writes in his poems, " as when in the winter months Jupiter pre­ pares fourteen days, which mortals call the windless season, the sacred nurse of the variegated halcyon.
tgt_text.2661: These fine days take place wherever it happens that the solstice turns to the south, when the pleiades set in the north.
tgt_text.2662: The bird is said to occupy seven days in building its nest, and the other seven in bringing out and nursing its young.
tgt_text.2663: The halcyon days are not always met with in this country at the time of the solstice, but they always occur in the Sicilian Sea.
tgt_text.2665: 4. The sethuia and the larus hatch their young among the rocks on the sea-side, and produce two or three, the larus during the summer, and the sethuia at the beginning of the spring, immediately after the equinox ;
tgt_text.2666: it sets upon its eggs like other birds ;
tgt_text.2667: neither of these kinds conceal themselves.
tgt_text.2668: The halcyon is the rarest of all, for it is only seen at the season of the setting of the pleiades, and at the solstice, and it first appears at seaports, flying as much as round a ship, and immediately vanishing away.
tgt_text.2669: Stesichorus also speaks of it in the same manner.5.
tgt_text.2670: The nightingale produces her young at the beginning of summer.
tgt_text.2671: She produces five or six eggs.
tgt_text.2672: She conceals herself from the autumn to the beginning of spring.
tgt_text.2673: Insects copulate and produce their young during the winter when­ ever the days are fine, and the wind in the south, at least such of them as do not conceal themselves, as the fly and ant.
tgt_text.2674: Wild animals produce their young once a year, unless, like the hare, they breed while they are nursing their young.
tgt_text.2675: 1. FISH also generally breed once a year, as the chyti.
tgt_text.2676: All those which are caught in a net are called chyti;
tgt_text.2677: the thyn­ nus, palamis, cestreus, chalais, colias, chromis, psetta, and such like, the labrax is an exception, for this alone of them all breeds twice a year, and the second fry of these are much weaker.
tgt_text.2678: The trichias1 and rock fish breed twice, the trigla is the only one that breeds three times a year.
tgt_text.2679: This is shewn by the fry, which appear three times at certain places.
tgt_text.2680: 2. The scorpius breeds twice, and so does the sargus, in spring and autumn, the salpa once only in the spring.
tgt_text.2681: The thynnis breeds once, but as some of the fry are produced at first, and others afterwards, it appears to breed twice.
tgt_text.2682: The first fry makes its appearance in the month of Decem­ ber, after the solstice, the second in the spring.
tgt_text.2683: The male thynnis is different from the female, for the female has a fin under the abdomen, called aphareus, which the male has not.
tgt_text.2685: Among the selachea, the rhine alone breeds twice in the year;
tgt_text.2686: at the beginning of the autumn, and at the period of the setting of the Pleiades.
tgt_text.2687: The young are, however, better in the autumn.
tgt_text.2688: At each breeding season it produces seven or eight.
tgt_text.2689: Some of the galei, as the asterias, seem to produce their ova twice every month.
tgt_text.2690: This arises from all the ova not being perfected at once.
tgt_text.2691: 4. Some fish produce ova at all seasons of the year, as the mursena:
tgt_text.2692: for this fish produces many ova, and the fry rapidly increase in size, as do those also of the hippurus,1 for these, from being very small, rapidly increase to a great size;
tgt_text.2693: but the muræna produces young at all seasons, the hippurus in the spring.
tgt_text.2694: The smyrus differs from the mu­ ræna, for the muræna is throughout variegated and weak.
tgt_text.2695: The smyrus is of one colour, and strong ;
tgt_text.2696: its colour is that of the pine tree, and it has teeth both internally and ex­ ternally.
tgt_text.2697: They say that these are the male and the female, as in others.
tgt_text.2698: These creatures go upon the land, and are often taken.
tgt_text.2700: The growth of all fish is rapid, and not the least so in the coracinus among small fish.
tgt_text.2701: It breeds near the land, in thick places full of seaweed.
tgt_text.2703: The pelamis and thynnus breed in Pontus, and nowhere else.
tgt_text.2704: The cestreus, chrysophrys, and labrax, breed near the mouths of rivers.
tgt_text.2705: The orcynes and scorpides, and many other kinds,. in the sea.6.
tgt_text.2706: Most fish breed in March, April, and May;
tgt_text.2707: a few in the autumn, as the salpe, sargus, and all the others of this kind a little before the autumnal equinox;
tgt_text.2708: and the narce and rhine also.
tgt_text.2709: Some breed in the winter and summer, as I before observed, as the labrax, cestreus, and belona in the winter;
tgt_text.2710: the thynnis in June, about the summer sol­ stice :
tgt_text.2711: it produces, as it were, a bag, containing many minute ova.
tgt_text.2712: The rhyas also breeds in the summer.
tgt_text.2713: The chelones among the cestræi begin to breed in the month of December, and so does the sargus, the myxon, as it is called, and the cephalus.
tgt_text.2714: They go with young thirty days.
tgt_text.2715: Some of the cestrei do not originate in coition, but are produced from mud and sand.
tgt_text.2717: The greater number of them contain ova in the spring, but some, as I observed, in the summer, autumn, and winter.
tgt_text.2718: But this does not take place in all alike, nor singly, nor in every kind, as it does in most fish which produce their young in the spring:
tgt_text.2719: nor do they produce as many ova at other seasons.
tgt_text.2720: But it must not escape our notice, that as different countries make a great difference in plants and animals, not only in the habit of their body, but also in the frequency of their sexual in­ tercourse and production of young;
tgt_text.2721: so different localities make a great difference in fish, not only in their size, and habit of their body, but in their young, and the frequency or rarity of their sexual intercourse, and of their offspring in this place or that.
tgt_text.2723: THE malacia breed in the spring, and first of all the marine sepia, though this one breeds at all seasons.
tgt_text.2724: It produces its ova in fifteen days.
tgt_text.2725: When the ova are extruded, the male follows, and ejects his ink upon them, when they be­ come hard.
tgt_text.2727: The male is more variegated than the female, and blacker on the back.
tgt_text.2728: The sexes of the polypus unite in the winter, the young are pro­ duced in the spring, when these creatures conceal themselves for two months.
tgt_text.2729: It produces an ovum like long hair, similar to the fruit of the white poplar.
tgt_text.2730: The fecundity of this animal is very great, for a great number of young are produced from its ova.
tgt_text.2731: The male differs from the female in having a longer head, and the part of the tentaculum which the fish­ ermen call the penis is white.
tgt_text.2732: It incubates upon the ova it produces, so that it becomes out of condition, and is not sought after at this season.
tgt_text.2734: The purpura produce their ova in the spring, the ceryx at the end of the winter;
tgt_text.2735: and, on the whole, the testacea appear to contain ova in the spring and autumn, except the eatable echini.
tgt_text.2736: These principally produce their young at the same seasons, but they always contain some ova, and especially at the full and new moon, and in fine weather, but those which live in the Euripus of the Pyrrhæi are better in winter.
tgt_text.2737: They are a small kind but full of ova.
tgt_text.2738: All the cochleæ appear to contain ova at the same season.
tgt_text.2740: THE undomesticated birds, as it was observed, generally pair and breed once a-year.
tgt_text.2741: The swallows and cottyphus breed twice, but the first brood of the cottyphus is killed by the cold, for it is the earliest breeder of all birds.
tgt_text.2742: It is able, however, to bring up the other brood.
tgt_text.2743: But the domestic birds, and those capable of domestication, breed frequently, as pigeons during the whole summer, and do­ mestic fowls.
tgt_text.2744: For these birds have sexual intercourse, and produce eggs all the year round, except at the winter solstice.
tgt_text.2745: 2. There are many kinds of pigeons, for the peleias and peristera are different.
tgt_text.2746: The peleias is the smaller, but the peristera is more readily tamed.
tgt_text.2747: The peleias is black and small, and has red and rough feet, for which reason it is never domesticated.
tgt_text.2748: The phatta is the largest of the tribe, the next is the œnas, which is a little larger than the peristera, the trygon is the least of all.
tgt_text.2749: If the peristera is supplied with a warm place and appropriate food, it will breed and bring up its young at any season of the year.
tgt_text.2750: If it is not properly supplied, it will only breed in the summer.
tgt_text.2751: Its young ones are best during the spring and autumn, those produced in the hot weather in summer are the worst.
tgt_text.2753: ANIMALS also differ in the age at which sexual inter­ course commences.
tgt_text.2754: For in the first place the period at which the spermatic fluid begins to be secreted, and the age of puberty is not the same, but different ;
tgt_text.2755: for the young of all animals are barren, or if they do possess the power of reproduction, their offspring are weak and small.
tgt_text.2756: This is very conspicuous in mankind, and in viviparous quadrupeds and birds, for in the one the offspring, in the other the eggs, are small.
tgt_text.2757: The age of puberty is nearly the same in the individuals of each kind, unless any alteration takes place, either as ominous, or from an injury done to their nature.
tgt_text.2759: In men this period of life is shown by the change of voice, and not only by the size but by the.
tgt_text.2760: form of the pudendum and of the breasts in women, but especially by the growth of hair on the pubes.
tgt_text.2761: The secretion of the spermatic fluid commences about the age of fourteen, the power of reproduction at twenty-one.
tgt_text.2762: Other animals have no hair on the pubes, for some have no hair at all, and others have none upon their under side, or less than on their upper side, but the change of the voice is conspicuous in some of them.
tgt_text.2763: And in others different parts of the body signify the period of the formation of the semen, and of the power of reproduction.
tgt_text.2765: In almost all animals the voice of the female and of the young is more acute than that of the male and the older animals, for even the stags have a deeper voice than their females.
tgt_text.2766: The males utter their cry at the season of copula­ tion, the females when they are alarmed.
tgt_text.2767: The voice of the female is short, that of the male longer.
tgt_text.2768: And the barking of old dogs is also deeper than of young ones, and the voice of the horse also varies.
tgt_text.2769: The females utter a little small cry as soon as they are born, and the males do the same, but their voice is deeper than that of the female, and as they grow older, it still increases.
tgt_text.2770: When they are two years old, and reach puberty, the male utters a great deep voice, that of the female is greater and clearer than it was at first;
tgt_text.2771: this continues till they are twenty years old at the outside, and after that the voice, both of the male and female, be­ comes weaker.
tgt_text.2773: For the most part, then, as we observed, the voice of the male differs from that of the female in depth, in those animals which utter a lengthened sound.
tgt_text.2774: There are, how­ ever, some exceptions, as oxen;
tgt_text.2775: for in these animals the voice of the female is deeper than that of the male, and the voice of the calf than that of the full-grown animal;
tgt_text.2776: where­ fore also in the castrated animals, the voice changes the other way, for it becomes more like that of the female.5.,
tgt_text.2777: The following are the ages at which animals acquire the power of reproduction.
tgt_text.2778: The sheep and goat arrive at puberty within a year after they are born, and especially the goat, and the males as well as the females, but the off­ spring of these males and of the others is different.
tgt_text.2779: For the males are better the second year than when they become older.
tgt_text.2780: In hogs, the male and female unite at eight months old, and the female produces her young when she is a year old, for this agrees with the period of gestation.
tgt_text.2781: The male reaches puberty at eight months old, but his off­ spring are useless till he is a year old.
tgt_text.2782: But these periods, as we have said, are not always the same, for swine will sometimes copulate when they are four months old, so as to have young and nurse them at six months old, and boars sometimes reach puberty at ten months old, and continue good to three years old.
tgt_text.2784: The bitch reaches puberty within a year after birth, and so does the dog, and sometimes this takes place at the end of eight months, but more frequently in the male than in the female.
tgt_text.2785: The period of gestation is sixty days, or one or two, or perhaps three days more, but never less than sixty days, or if they produce young in a less time, it never comes to perfection.
tgt_text.2786: The bitch is ready for sexual intercourse again in six months, but never sooner.
tgt_text.2787: The horse reaches puberty in both sexes at two years old, and is capable of reproduction, but its offspring at that age are small and weakly.
tgt_text.2788: For the most part, sexual inter­ course begins at three years of age, and the colts continue to improve from that period till they are twenty years old.
tgt_text.2789: The male is useful till he is thirty years old, so that he can beget during almost the whole of his life, for the horse generally lives five-and-thirty years, and the mare more than forty, and a horse has been known to live seventy-five years.
tgt_text.2791: The ass reaches puberty in both sexes at the age of thirty months;
tgt_text.2792: they rarely, however, produce young till they are three years, or three years and six months old.
tgt_text.2793: But it has been known to be pregnant and bring up its young within the year.
tgt_text.2794: The cow also has been known to produce young and rear it within the year after birth, which grew to the ordinary size, and no more.
tgt_text.2795: 18. These are the periods of puberty in these animals.
tgt_text.2796: The seventieth year in man, and the fiftieth in woman, is the latest period of reproduction, and this happens rarely, for only a few have had children at this time of life.
tgt_text.2797: Sixty-five is generally the boundary in one sex, and forty­ five in the other.
tgt_text.2798: The sheep produces young till it is eight years old, and, if well treated, until it is eleven, though the act of copulation is continued in both sexes during the whole period of life.
tgt_text.2800: Fat goats are rarely productive, wherefore they com­ pare barren vines with barren goats, but they are pro-. ductive when they are lean.
tgt_text.2801: The rams copulate with the old sheep first, but they do not follow after the younger;
tgt_text.2802: and the younger, as I before observed, produce a smaller offspring than the older.
tgt_text.2804: A wild boar will beget till he is three years old, but the progeny of older animals is inferior;
tgt_text.2805: for he has not the same power or strength.
tgt_text.2806: He generally goes to the female when full of food, and without having been to another female, or, if not, the act of coition is of shorter duration, and the progeny smaller.
tgt_text.2807: The sow produces the smallest number of pigs at her first litter, but at the second they are more flourishing.
tgt_text.2808: She also produces young when old, but the act of coition is longer.
tgt_text.2809: At fifteen years old, she no longer produces young, but becomes fierce.
tgt_text.2810: 11. If well-fed, she will be more ready for sexual in­ tercourse, whether young or old ;
tgt_text.2811: and, if rapidly fattened when pregnant, she has less milk after parturition.
tgt_text.2812: As regards the age of the parent, the young of those in the prime of their age are the best, and those that are born at the beginning of winter.
tgt_text.2813: The worst are those born in the summer, for they are small, and thin, and weak.
tgt_text.2814: If the male is well fed, he is ready for sexual intercourse at all seasons, by day as well as by night;
tgt_text.2815: but if not well fed, he is most ready in the morning, and as he grows old, be be­ comes less disposed for it, as was said before.
tgt_text.2816: And it fre­ quently happens that those which are impotent, through age or weakness, and cannot copulate readily, will approach the female as she lies down tired with long standing.
tgt_text.2817: The sow generally becomes pregnant when she hangs down her ears in her heats;
tgt_text.2818: if she is not pregnant, she becomes heated again.
tgt_text.2819: 12. Bitches do not copulate during the whole of their life, but only to a certain period.
tgt_text.2820: Their coition and preg­ nancy generally takes place till they are twelve years old, but both males and females have been known to perform the act of coition at eighteen and even twenty years of age;
tgt_text.2821: but old age takes away from both sexes the power of reproduction, as in other animals.
tgt_text.2823: The camel is retroningent, and performs the act of intercourse in the manner already described;
tgt_text.2824: the period of its coition in Arabia is in the month of September;
tgt_text.2825: the female goes with young twelve months, and produces one foal, for the animal is one of those which produce but one.
tgt_text.2826: Both the male and female arrive at puberty at the age of three years, and the female is ready for the male again at the end of a year after parturition.
tgt_text.2828: The elephant arrives at puberty, the earliest at ten years of age, the latest at fifteen, and the male at five or six years old.
tgt_text.2829: The season for the intercourse of the sexes is in the spring:
tgt_text.2830: and the male is ready again at the end of three years, but he never touches again a female whom he has once impregnated.
tgt_text.2831: Her period of gestation is two years, and then she produces one calf, for the elephant belongs to the class of animals which have but one young one at a time.
tgt_text.2832: The young one is as large as a calf of two or three months old.
tgt_text.2833: This, then, is the nature of the sexual inter­ course of those animals which perform this function.1.
tgt_text.2834: WE must now treat of the mode of reproduction, both of those animals which use sexual intercourse, and those which do not;
tgt_text.2835: and, first of all, we will speak of the testacea, for this is the only entire class which is not reproduced by sexual intercourse.
tgt_text.2836: The purpuræ collect together in the spring, and produce what is called their nidamental capsules (melicera), for it is like honey-comb, though not so deeply cut, but, as it were, made up of the white pods of vetches.
tgt_text.2837: These capsules have neither opening nor perforation, nor are the purpuræ produced from them ;
tgt_text.2838: but both these and other testacea are produced from mud and putrefaction.
tgt_text.2839: But this substance is an excrementitious matter both in the pur­ pura and the ceryx, for these last also produce similar cap­ sules.
tgt_text.2841: The testacea which produce these capsules are gene­ rated in the same way as the rest of their class, but more readily when there are homogeneous particles pre-existing among them;
tgt_text.2842: for, when they deposit their nidamental cap­ sules, they emit a clammy mucus, from which the scales of the capsules are formed.
tgt_text.2843: When all these have been depo­ sited, they emit upon the ground a sort of chyle, and small purpuræ spring up upon the same spot and adhere to the larger purpuræ, though some of these can hardly be dis­ tinguished by their form.
tgt_text.2844: But if they are taken before the breeding season, they will sometimes breed in the baskets, not indeed anywhere, but they collect together like they do in the sea, and the narrow limits of their place of captivity make them hang together like bunches of fruit.
tgt_text.2846: There are many kinds of purpuræ, some of which are large, as those which are found near Sigeum and Lectum ;
tgt_text.2847: and others are small, as those in the Euripus and on the Carian coast.
tgt_text.2848: Those found in gulfs are large and rough.
tgt_text.2849: Most of them contain a black pigment;
tgt_text.2850: in others it is red, and the quantity of it small.
tgt_text.2851: Some of the largest weigh as much as a mina.
tgt_text.2852: Near the shore and on the coast they are small, and the pigment is red.
tgt_text.2853: Those which are natives of the north contain a black pigment;
tgt_text.2854: in those of the south it is red, generally speaking.
tgt_text.2856: They are taken in the spring, about the time that they deposit their capsules, but they are never taken during the dog-days, for then they do not feed, but conceal themselves and get out of the way.
tgt_text.2857: The pigment is contained between the mecon and the neck.
