tgt_text.2858: The union of these parts is thick, and the colour is like a white membrane;
tgt_text.2860: When this is bruised, the pigment wets and stains the hand.
tgt_text.2861: Something resembling a vein passes through it, and this appears to be the pigment;
tgt_text.2862: the nature of the rest resembles alum.
tgt_text.2864: The pigment is the worst at the period of depositing their nidamental capsules.
tgt_text.2866: The small ones are pounded up, shells and all, for it is not easy to separate them;
tgt_text.2867: but they separate the larger kinds from the shells, and then extract the pig­ ment.
tgt_text.2868: For this purpose the mecon is divided from the neck, for the pigment lies above the part called the stomach, and when this is taken away, they are divided asunder.
tgt_text.2869: They are careful to bruise them while alive, for if they die before they are cut up, they vomit up the pig­ ment ;
tgt_text.2870: for this reason they keep them in the baskets till a sufficient number is collected, and there is time to procure the pigment.
tgt_text.2872: The ancients did not let down or fasten any basket-net to their baits, so that it often happened that the purpura fell off as they were drawn up ;
tgt_text.2873: but at the present time they use basket-nets, in order that if the purpura should fall off, it may not be lost.
tgt_text.2874: They are 'most likely to fall off when full, but when empty it is difficult to draw them from the bait.
tgt_text.2875: These are the peculiarities of the purpura.
tgt_text.2876: The nature of the ceryx is the same as that of the purpura, and so are their seasons.
tgt_text.2878: They both have opercula, and so have all turbinated shell-fish, from the period of their birth.
tgt_text.2879: They feed by fore­ ing out their tongue, as it is called, beneath the operculum:
tgt_text.2880: the purpura has a tongue larger than a finger, with which it feeds upon and pierces the conchylia, and even the shells of its own species.
tgt_text.2881: Both the purpura and the ceryx are long-, lived, for the purpura lives six years, and its annual increase is seen in the divisions on the helix of its shell.
tgt_text.2883: The mya also deposits nidamental capsules;
tgt_text.2884: those which are called limnostrea are the first to originate in muddy places, but the conchæ, chemæ, solens, and pectens find their subsistence in sandy shores ;
tgt_text.2885: the pinnæ grow up from their byssus both in sandy and muddy shores.
tgt_text.2886: The pinnæ always contain a pinnophylax, either like a small caris or cancer, and soon die when this is extracted.
tgt_text.2887: On the whole, all the testacea are produced spontaneously in mud, different kinds originating in different sorts of mud;
tgt_text.2888: the ostrea is found in mud, the conchae and others that have been men­ tioned in sand.
tgt_text.2889: The tethya, balanus, and others which live on the surface, as the patella and nerita, originate in holes in the rocks.
tgt_text.2890: All these reach maturity very soon, espe­ cially the purpuræ and pectens, for they are matured in one year.
tgt_text.2892: Very small white cancri are produced in some of the testacea, especially in the myæ that inhabit muddy places, and next to this in the pinnæ those which are called pinno­ teræ;
tgt_text.2893: they occur also in the pectens and limnostrea.
tgt_text.2895: and the fishermen say that they are produced at the same time as the creatures they inhabit.
tgt_text.2896: The pectens disappear for some time in the sand, and so do the purpuræ.
tgt_text.2897: The ostrea (bivalves) are produced in the manner described, for some of them originate in shallow water, others near the shore, or among rocks, or in rough hard places, or in sand;
tgt_text.2898: and some have the power of locomotion, others have not.
tgt_text.2900: Among those that are not locomotive, the pinnæ are fixed;
tgt_text.2901: the solens and conchae remain on one spot, though not fixed, and do not survive separation from their home.
tgt_text.2902: The nature of the aster' is so hot, that if it is captured immediately after swallowing anything, its food is found digested;
tgt_text.2903: and they say that it is very troublesome in the Pyrrhæan Euripus.
tgt_text.2904: Its form is like the paintings of a star.
tgt_text.2905: The creatures called pneumones are spontaneously produced.
tgt_text.2906: The shell which painters use is very thick, and the pigment is produced on the outside of the shell;
tgt_text.2907: they are principally found in the neighbourhood of Caria.
tgt_text.2909: The carcinium also originates in earth and mud, and afterwards makes its way into an empty shell, and when it grows too large for that, it leaves it for a larger one, as the shell of the nerita, strombus, and such like;
tgt_text.2910: it frequently occurs in the small ceryx.
tgt_text.2911: When it has entered the shell, it carries it about and lives in it, except that as it grows it migrates into a larger shell.
tgt_text.2913: THE nature of the testacea is the same as that of crea­ tures without shells, as the cnidæ2 and sponges, which inha­ bit the holes in rocks.
tgt_text.2914: There are two kinds of cnidæ, some which live in holes in the rocks, and cannot be separated from them, and other migrating species which live upon the smooth flat surface of the rocks.
tgt_text.2915: (The patella also is free and locomotive.)
tgt_text.2916: In the interior of the sponges are found the creatures called pinnophylaces, and the interior is closed with a net like a spider's web, and small fish are captured by opening and closing this web, for it opens as they ap­ proach, and closes upon them when they have entered.
tgt_text.2918: There are three kinds of sponges ;
tgt_text.2919: one of them is thin, the other is thick, and the third, which is called the Achillean sponge, is slender, compact, and very strong ;
tgt_text.2920: it is placed beneath helmets and thigh-pieces, for the sake of deadening the sound of blows;
tgt_text.2922: Among the compact kinds, those which are very hard and rough are called tragi.
tgt_text.2923: They all grow upon the rock or near the shore, and obtain their food from the mud.
tgt_text.2924: This is evident, for they are full of mud when they are captured.
tgt_text.2925: This is the case with all other fixed things, that they derive their food from the spot to which they are attached.
tgt_text.2927: The compact species are weaker than those which are thin, because their point of attachment is smaller.
tgt_text.2928: It is affirmed that the sponge possesses sensation;
tgt_text.2929: this is a proof of it, that it contracts if it perceives any pur­ pose of tearing it up, and renders the task more difficult.
tgt_text.2930: The sponge does the same thing when the winds and waves are violent, that it may not lose its point of attachment.
tgt_text.2931: There are some persons who dispute this, as the natives of Torona.
tgt_text.2932: The sponge is inhabited by worms and other living creatures, which the rock-fish eat when the sponge is torn up, as well as the remainder of its roots.
tgt_text.2933: But if the sponge is broken off, it grows again, and is completed from the por­ tion that is left.
tgt_text.2935: The thin sponges are the largest, and they are most abundant on the Lycian coast;
tgt_text.2936: the compact sponges are softer, and the Achillean are more harsh than the others.
tgt_text.2937: On the whole, those that inhabit deep places with a mild temperature are the softest, for wind and cold weather harden them, as they do other growing things, and stop their increase.
tgt_text.2938: For this reason the sponges of the Hellespont are rough and compact;
tgt_text.2939: and, altogether, those beyond Malea, and those on this side, differ in softness and hardness.
tgt_text.2941: Neither should the heat be very great, for the sponge be­ comes rotten, like plants, wherefore those near the shore are the best, especially if the water is deep near the land, for the temperature is moderated by the depth.
tgt_text.2942: When alive, before they are washed, they are black.
tgt_text.2943: Their point of attach­ ment is neither single nor dispersed over the whole surface, for there are empty passages between the points of attach­ ment.
tgt_text.2944: Something like a membrane is extended over their lower part, and the attachment is by several points;
tgt_text.2945: on the upper part are other closed passages, and four or five which are apparent.
tgt_text.2946: Wherefore some persons say that these are the organs by which they take their food.
tgt_text.2948: There is also another species called aplysia, because it cannot be washed.
tgt_text.2950: but the other parts of the substance are quite compact.
tgt_text.2951: When cut open it is more compact and smooth than the sponge, and the whole is like a lung ;
tgt_text.2952: of all the sponges this one is con­ fessed to have the most sensation, and to be the most enduring.
tgt_text.2953: They are plainly seen in the sea near the sponges, for the other sponges are white as the mud settles down upon them, but these are always black.
tgt_text.2954: This is the mode of production in sponges and testacea.1.
tgt_text.2955: AMONG the malacostraca the carabi are impregnated by sexual intercourse, and contain their ova during three months, May, June, and July.
tgt_text.2956: They afterwards deposit them upon the hollow part of their folded tail, and their ova grow like worms.
tgt_text.2957: The same thing takes place in the malacia and oviparous fish, for their ova always grow.
tgt_text.2959: The ova of the carabi are sandy, and divided into eight parts ;
tgt_text.2960: for a cartilaginous appendage, round which the ova are attached, is united to each of the opercula at their junction with the side ;
tgt_text.2961: and the whole resembles a bunch of grapes, for every one of the cartilaginous appendages is fre­ quently subdivided, and the divisions are apparent to any one who will separate them, but when first seen they appear to be united.
tgt_text.2962: Those ova which are in the centre are larger than those which are contiguous to the perforation, and the last are the least.
tgt_text.2964: The smallest ova are as large as millet;
tgt_text.2965: the ova are not continuous with the perforation, but in the middle.
tgt_text.2966: For two divisions extend on each side, from the tail and from the thorax, and this is also the line of junction for the opercula.
tgt_text.2967: The ova, which are placed at the side, cannot be enclosed, unless the extremity of the tail is drawn over them ;
tgt_text.2968: this, however, covers them like a lid.4.
tgt_text.2969: The female, in depositing her ova, appears to collect them on the cartilaginous appendages by means of the broad part of the folded tail.
tgt_text.2970: She produces them by pressing with her tail and bending her body.
tgt_text.2971: These cartilaginous processes at the season of oviposition in­ crease in size, in order to become appropriate recep­ tacles for the ova.
tgt_text.2972: The ova are deposited on these pro­ cesses, as those of the sepia are deposited upon broken pieces of wood or anything floating in the sea.
tgt_text.2973: This is the manner of depositing them;
tgt_text.2974: but after they have been ripened twenty days, they are cast off altogether in a mass, as they appear when separated from the parent;
tgt_text.2975: in fifteen days, at the outside, the carabi are produced from these ova, and they are often taken off less than a finger's length.
tgt_text.2976: The ova are produced before Arcturus, and after Arcturus they are cast off.
tgt_text.2978: The cyphæ among the carides contain their ova about four months.
tgt_text.2979: The carabi are found in rough and rocky places, the astaci in those that are smooth ;
tgt_text.2980: but neither of them inhabit mud.
tgt_text.2981: For this cause the astaci are found in the Hellespont and near Thasus;
tgt_text.2982: the carabi in the neighbour­ hood of Sigeum and Athos.
tgt_text.2983: Fishermen, when they pursue their calling in the open sea, distinguish the rough and muddy places by the nature of the shore, and other signs.
tgt_text.2984: In the spring and winter they come near the shore;
tgt_text.2985: in sum­ mer time they go into deep water, sometimes for the sake of warmth, and sometimes for the.
tgt_text.2987: Those called arcti1 breed nearly at the same time as the carabi, wherefore they are most excellent in winter and in spring before the breeding season, and they are worst after they have deposited their ova.
tgt_text.2988: They change their shell in the spring, like the serpent, which puts off' its old age, as it is called.
tgt_text.2989: Both the carabi and the carcini do this when they are young, as well as afterwards.
tgt_text.2990: All the carabi are long- lived.
tgt_text.2991: 1. THE malacia produce a white ovum after sexual inter­ course ;
tgt_text.2992: in the course of time this becomes sandy, like that of the testacea.
tgt_text.2993: The polypus deposits its ova in holes or pots, or any other hollow place;
tgt_text.2994: the ovum is like bunches of the wild vine and of the white poplar, as was observed before;
tgt_text.2995: when the ova are produced they remain suspended from the hole in which they were deposited:
tgt_text.2996: and the ova are so numerous, that when taken out they will fill a vessel much larger than the head of the polypus in which they were contained.
tgt_text.2998: About fifty days afterwards the young polypi burst the eggs and escape, like phalangia, in great numbers.
tgt_text.2999: The par­ ticular shape of each limb is not distinct, though the general form is plain.
tgt_text.3000: Many of them perish from their small size and debility.
tgt_text.3001: Some have been observed so small that they could not be distinguished, unless they were touched, when they were seen to move.
tgt_text.3003: The sepia also deposits eggs, which resemble large, black, myrtle seeds.
tgt_text.3004: They are united together like a bunch of fruit, and are enclosed in a substance which prevents them from separating readily.
tgt_text.3005: The male emits his ink upon them, a mucous fluid, which causes their slippery appearance.
tgt_text.3006: The ova increase in this way;
tgt_text.3007: and when first produced they are white, but when they have touched the ink they become large and black.
tgt_text.3008: When the young sepia, which is entirely formed of the internal white of the ovum, is produced, it makes its way out by the rupture of the membrane of the ovum.
tgt_text.3010: The ovum which the female first produces is like hail, and to this the young sepia is attached by the head, as birds are attached to the abdomen.
tgt_text.3011: The nature of the umbilical attachment has never been observed, except that as the sepia increases the white always becomes less, and at last entirely disappears, like the yolk of the eggs of birds.
tgt_text.3013: The eyes are at first very large in these as in other animals, as in the diagram.
tgt_text.3014: The ovum is seen at A, the eyes at B and C, and the embryo sepia itself at D.
tgt_text.3015: The female contains ova during the spring.
tgt_text.3016: The ova are produced in fifteen days;
tgt_text.3017: and when the ova are produced they remain for fifteen days longer like the small seeds of grapes, and when these are ruptured the young sepias escape from the inside.
tgt_text.3018: If a person divides them before they have reached maturity, the young sepias emit their fœces and vary in colour, and turn from white to red from alarm.
tgt_text.3020: The crustaceans incubate upon their ova, which are placed beneath them;
tgt_text.3021: but the polypus and sepia and such like incubate upon their ova wherever they may be depo­ sited, and especially the sepia, for the female has often been observed with her abdomen upon the ground, but the female polypus has been observed sometimes placed upon her ova, and sometimes upon her mouth, holding with her tentacula over the hole in which the ova were deposited.
tgt_text.3022: The sepia deposits her ova upon the ground among fuci and reeds, or upon any thing thrown in the water, as wood, branches, or atones;
tgt_text.3023: and the fishermen are careful to place branches of trees in the water.
tgt_text.3024: Upon these they deposit their long and united ova like branches of fruit.
tgt_text.3026: The ova are deposited and produced by repeated exertion, as if the parturition were accompanied with pain.
tgt_text.3027: The teuthis oviposits in the sea.
tgt_text.3028: The ova, like those of the sepia, are united together.
tgt_text.3029: Both the teuthus and sepia are short-lived, for very few of them survive a year.
tgt_text.3030: The same is the case with the polypus.
tgt_text.3031: Each egg produces one small sepia, and so also in the teuthis.
tgt_text.3032: The male teuthus differs from the female;
tgt_text.3033: for if the hair (branchia) are drawn aside, the female will be seen to have two red substances like mammæ, which the male does not possess.
tgt_text.3034: The sepia also has the same sexual distinction, and is more variegated than the female, as I observed before.
tgt_text.3036: IT has already been observed that the male insects are less than the female, and that the male mounts upon the female;
tgt_text.3037: and the manner of their sexual intercourse has been described, and the difficulty of separating them.
tgt_text.3038: Most ot them produce their young very soon after sexual intercourse.
tgt_text.3039: All the kinds except some psychs (butterflies and moths) produce worms.
tgt_text.3040: These produce a hard substance, like the seed of the cnecus,1 which is fluid within.
tgt_text.3041: From the worm an animal is produced, but not from a portion of it, as if it were an ovum, but the whole grows and becomes an articu­ lated animal.
tgt_text.3043: Some of them are produced from similar animals, as phalangia and spiders from phalangia and spiders, and atte­ labi,2 locusts, and grasshoppers.
tgt_text.3044: Others do not originate in animals of the same species, but their production is sponta­ neous, for some of them spring from the dew which falls upon plants.
tgt_text.3045: The origin of these is naturally in the spring, though they often appear in the winter, if fine weather and south winds occur for any length of time.
tgt_text.3046: Some originate in rotten mud and dung;
tgt_text.3047: and others in the fresh wood ot plants or in dry wood;
tgt_text.3048: others among the hair of animals, or in their flesh, or excrements, whether ejected, or still exist­ ing in the body, as those which are called helminthes.
tgt_text.3050: There are three kinds of these, the flat worms, the round worms, and those which are called ascarides.
tgt_text.3051: From these creatures nothing is produced;
tgt_text.3052: but the broad worm is attached to the intestine, and produces something like the seed of the colocynth, and this is used by physicians as a proof of the presence of the worm.
tgt_text.3055: and these originate in the leaves of green plants, especially the rha­ phahus, which some persons call crambe.
tgt_text.3056: At first they are smaller than millet, afterwards they grow into little worms, in three days they become small caterpillars, afterwards they grow and become motionless, and change their form.
tgt_text.3057: In this state the creature is called chrysalis.
tgt_text.3058: It has a hard covering, but moves when it is touched.
tgt_text.3059: They are united to something by weblike processes, and have no mouth nor any other visible organ.
tgt_text.3060: After a short time the covering is burst, and a winged animal escapes, which is called a but­ terfly.
tgt_text.3062: At first, while in the caterpillar state, they take food and evacuate fœces, but in the chrysalis state they do nei­ ther.
tgt_text.3063: The same is the case with all other creatures which originate in worms, and those which produce worms after sexual intercourse, or even without this process;
tgt_text.3064: for the offspring of bees, anthrenæ, and wasps, while they are young worms, consume food and evacuate excrement, but when from worms they receive their conformation they are called nymphæ, and neither feed nor evacuate, but remain quiet in their covering until they are grown.
tgt_text.3065: They then make their escape by cutting through a place where the cell is fastened on.
tgt_text.3067: The penial and hypera2 also are produced from a kind of campe (caterpillar) which make a wave as they walk, and as they advance bend the hinder extremity up to that which has preceded.
tgt_text.3068: The creature pro­ duced always derives its colour from the campe in which it originates.
tgt_text.3069: A certain great worm, which has as it were horns, and differs from others, at its first metamorphosis produces a campe, afterwards a bombylius, and lastly a necydalus.
tgt_text.3070: It passes through all these forms in six months From this animal some women unroll and separate the bombycina (cocoons), and afterwards weave them.
tgt_text.3071: It is said that this was first woven in the island of Cos by Pamphila, the daughter of Plateos.7.
tgt_text.3072: From the worms in dry wood the insects called carabi are produced in the same manner;
tgt_text.3073: for at first they are im­ moveable worms, and afterwards the carabi are produced by the rupture of their case.
tgt_text.3074: The crambides originate in the plant called crambe, and these also have wings, and the prasocurides from the plant called prasum (onion).
tgt_text.3075: The oestri are produced from the little flat creatures that are found on the surface of rivers.
tgt_text.3076: Wherefore also they con gregate in the greatest numbers around the waters where such animals are found.
tgt_text.3077: The kind of pygolampis which has no wings originates in a small, black, hairy caterpillar.
tgt_text.3079: undergo another change, and turn into the winged creatures called bostrychi.8.
tgt_text.3080: The empides originate in ascarides, and the ascarides originate in the mud of wells and running waters which flow over an earthy bottom.
tgt_text.3081: At first the decaying mud acquires a white colour, which afterwards becomes black, and finally red.
tgt_text.3082: When this takes place, very small red creatures are seen growing in it like fuci.
tgt_text.3083: At first these move about in a mass, afterwards their connection is ruptured, the creatures called ascarides are borne about in the water, after a few days they stand erect in the water without motion and of a hard texture, and subsequently the case is broken and the empis sits upon it until either the sun or the wind enables it to move, then it flies away.
tgt_text.3085: The commencement of life in all other worms, and in all creatures produced from worms, originates in the influ­ ence of the sun and wind.
tgt_text.3086: The ascarides are produced in greater numbers, and more quickly, where the various matters are mixed together, as in the works conducted in the Megarian territory, for putrefaction thus takes place more readily.
tgt_text.3087: The autumnal season also is favourable to their increase, for there is less moisture at that time of the year.
tgt_text.3088: The crotones1 originate in the agrostis, the melo­ lonthæ from the worms which originate in the dung of oxen \ and asses.
tgt_text.3090: The canthari which roll up dung, hide.
tgt_text.3091: themselves in it during the winter, and produce worms, which afterwards become canthari;
tgt_text.3092: and from the worms which inhabit the osprea,1 winged creatures, like those already mentioned, derive their existence.
tgt_text.3093: Flies originate in dung which has been set apart, and those who are employed in this work strive to separate the remainder which is mixed together, for they say that the dung is thus brought to putrefac.
tgt_text.3095: The origin of these worms is very small;
tgt_text.3096: for first of all a redness is perceived, and motion commences, as if they were united together.
tgt_text.3097: The worm then again becomes still, afterwards it moves, and then again is immoveable.
tgt_text.3098: From this the worm is completed, and motion recommences under the action of the sun and wind.
tgt_text.3099: The myops is produced in wood.
tgt_text.3100: The orsodacnæ2 from the metamorphosis of worms, which originate oil the stalks of the crambe.
tgt_text.3101: The cantharis from worms which dwell on the fig tree, apium (pear tree), and pitch tree, for there are worms on all these, and on the cynacantha.
tgt_text.3103: They assemble round strong smelling things because they originate from them.
tgt_text.3104: 12. The con ops springs from aworm which originates in the thick part of vinegar;
tgt_text.3105: for there seem also to be worms in things which are the farthest from putrefaction, as in snow which has laid for some time:
tgt_text.3106: for after having laid, it becomes red, wherefore, also, the worms are such and hairy.
tgt_text.3107: Those in the snow in Media are large and white, and furnished with but little power of motion.
tgt_text.3108: In Cyprus, when the manufacturers of the stone called chalcitis burn it for many days in the fire, a winged creature, something larger than a great fly, is seen walking and leaping in the fire.
tgt_text.3110: The worms perish when they are taken out of the snow, and so do these creatures when taken from the fire.
tgt_text.3111: And the salamander shews that it is possible for some animal substances to exist in the fire, for they say that fire is extinguished when this animal walks over it.
tgt_text.3113: In the river Hypanis in the Cimmerian Bosphorus, about the summer solstice, capsules larger than grape-seed are floated down the river:
tgt_text.3114: when these are ruptured, a four-footed, winged creature makes its escape, which lives and flies about till the evening.
tgt_text.3115: As the sun descends, it becomes emaciated, and is dead by sunset, having lived but one day;
tgt_text.3116: for which cause it is called ephemerum.
tgt_text.3117: Most animals which spring from caterpillars or worms, are first of all enclosed in a web, and this is their nature.
tgt_text.3119: The wasps which are called ichneumons, which are smaller than the others, kill the phalangia, and carry them to a wall, or some other place with a hole in it;
tgt_text.3120: and when they have covered them over with mud, they oviposit there, and the ichneumon wasps are produced from them.
tgt_text.3121: Many of the coleoptera, and other small and anonymous creatures make little holes in tombs or walls, and there deposit their worms.
tgt_text.3122: 16. The period of reproduction, from its commencement to its conclusion, is generally completed in three or four weeks.
tgt_text.3123: In the worms and worm-like creatures, three weeks are usually sufficient, and four weeks are usually enough for those which are oviparous.
tgt_text.3124: In one week from their sexual intercourse, the growth of the ovum is completed.
tgt_text.3125: In the remaining three weeks, those that produce by gene­ ration, hatch and bring forth their ova, as in the spiders, and such like creatures.
tgt_text.3126: The metamorphoses generally occupy three or four days, like the crisis of diseases.
tgt_text.3127: This is the mode of generation in insects.
tgt_text.3128: 17. They die from the shrivelling of their limbs, as large animals do of old age.
tgt_text.3129: Those which are furnished with wings have these organs drawn together in autumn.
tgt_text.3130: The myopes die from an effusion of water in their eyes.1.
tgt_text.3131: ALL persons are not agreed as to the generation of bees, for some say that they neither produce young, nor have sexual intercourse;
tgt_text.3132: but that they-bring their young from other sources;
tgt_text.3133: and some say that they collect them from the flowers of the calyntrus,1 and others from the flower of the calamus.
tgt_text.3135: Others again, say that they are found in the flowers of the olive, and produce this proof, that the swarms are most abundant when the olives are fertile.
tgt_text.3136: Other per­ sons affirm that they collect the young of the drones from any of the substances we have named, but that the rulers (queens) produce the young of the bees.
tgt_text.3138: There are two kinds of rulers, the best of these is red, the other black and variegated :
tgt_text.3139: their size is double that of the working bees ;
tgt_text.3140: the part of the body beneath the cincture is more than half of the whole length:
tgt_text.3141: by some they are called the mother bees, as if they were the parents of the rest;
tgt_text.3142: and they argue, that unless the ruler is present, drones only are produced, and no bees.
tgt_text.3143: Others affirm that they have sexual intercourse, and that the drones are males, and the bees females.
tgt_text.3145: The other bees originate in the cells of the comb, but the rulers are produced in the lower part of the comb, six or seven of them separated, opposite to the rest of the pro. geny.
tgt_text.3146: The bees have a sting, which the drones have not:
tgt_text.3147: the kings and rulers have a sting which they do not make use of, and some persons suppose that they have none.
tgt_text.3149: THEBE are several kinds of bees, the best are small, round, and variegated:
tgt_text.3150: another kind is large, like the anthrene:
tgt_text.3151: a third kind is called phor;
tgt_text.3152: this is black, and has a broad abdomen :
tgt_text.3153: the drone is the fourth, and is the largest of all;
tgt_text.3154: it has no sting, and is incapable of work, for which reason people often wrap something round their hives, so that the bees can enter, but the drones, being larger, cannot.
tgt_text.3156: There are two kinds of rulers among bees, as I observed before.
tgt_text.3157: In every hive there are several rulers, and not a single one, for the hive perishes if there are not rulers enough (not that they thus become anarchical, but, as they say, because they are required for breeding the bees) ;
tgt_text.3158: if there are too many rulers they perish, for thus they become distracted.
tgt_text.3159: 3- If the spring is late, and drought and rusts are about, the progeny is small.
tgt_text.3160: When the weather is dry, they make honey.
tgt_text.3161: When it is damp, their progeny multiplies;
tgt_text.3162: for which reason, the olives and the swarms of bees multiply at the same time.
tgt_text.3163: They begin by making comb, in which they place the progeny, which is deposited with their mouths, as those say who affirm that they collect it from external sources.
tgt_text.3164: Afterwards they gather the honey which is to be their food, during the summer and the autumn;
tgt_text.3165: that which is gathered in the autumn is the best.
tgt_text.3167: They bring the material of wax from the droppings of trees, but the honey falls from the air, principally about the rising of the stars, and when the rainbow rests upon the earth.
tgt_text.3168: Generally no honey is produced before the rising of the Pleiades.
tgt_text.3169: We argue that wax is made, as I said, from flowers, but that the bees do not make honey, but simply collect that which falls ;
tgt_text.3170: for those who keep bees find the cells filled with honey in the course of one or two days.
tgt_text.3171: In the autumn there are flowers enough, but the bees make no honey, if that which they have produced is taken away.
tgt_text.3172: But if one supply was taken away, and they were in want of food, they would make more if they procured it from flowers.
tgt_text.3174: The honey becomes thick by ripening, for at first it is like water, and continues liquid for some days, wherefore it never becomes thick if it is taken away during that time.
tgt_text.3175: It requires twenty days to make it consistent;
tgt_text.3176: this is very plain from the taste of it, for it differs both in sweetness and solidity.
tgt_text.3177: The bee carries honey from every plant which has cup-shaped flowers, and from all those which contain a sweet principle, but does not injure the fruit;
tgt_text.3178: it takes up and carries away the sweet taste of plants with its tongue-like organ.
tgt_text.3180: The honey-comb is pressed when the wild figs begin to appear;
tgt_text.3181: and they produce- the best grubs when they can produce honey.
tgt_text.3182: The bees carry the wax and bee­ bread upon their legs, but the honey is disgorged into the cells.
tgt_text.3183: After the progeny is deposited in the cells, they incubate like birds.
tgt_text.3184: In the wax cells the little worm is placed at the side;
tgt_text.3185: afterwards it rises of itself to be fed.
tgt_text.3186: It is united to the comb in such a manner as to be held by it.
tgt_text.3187: The progeny both of the bees and drones from which the little worms are produced, is white.
tgt_text.3188: As they grow they become bees-and drones.
tgt_text.3189: The progeny of the king-bees is rather red, and about the consistency of thick honey.
tgt_text.3190: In bulk it is as large as the creature which is pro­ duced from it.
tgt_text.3191: The progeny of the king-bee is not a worm, but comes forth a perfect bee, as they say;
tgt_text.3192: and, when the progeny is produced in the comb, honey is found in that;
tgt_text.3195: After the grub is covered up, it has wings and feet;
tgt_text.3196: and when it has acquired wings, it bursts through the membrane, and flies away.
tgt_text.3197: It evacuates an excremen­ titious matter while it is a worm, but not afterwards, until it is perfected, as I observed before.
tgt_text.3198: If a person cuts off the head of the grub before its wings are acquired, the other bees devour it;
tgt_text.3199: if a person having cut off the wings of a drone lets it go, the bees will eat off the wings of the other drones.
tgt_text.3201: The bee will live for six years, some have lived for seven, and if a swarm lasts nine or ten years, it is con­ sidered to have done well.
tgt_text.3202: In Pontus there are very white bees, which make honey twice every month.
tgt_text.3203: In Thernis­ cyra, near the river Thermodon, are found bees which make cells in the earth, and in hives with a very small quantity of wax, but their honey is thick.
tgt_text.3204: The cells are smooth and homogeneous.
tgt_text.3205: They only do this in the winter, and not all the year round:
tgt_text.3206: for there is a great deal of ivy in the place, which flowers at this season of the year, and from this they carry away the honey.
tgt_text.3207: From the higher regions of Amisus a kind of white honey is procured, which the bees form upon the trees without wax.
tgt_text.3208: The same is also found in another place in Pontus.
tgt_text.3209: There are also bees which form triple cells in the earth ;
tgt_text.3210: these form honey, but never have grubs.
tgt_text.3211: All such as these, however, are not cells, neither are they formed by every kind of bee.1.
tgt_text.3212: THE anthrenæ1 and wasps form cells for their progeny when they have no rulers, but are wandering about in search of them, the anthrenæ upon some high place, the wasps in holes.
tgt_text.3213: But when they have the rulers they form their cells underground.
tgt_text.3214: All their cells are hexagonal, like those of bees;
tgt_text.3215: they are not formed of wax, but of a web­ like membrane, made of the bark of trees.
tgt_text.3216: The cells of the anthrenæ are far more elegant than those of wasps.
tgt_text.3217: Upon the side of their cells they place their progeny, in the manner of the bees, like a drop of liquid united to the wall of the celL
tgt_text.3218: The progeny in all the cells is not alike, but in some they are so large as to be almost ready for flight, in others are nymphæ, in others grubs.
tgt_text.3220: The only excrementitious matter is found in the cells of the grubs, as in the case of bees.
tgt_text.3221: As long as they are nymphæ they remain motionless, and the cell is sealed over, and on the other side of the cell which contains their pro­ geny, there is a drop of honey in the combs of the anthrenæ.
tgt_text.3222: The grubs of these creatures are produced in the autumn, not in the spring, but they evidently grow most rapidly at the full moon.
tgt_text.3223: The progeny and the grubs are not united to the bottom, but to the side of the cell.
tgt_text.3224: 1. SOME of the bombycia1 form an angular cell of mud, which they attach to a stone or something else, and smear with a kind of transparent substance;
tgt_text.3225: this is so very thick and hard, that it can scarcely be broken with the blow of a spear.
tgt_text.3226: In this they deposit their ova, and the white maggots are contained in a black membrane;
tgt_text.3227: and wax is formed in the mud without any membrane, this wax is much more yellow than that of bees.
tgt_text.3229: The ants also have sexual intercourse, and produce maggots which they do not attach to anything.
tgt_text.3230: As these grow, they change from small round things to long articu­ lated beings.
tgt_text.3231: The season for their production is in the spring.
tgt_text.3233: The land-scorpions also bring forth many egg-like maggots, upon which they incubate.
tgt_text.3234: When the young ones are perfect, they drive out and destroy their parents like spiders, for they are frequently eleven in number.
tgt_text.3236: THE arachnia copulate in the manner already described, and produce maggots which at first are small.
tgt_text.3237: After their metamorphosis they become spiders, not from a part but from the whole of the maggot, for they are round from the first.
tgt_text.3238: When the female has produced her ova, she in­ cubates upon them, in three days they acquire limbs.
tgt_text.3239: All of them produce their young in a web, which is thin and small in some species, but compact in others.
tgt_text.3240: Some are enclosed entirely in a round receptacle, and others are only partially covered by the web.
tgt_text.3241: All the young spiders are not produced at once, but as soon as they are hatched they leap out and shoot forth a web.
tgt_text.3242: If they are bruised they are found to contain a thick white fluid like that of maggots.
tgt_text.3244: The field-spiders first of all deposit their ova in a web, of which one half is attached to themselves, and the other external, they incubate upon this, and produce their young alive.
tgt_text.3245: The phalangia deposit their ova in a thick basket which they weave, upon this they incubate.
tgt_text.3246: The smooth kinds produce a small number, the phalangia a great many.
tgt_text.3247: When they are grown, they surround their parent in a circle, kill and throw her out.
tgt_text.3248: They often seize the male in the same way if they can catch him, for he assists the female in incubation.
tgt_text.3249: Sometimes there are as many as three hundred round a single phalangium.
tgt_text.3250: The little" spiders become full-grown in about four weeks.
tgt_text.3252: LOCUSTS copulate in the same manner as all other in­ sects, the smaller mounting upon the larger, for the male is the smaller.
tgt_text.3253: They oviposit by fixing the organ which is attached to their tail (the ovipositor) in the ground.
tgt_text.3254: The males do not possess this organ.
tgt_text.3255: Many of them deposit their ova in one spot, so as to make it appear like a honey- comb.
tgt_text.3256: As soon as they have deposited their ova, egg-like maggots are formed, which are covered with a thin coating of earth like a membrane, and in this they are matured.
tgt_text.3258: The young are so soft as to collapse if they are only touched.
tgt_text.3259: They are not produced on the surface, but a little below the surface of the soil;
tgt_text.3260: and as soon as they are matured, they escape from the coat of soil in which they are enclosed as small black locusts.
tgt_text.3261: Their skin is subsequently ruptured, and they then attain their full size.
tgt_text.3262: They produce their young at the end of summer, and then die.3.
tgt_text.3263: For as soon as they have deposited their ova, small worms make their appearance on their necks, the males also perish at the same time:
tgt_text.3264: they come out of the earth in the spring.
tgt_text.3265: Locusts never shew themselves in mountainous countries, nor in poor land, but in plains, and broken soil, for they deposit their ova in fissures.
tgt_text.3266: The ova remain in the soil during the winter, and in the summer the locusts are produced from the germs of the preceding year.
tgt_text.3268: The young of the attelabi are produced in the same manner, and the parents die after having deposited their ova.
tgt_text.3269: Their ova are destroyed by the rains of the autumn, if the weather is wet;
tgt_text.3270: but if that season is dry, many atte­ labi are produced, because they are not equally destroyed;
tgt_text.3271: for their destruction appears to be irregular, and to take place by accident.
tgt_text.3273: THERE are two kinds of grasshoppers:
tgt_text.3275: These are the first to appear, the last to perish.
tgt_text.3277: these appear last, and disappear first.
tgt_text.3278: There is another difference between the small and large kind.
tgt_text.3279: Those which chirp have a division in the middle of the body :
tgt_text.3280: those which do not chirp have none.
tgt_text.3281: The large ones, which chirp, are called achetæ;
tgt_text.3283: Such of these as are divided, sing a little.
tgt_text.3285: Grasshoppers do not appear where there are no trees, for which reason they are unknown in the open country of Cyrene, but are abundant near the city, and especially among olive trees, for these do not give much shade, and grasshoppers are not produced in the cold, nor in very shady groves.
tgt_text.3286: Both the large and small ones have sexual inter­ course with their own kind, copulating with each other on their backs.
tgt_text.3287: The male inserts his organ into the female, in the same manner as other insects.
tgt_text.3288: The female has a divided pudendum.
tgt_text.3289: The female individual is the one which receives the male.
tgt_text.3291: They deposit their ova in fields, piercing the soil with the organ at the extremity of their body, like the attelabi;
tgt_text.3292: for the attelabi also oviposit in the fields, for which reason they are common in Cyrene.
tgt_text.3293: They oviposit also in the reeds which are used to support the vines;
tgt_text.3295: and so they do in the stems of the scilla.
tgt_text.3296: The young ones are washed into the earth, and are common in rainy weather.
tgt_text.3297: The maggot, when it is grown in the earth, becomes a tettigometra:
tgt_text.3298: these are sweetest before they have ruptured their covering.
tgt_text.3300: And when the season arrives for their appearance, about the solstice, they come forth by night, and immedi.
tgt_text.3301: ately burst their envelope, and the tettigometra becomes a grasshopper.
tgt_text.3302: They immediately become black and hard, acquire their full size, and begin to chirp.
tgt_text.3303: In both kinds the males chirp ;
tgt_text.3304: the others, which do not chirp, are females.
tgt_text.3305: When first produced the males are the sweetest:
tgt_text.3306: after the sexual intercourse, the females are sweetest, for they contain white ova.5.
tgt_text.3307: If a noise is made as they fly along, they emit a fluid like water, which the agriculturists describe as if they emitted both a liquid and solid excrement, and that they feed on dew;
tgt_text.3308: and if any one approaches them with a bent finger, which is gradually straightened, they will remain more quiet than if it is put out straight at once, and will climb up upon the finger;
tgt_text.3309: for, from the dimness of their sight, they climb upon it as if it were a moving leaf.
tgt_text.3311: THOSE insects which are not carnivorous, but live upon the juices of living flesh, as lice, fleas, and bugs, produce nits from sexual intercourse;
tgt_text.3312: from these nits nothing else is formed.
tgt_text.3313: Of these insects the fleas originate in very small portions of corrupted matter, for they are always collected together where there is any dry dung.
tgt_text.3315: proceed from the moisture, which collects on the bodies of animals:
tgt_text.3316: lice from the flesh of other creatures;
tgt_text.3317: for before they appear, they exist in little pimples which do not contain matter:
tgt_text.3318: and if these are pricked, the licez escape from them.
tgt_text.3319: Some persons have been afflicted with a disease arising from excessive moisture in the body, of which people have died, as they say that Alcmon the poet, and Pherecydes of Syria did.2.
tgt_text.3320: And in some diseases lice are very common.
tgt_text.3321: There is a kind of lice, which they call wild, and are harder than the common sort, which are difficult to eradicate from the body.
tgt_text.3322: The heads of children are most subject to be infested with lice, and men the least so, for women are more liable to them than men.
tgt_text.3323: Those that have lice in the head are less subject to headache.
tgt_text.3324: Many other animals are infested with lice:
tgt_text.3325: for both birds have them, and those which are called phasiani, unless they dust themselves, are destroyed by them.
tgt_text.3326: And so are all those creatures which have feathers with a hollow stem, and those which have hair, except the ass, which has neither lice nor ticks.
tgt_text.3328: sheep and goats have ticks, but no lice;
tgt_text.3329: hogs are infested with large, hard lice, and dogs with those which are called cynoraïstæ.
tgt_text.3330: All lice originate in the animals that are in­ fested with them.
tgt_text.3331: All creatures that have lice, and wash themselves, are more liable to them when they change the water in which they bathe.
tgt_text.3333: In the sea is a kind of lice1 growing on fish ;
tgt_text.3334: but these do not originate in the fish, but in the mud.
tgt_text.3335: Their ap­ pearance is that of wood-lice with many feet, except that they have a wide tail.
tgt_text.3336: There is one species of marine lice which occur everywhere, and especially infest the trigla.
tgt_text.3337: All these creatures are furnished with many legs, are ex­ sanguineous, and insects.
tgt_text.3338: The œstrus2 of the thynnus occurs near the fins:
tgt_text.3339: in shape it is like a scorpion, and as large as a spider.
tgt_text.3340: In the sea between Cyrene and Egypt, there is a fish called the phtheira, which accompanies the dolphin;
tgt_text.3341: it is the fattest of all fish, because it enjoys an abundance of the food which the dolphin hunts for.
tgt_text.3343: THERE are also other minute animals, as I observed be­ fore, some of which occur in wool,3 and in woollen goods;
tgt_text.3344: as the moths, which are produced in the greatest abundance when the wool is dusty, and especially if a spider is enclosed with them, for this creature is thirsty, and dries up any fluid which may be present.
tgt_text.3345: This worm also occurs in gar.
tgt_text.3347: There is one which occurs in old honeycombs, like the creature which inhabits dry wood:
tgt_text.3348: this appears to be the least of all creatures, it is called acari, it is white and small.
tgt_text.3349: Others also are found in books,4 some of which are like those which occur in garments:
tgt_text.3351: 5 they have no tails, and are very small.
tgt_text.3352: And on the whole, they occur in everything, so to say, which from being dry, becomes moist, or being moist, becomes dry, if it has any life in it.
tgt_text.3353: 2- There is a little worm which is called xylophthorus,1 which is no less extraordinary than these animals ;
tgt_text.3354: for its variegated head is projected beyond its case, and its feet are at the extremity, as in other worms.
tgt_text.3355: The rest of the body is contained in a case made of a substance like spider's web, and a dry material on the outside of this;
tgt_text.3356: so that it appears to walk about with this attached to it.
tgt_text.3357: These creatures are attached to their case, and as a snail to its shell, so the whole of the case is joined to the worm, and it does not fall out of it, but is drawn out of it, as if they were joined toge­ ther.
tgt_text.3358: If a person pulls off the case, the creature dies, and becomes as helpless as a snail without its shell.
tgt_text.3359: As time advances, this grub becomes a chrysalis, like a caterpillar, and lies without motion:
tgt_text.3360: but the nature of the winged creature that is produced has never been ascertained.
tgt_text.3362: The wild figs upon the fig-trees contain a creature called psen;
tgt_text.3363: 2 this is at first a little worm, and afterwards having ruptured the case, the psen flies out, and leaves it behind.
tgt_text.3364: It then pierces the unripe figs, and causes them not to fall off, wherefore gardeners place wild fruit near the cultivated kinds, and plant the wild and cultivated plants near each other.
tgt_text.3366: THE sexual intercourse of sanguineous and oviparous quadrupeds takes place in the spring.
tgt_text.3367: They do not, how­ ever, all copulate at the same season;
tgt_text.3368: but some in the spring, others in the summer or autumn, as the season is appropriate for bringing up the young of each species.
tgt_text.3369: The tortoise pro­ duces hard, two-coloured eggs, like those of birds.
tgt_text.3370: Having deposited her eggs, she buries them, and makes a beaten place above them.
tgt_text.3371: When this is done, she sits upon them.
tgt_text.3372: The eggs are hatched the following year.
tgt_text.3373: The emys goes out of the water to deposit her eggs, and digs a hole like a cask, in which she places her eggs and leaves them.
tgt_text.3374: Having left them alone for less than thirty days, she digs them up again and hatches them and leads them at once to the water.
tgt_text.3375: The marine turtles deposit their eggs in the earth like do­ mestic birds, and cover them up with earth and sit upon them during the night.
tgt_text.3376: They produce a great many eggs, as many as an hundred.
tgt_text.3378: The saurians and both the land and river crocodiles produce their eggs upon the land.
tgt_text.3379: Those of the lizards are hatched spontaneously in the earth ;
tgt_text.3380: for the lizard does not live a whole year, for it is said to live only six months.
tgt_text.3381: The river crocodile produces as many as sixty eggs, which are white.
tgt_text.3382: She sits upon them for sixty days, for they live a long while.
tgt_text.3383: A very large animal is produced from these small eggs;
tgt_text.3384: for the egg is not larger than that of a goose, and the young is in proportion, but when full grown the creature measures seventeen cubits.
tgt_text.3385: Some persons say that it grows as long as it lives.
tgt_text.3386: AMONG serpents the viper is externally viviparous, but first of all internally oviparous.
tgt_text.3387: The ovum, like that of fish, is of one colour and soft skinned.
tgt_text.3388: The young are produced in the upper part.
tgt_text.3389: They are not enclosed in a shelly covering, neither are the ova of fish.
tgt_text.3390: The little vipers are produced in a membrane, which they rupture on the third day, and some­ times they make their escape by eating their way through the mother.
tgt_text.3391: They are produced one by one in the course of a day, and their number often exceeds twenty.
tgt_text.3392: Other serpents are externally oviparous, but their ova are joined together like women's necklaces.
tgt_text.3393: When the female deposits her eggs in the soil, she incubates upon them.
tgt_text.3394: These also are hatched in the second year.
tgt_text.3395: This is the manner of the production of serpents, insects, and of oviparous quadrupeds.
tgt_text.3397: THE above describes the manner of reproduction in ser.
tgt_text.3399: All birds are oviparous, but the season of sexual intercourse and of bring­ ing out their young is not the same in all;
tgt_text.3400: for some copu­ late and produce eggs at all seasons, as we may say, as the domestic fowl and the pigeon, for the domestic fowl lays eggs all the year round, except two months at the winter solstice.
tgt_text.3401: Some of the finest birds will lay sixty eggs before they want to sit, though these are not so fruitful as the more common kinds.
tgt_text.3402: The Adrianic fowls are very small, but they lay every day;
tgt_text.3403: but they are cruel, and often kill their chickens.
tgt_text.3405: Some of the domestic birds lay twice a-day, and some have been known to lay so many eggs that they died very soon.
tgt_text.3407: The domestic fowls, as I said, lay continually;
tgt_text.3408: but the pigeon, dove, trygon, and cenas lay twice a-year;
tgt_text.3410: The greatest number of birds lay in the spring;
tgt_text.3411: and some of them produce many young, and this in two ways;
tgt_text.3412: some producing their young often, as the pigeon;
tgt_text.3413: others producing .many at a time, as the domestic fowl.
tgt_text.3414: All birds with crooked claws, except the cenchris,1 lay but few eggs.
tgt_text.3415: This bird lays the most of any of its class;
tgt_text.3416: for it has been observed to produce four, and it even produces more.
tgt_text.3417: Some birds lay their eggs in nests;
tgt_text.3418: but those that do not fly, as partridges and quails, do not make nests, but lay their eggs on the ground and cover them over with rubbish.
tgt_text.3419: The lark and tetrix2 do the same.
tgt_text.3420: 3. These birds make their nests in a place sheltered from the wind.
tgt_text.3421: That which the Beotians call ærops3 is the only bird that makes its nests in caverns in the earth.
tgt_text.3422: The cichlæ4 make nests of mud like swallows in the tops of trees;
tgt_text.3423: but they place them in order close to each other, so that from their proximity they look like a chain of nests.
tgt_text.3424: Among the birds which make solitary nests, the hoopoe makes no real nest, but lays its eggs in the stumps of hollow trees, without building at all.
tgt_text.3425: The coccyxl lays its eggs in houses and boles in rocks.
tgt_text.3426: The tetrix, which the Athenians call " urax," makes no nest on the ground or in trees, but in herbaceous plants.
tgt_text.3428: THE eggs of all birds are alike and have a hard shell, if they are produced by sexual intercourse and are not decayed, for domestic fowls sometimes lay soft eggs.
tgt_text.3429: Birds' eggs are two-coloured, externally white, internally yellow.
tgt_text.3430: The eggs of birds inhabiting the sides of streams and lakes differ from those living on dry land, for in the eggs of aquatic birds the yolk bears a much larger proportion to the white.
tgt_text.3432: The colours of eggs vary in different kinds of birds.
tgt_text.3433: Some have white eggs, as pigeons, partridges;
tgt_text.3434: some yellow, as those inhabiting streams ;
tgt_text.3435: others are spotted, as those of the meleagris2 and phasianus;
tgt_text.3436: 3 the eggs of the cenchris are red like vermilion.
tgt_text.3437: In the egg itself there is a difference;
tgt_text.3438: for one end is pointed, the other round.
tgt_text.3439: The round, end is pro­ duced first.
tgt_text.3440: The large, sharp eggs are males;
tgt_text.3441: those which are round and circular at the sharp end are females.
tgt_text.3444: Some are hatched spontaneously in the earth, as in Egypt, being buried in dung;
tgt_text.3445: and they say that in Syracuse a drunkard placed eggs beneath his mat, and drank without ceasing until the eggs were hatched;
tgt_text.3446: and eggs placed in warm vessels have been matured and hatched spontaneously.
tgt_text.3448: The seminal fluid of all birds is white, like that of other animals;
tgt_text.3449: and when they copulate the female receives the male semen near the diaphragm.
tgt_text.3450: The egg at first appears small and white, afterwards red and bloody;
tgt_text.3451: as it grows it be­ comes quite ochreous and yellow;
tgt_text.3452: when it becomes larger a distinction is made, and the internal part becomes yellow, the external white;
tgt_text.3453: and when it is perfected it is set at liberty, and excluded just at the period when it is changing from soft to hard.
tgt_text.3454: So that during exclusion it is not har- dened;
tgt_text.3455: but as soon as it is excluded it thickens and becomes hard, unless it is diseased.
tgt_text.3456: And eggs have been known to be excluded in the state in which all eggs are at a certain period of their growth;
tgt_text.3457: for they were entirely yellow, as the young bird is afterwards.
tgt_text.3458: Such have also been observed in the domestic fowl beneath the diaphragm, where the eggs of the hen are placed, entirely yellow, and as large as eggs usually are.
tgt_text.3460: 5. They are mistaken who say that the hypenemia (barren eggs) are the remains of former acts of sexual intercourse;
tgt_text.3461: for young birds, as fowls and geese, have been frequently observed to lay such eggs without any sexual intercourse.
tgt_text.3462: Barren eggs are smaller, not so sweet, and more fluid than fertile eggs, and they are more numerous.
tgt_text.3463: If they are placed under a bird, the fluid part never thickens, but both the yolk and the white remain in their original state.
tgt_text.3464: Many birds produce these eggs, as the domestic fowl, partridge, pigeon, peafowl, goose, and chenalopex.
tgt_text.3466: Eggs are hatched more readily in summer than in winter;
tgt_text.3467: for in the summer the domestic fowl will hatch in eighteen days, but in winter sometimes in not less than twenty-five days.
tgt_text.3468: Some birds also are more adapted for incubation .than others.
tgt_text.3469: A thunder-storm during the season of incubation will destroy the eggs.
tgt_text.3470: What are called cyno­ sura and uria (addled eggs) are more frequently produced in the summer.
tgt_text.3471: The hypenemia2 are by some persons called zephyria, because they say that birds receive these winds in the spring.
tgt_text.3472: They do the same thing if they are touched with the hand.
tgt_text.3474: and eggs that are produced by sexual intercourse are changed to an­ other kind, if the hen which contains either hypenemia or fertile eggs has sexual intercourse with another bird before the eggs begin to change from yellow to white, and the hypenemia become fertile, and the fertile eggs produce birds of the nature of the second male.
tgt_text.3476: But if the change from yellow to white has already taken place, neither the barren nor the fertile eggs are al­ tered, so as to change to the nature of the second male.
tgt_text.3477: And if the sexual intercourse should be discontinued while the eggs are small, those which existed previously undergo no change, but if the act is repeated, a rapid increase in size takes place.
tgt_text.3478: The nature of the white and yolk of the egg is different, not only in colour, but in other properties, for the yolk coagu­ lates with cold, while the white remains fluid, but the white coagulates with heat, which the yolk does not, but remains soft, if it is not burnt;
tgt_text.3479: and it becomes consistent and dry by boiling rather than roasting.
tgt_text.3481: The white and yolk are separated from each other by a membrane.
tgt_text.3482: The chalazæ at the extremities of the yolk have nothing to do with generation, as some persons suppose.
tgt_text.3483: These spots are two, one below and one above.
tgt_text.3484: If many whites and yolks of eggs are taken out, and mixed together in a vessel, and cooked with a slow and moderate heat, the yolks will all collect in the middle, and the whites will surround them.
tgt_text.3485: Young domestic fowls begin to lay eggs at the beginning of the spring;
tgt_text.3486: they lay more than those which are older, but those of the young birds are smaller, and if birds are not permitted to incubate, they are de­ stroyed and become sick.
tgt_text.3488: After copulation birds ruffle and shake themselves, and often cover themselves with chaff, and this also they do when they have laid.
tgt_text.3489: Pigeons draw up their tail, geese go and bathe.
tgt_text.3490: The pregnancy and conception of barren eggs is quick in most birds, as in the partridge, on ac­ count of the violence of their sexual desires ;
tgt_text.3491: for if the hen stands in the way of the breath of the male, she con­ ceives, and immediately becomes of no use for fowling;
tgt_text.3492: for the partridge appears to have a very distinct smell.
tgt_text.3493: The production of the egg after copulation, and the production of the young by incubation, do not occupy the same length of time in all birds, but varies according to their size.
tgt_text.3494: The egg of the domestic fowl is perfected in ten days after sexual intercourse, and that of the pigeon in a shorter time.
tgt_text.3495: Pigeons are able to retain their eggs even in the act of parturition.
tgt_text.3496: If they are disturbed by anything occurring in the neighbourhood of their nest, or a feather be plucked out, or if anything else troubles or disturbs them, they re­ 'tain the egg they were about to lay.10.
tgt_text.3497: This is peculiar to pigeons, and so is the following for they kiss each other when the male is about to mount, or else they will not endure it.
tgt_text.3498: The older bird first gives a kiss, but afterwards he mounts without kissing, but younger birds always kiss before copulation.
tgt_text.3499: This also is peculiar to these birds.
tgt_text.3500: The females kiss and mount upon each other like the males, when there is no male present.
tgt_text.3501: They do not project anything into each other, but produce more eggs than those which produce fertile ones;
tgt_text.3502: from these eggs nothing is hatched, but they are all barren.
tgt_text.3504: THE production of the bird from the egg is alike in then:
tgt_text.3505: all, but the period of completion varies, as I observed be­ fore.
tgt_text.3506: In domestic fowls the first sign of alteration takes place larger after three days and nights.
tgt_text.3507: This period is longer in larger birds, and shorter in small birds.
tgt_text.3508: During this period the upper part of the yolk advances to the small extremity of the egg, which is the beginning of the egg.
tgt_text.3509: This is the part from which the chicken is excluded, and the heart is visible like a red spot in the white of the egg.
tgt_text.3511: This spot palpitates and moves as though it were en­ dued with life.
tgt_text.3512: From this, as it increases, two involved sanguineous passages like veins lead to each of the sur­ rounding tunics ;
tgt_text.3513: and a membrane which has sanguineous passages encloses the white at this period, and separates it from the venous passages.
tgt_text.3514: A short time afterwards the body is distinguished, at first very small and white, but the head is distinct, and in this the eyes are the most enlarged.
tgt_text.3515: And this continues for some time, for afterwards the eyes are reduced in size and approach each other, but the lower part of the body has not at first any proportion to the upper part.
tgt_text.3517: One of the passages from the heart extends into a circle around the embryo, and the other to the yolk, as if it were an umbilical cord.
tgt_text.3518: The origin of the young bird is in the white, its nutriment is derived from the yolk through the umbilical cord.
tgt_text.3519: On the tenth day, the whole of the young bird and all its parts are distinct, but its head is still larger than the rest of the body, and the eyes are larger than the rest of the head.
tgt_text.3520: They have no sense of sight.
tgt_text.3521: If the eyes are taken out at this period, they are larger than beans, and black;
tgt_text.3522: when the skin is taken from them, they are seen to contain a white and cold fluid, very brilliant in appearance, but without any hard substance.
tgt_text.3523: This is the manner of the development of the eyes and head.
tgt_text.3525: At the same period the viscera are visible, but the stomach, and intestines, and the veins from the heart still appear to extend towards the navel.
tgt_text.3526: From the navel a vein appears to extend upon the membrane which encloses the yolk, and the yolk itself is at this period fluid, and more abundant than in its natural state.
tgt_text.3527: The other extends to the membrane which encloses the whole membrane con­ taining the embryo, and the membrane of the yolk and the fluid between them, and when the young birds have grown a little more, part of the yolk goes to one end, and part to the other, and between them is the fluid white;
tgt_text.3528: but the white is still below the lower part of the yolk, where it was at first, but at the tenth day the white disappears, for it has become small, viscid, thick, and rather yellow.
tgt_text.3530: This is the position of all the parts:
tgt_text.3531: the first and last part adjoining the shell is the membrane of the egg, not the membrane of the shell, but beneath this.
tgt_text.3533: within this is the young bird, and a membrane surrounding it, and separating it from the fluid;
tgt_text.3534: beneath the embryo is the yolk, to which one of the veins extends, and the other to the white which encloses it.
tgt_text.3535: A membrane containing a fluid resembling sanies encloses the whole, and then another membrane which surrounds the embryo itself, as I observed, and separates it from the fluid.
tgt_text.3536: Below this the yolk, enclosed in another membrane, which is reached by the umbilical cord from the heart, and the great vein, so that the embryo does not appear to be in either of the fluids.
tgt_text.3538: About the twentieth day, if the hatching has been de­ layed beyond this period, the young bird is able to chirp when moved externally, and if the shell is taken off, by this time also it is downy.
tgt_text.3539: The head is placed over the right leg upon the side, and the wing is over the head.
tgt_text.3540: At this period the chorion-like membrane is visible, which is united with the lowest membrane of the shell, to which one of the umbilical cords passes, and the young bird is complete.
tgt_text.3541: The other chorion-like membrane is also visible, enclosing the yolk.
tgt_text.3542: To this the other umbilical cord extends.
tgt_text.3543: Both of these cords are attached to the heart and the great vein.
tgt_text.3544: At the same period the cord which is attached to one chorion falls off, and is separated from the animal, but the one which passes to the yolk remains suspended from the young bird by a thin bowel, and a considerable portion of the yolk is contained in the young bird, and some of it is found in the stomach.
tgt_text.3546: At this period also they eject an excrementitious matter into the external chorion, and contain it in the stomach.
tgt_text.3547: The external excrement is white, the internal yellow.
tgt_text.3548: At last the yolk, which has been continually wasting and advancing, is entirely taken up and enclosed in the young bird.
tgt_text.3549: So that portions of it may be observed in the intestines of birds if they are dissected on the tenth day after exclusion from the egg.
tgt_text.3550: But it is set at liberty from the navel, nor does any communication remain, but the whole is separated.
tgt_text.3551: About the before-mentioned period the young bird sleeps, but it stirs itself, and looks up, and chirps when it is touched, and the heart swells up with the navel, as if the embryo were breathing.
tgt_text.3552: This is the manner of the development of the chick in the egg.8.
tgt_text.3553: Birds also produce some barren eggs, as well as those from sexual intercourse, but they produce nothing after in­ cubation.
tgt_text.3554: This is particularly observed in pigeons.
tgt_text.3556: in some a thin division of white pre­ vents the yolks from mixing together;
tgt_text.3557: others have not this division, but touch each other.
tgt_text.3558: There are some hens which always lay double eggs, and in these the peculiarities of the yolks have been observed;
tgt_text.3559: for a certain bird having laid eighteen eggs, hatched two chickens from each of them, ex­ cept those that were addled;
tgt_text.3561: except that one of the twin chickens was Irage and the other small in each.
tgt_text.3563: -1. ALL the pigeon tribe, as the phatta and trygon, generally produce two eggs;
tgt_text.3564: the trygon and the phatta are those which generally lay three.
tgt_text.3565: The pigeon lays, as I said, at every season;
tgt_text.3566: the trygon and the phatta in the spring, and uot more than twice.
tgt_text.3567: The second brood are hatched when the first has been destroyed, for many birds destroy them.
tgt_text.3568: It sometimes lays three, as I have said, but it never brings out more than two young ones, and sometimes only one, the remaining eg,, is always addled.
tgt_text.3569: Very few birds begin to lay before they are a year old ;
tgt_text.3570: but when they have once begun to lay, they all, as we may say, naturally contain eggs to the end of their life, though it is not easy to see them in some birds, from their small size.
tgt_text.3572: The pigeon usually produces one male and one female, and of these the male is often hatched first;
tgt_text.3573: and having laid an egg one day, she omits many days and then lays another.
tgt_text.3574: The male sits during a portion of the day, and the female during the night.
tgt_text.3575: The first young one is hatched and able to fly within twenty days, and the egg is billed on the day before it is hatched;
tgt_text.3576: both the old birds keep the young ones warm for some time, as they do the eggs.
tgt_text.3577: During the time of bringing up their young the female is fiercer than the male:
tgt_text.3578: this is also the case in other animals.
tgt_text.3579: They produce young ten times in a year, and sometimes eleven times;
tgt_text.3580: those in Egypt even twelve times.
tgt_text.3581: The cock and hen birds copulate within the year, for they do this at the end of six months.
tgt_text.3583: And some say that the phatta and trygon are matured when three months old, and they consider their great num­ bers as a proof of this.
tgt_text.3584: The female contains her eggs four­ teen days, and then sits upon them fourteen more;
tgt_text.3585: in four­ teen days after this the young ones
tgt_text.3586: By so well that it is difficult to catch them.
tgt_text.3587: The phatta lives, as they say, forty.
tgt_text.3589: the partridge more than sixteen years.
tgt_text.3590: The pigeon, after having brought out her young, lays again in thirty days.
tgt_text.3592: THE vulture builds its nest in inaccessible rocks, where­ fore its nest and young ones are rarely seen.
tgt_text.3593: For this reason Herodorus, the father of Bryson the sophist, says that vultures come from another part of the earth, which is invisible to us, giving as a reason for his opinion, that they are seen in great numbers suddenly following the path of an army.
tgt_text.3594: But difficult as it is to observe them, their nests have been seen.
tgt_text.3596: No other car­ nivorous bird has been observed to produce young more than once a year;
tgt_text.3597: but the swallow more frequently produces young twice a year than the carnivorous birds.
tgt_text.3598: If a person pierces the eyes of young swallows they recover, and are able to see afterwards.
tgt_text.3600: THE eagle produces three eggs, of which two only are hatched.
tgt_text.3601: This is also related in the poems of Musæus.
tgt_text.3602: The bird which lays three eggs, hatches two, and brings up but one.
tgt_text.3604: but three young have been seen in the nest.
tgt_text.3605: When the young begin to grow, one of them is turned out by the parent, because she dislikes the trouble of feeding it.
tgt_text.3606: At this period it is said to be without food, so that it does not capture the young of wild crea­ tures, for a few days the talons are turned back, and the feathers become white, so that it then becomes cruel to its young.
tgt_text.3607: The phene 1 receives and brings up the ejected young one.
tgt_text.3609: The eagle incubates for thirty days;
tgt_text.3610: this is the usual period of incubation for large birds, as the goose and the bustard.
tgt_text.3611: Moderately sized birds usually sit twenty days, as the ictinus 2 and hierax.
tgt_text.3613: The ictinus usually produces two young ones, and sometimes three ;
tgt_text.3614: the Ætolian kite, as it is called, sometimes produces four.
tgt_text.3615: The raven produces not only two, but, as they say, many eggs, which she sits upon for about twenty days.
tgt_text.3616: She also turns out some of her young ones.
tgt_text.3617: Many other birds do the same thing;
tgt_text.3618: and generally those which produce several turn out one.
tgt_text.3620: All kinds of eagles do not behave in the same way to their young;
tgt_text.3622: and the black eagles are careful for the food of their young;
tgt_text.3623: but all birds with crooked talons as soon as their young can fly well beat them and drive them from the nest.
tgt_text.3624: And most birds of other classes, as I have before observed, do the same tiling;
tgt_text.3625: and when they have brought them up, they take no more notice of them, except the crow.
tgt_text.3626: This bird cares for its young a long while, for as it flies past them it gives them food after they are able to fly.
tgt_text.3628: THE cuckoo is said by some persons to be a changed hawk, because the hawk which it resembles disappears when the cuckoo comes, and indeed very few hawks of any sort can be seen during the period in which the cuckoo is singing except tor a few days.
tgt_text.3629: The cuckoo is seen for a short time in the summer, and disappears in winter.
tgt_text.3630: But the hawk has crooked talons, which the cuckoo has not, nor does it resemble the hawk in the form of its head, but in both these respects is more like the pigeon than the hawk, which it resembles in nothing but its colour;
tgt_text.3631: the markings, however, upon the hawk are like lines, while the cuckoo is spotted.
tgt_text.3633: Its size and manner of flight is like that of the smallest kind of hawk, which generally disappears during the season in which the cuckoo is seen.
tgt_text.3634: But they have both been seen at the same time, and the cuckoo was being devoured by the hawk, though this is never done by birds of the same kind..
tgt_text.3635: They say that no one has ever seen the young of the cuckoo.
tgt_text.3636: It does, however, lay eggs, but it makes no nest;
tgt_text.3637: but some­ times it lays its eggs in the nests of small birds, and devours their eggs, especially in the nests of the pigeon, when it has eaten their eggs.
tgt_text.3638: Sometimes it lays two, but usually only i one egg;
tgt_text.3639: it lays also in the nest of the hypolais,1 which hatches and brings it up.
tgt_text.3640: At this season it is particularly fat and sweet-fleshed ;
tgt_text.3641: the flesh also of young hawks is very sweet and fat.
tgt_text.3642: There is also a kind of them which builds a nest in precipitous cliffs.1.
tgt_text.3643: IN many birds the male alternates with the female in the duty of incubation, as we observed in speaking of pigeons, and takes her place while she is obliged to procure food for herself.
tgt_text.3644: In geese the female alone sits upon the eggs, and having once begun, sibe never leaves them during the whole- process of incubation.
tgt_text.3645: The nests of all water birds are situated in marshy and grassy places, by which means they can keep quiet and still have food within their reach, so that they do not starve all the while.
tgt_text.3646: The females alone, among the crows, sit on the eggs, which they never leave;
tgt_text.3647: but the males bring them food and feed them.
tgt_text.3649: The females of the pigeons begin to sit at twilight, and remain on the nest the whole night, till dawn;
tgt_text.3650: and the male the rest of the time.
tgt_text.3651: Partridges make two nests of eggs, upon one of which the male sits, on the other the female;
tgt_text.3652: and each of them hatches and brings up its own:
tgt_text.3653: and the male has sexual intercourse with its young as soon as they are hatched.
tgt_text.3655: THE peacock lives about twenty-five years, and produces young generally at three years old;
tgt_text.3656: by which time also they have obtained their variegated plumage:
tgt_text.3657: and it hatches in thirty days, or rather more.
tgt_text.3658: It only produces young once a-year, laying twelve eggs, or not quite so many.
tgt_text.3659: It lays its eggs at intervals of two or three days, and not regularly.
tgt_text.3660: At first they lay only eight.
tgt_text.3661: The pea-fowl also lays barren eggs:
tgt_text.3662: they copulate in the spring, and lay their eggs imme­ diately afterwards.
tgt_text.3664: This bird sheds its feathers when the leaves of the trees begin to fall, and begins to acquire them again with the first budding in the spring.
tgt_text.3665: Those who rear these birds place the eggs for incubation beneath domestic fowls ;
tgt_text.3666: because the peacock flies at, and torments the hen when she is sitting;
tgt_text.3667: for which reason some of the wild birds make their escape from the males before they begin to lay and sit.
tgt_text.3668: They place only two eggs under domestic fowls, for these are all that they can hatch and bring out;
tgt_text.3669: and they take care to put food before them, that they may not get up and desert their incubation.
tgt_text.3671: Birds at the season of sexual intercourse have large testicles.
tgt_text.3672: In the more lascivious they are always more evi­ dent, as the domestic cock and the partridge.
tgt_text.3673: In those that are not always lascivious, they are less.
tgt_text.3674: This, is the manner of the gestation and reproduction of birds.
tgt_text.3676: IT has been already observed that fish are not always oviparous, for the selache are always viviparous.
tgt_text.3678: The selache are viviparous, having first of all produced ova internally;
tgt_text.3679: and these they bring up in themselves, except the batrachus.
tgt_text.3680: Fish have also, as I observed before, very different uteri in different kinds:
tgt_text.3681: for in the oviparous genera- the uterus is double, and situated low down.
tgt_text.3682: In the selache the uterus is more like that of birds.
tgt_text.3683: There is this difference, however, that the ova are not placed near the diaphragm, but in an intermediate position near the spine;
tgt_text.3684: and when they have grown they change their place from this part.
tgt_text.3685: The ovum in all fish is not of two, but of one colour ;
tgt_text.3686: and it is more white than yellow, both in its early stages, and after the formation of the embryo.2.
tgt_text.3687: The development of the ovum is different in fish and in birds, in that it has not the umbilical cord which passes to the membrane of the shell;
tgt_text.3688: but only the passage which leads to the yolk in the eggs of birds.
tgt_text.3689: The rest of the deve­ lopment of the ovum is alike in birds and fish ;
tgt_text.3690: for it takes place at the extremity, and the veins have their origin in a similar manner in'the heart;
tgt_text.3691: and the head, and eyes, and upper parts of the body are larger than the rest.
tgt_text.3692: As the young fish increases, the ovum continues to diminish, and at last it disappears, and is absorbed, like the yolk in the eggs of birds.
