tgt_text.4536: There is also considerable variety in the bosoms of young girls, for in some they are very large, in others small.
tgt_text.4537: This generally takes place in those girls which have much superfluous humour, for when the cata­ menia are about to appear, but before they arrive, the more fluid the patient is, the more necessary it is that the breasts should increase until the catamenia make their appearance, and the breasts, which then begin to increase, remain so after­ wards.
tgt_text.4538: In youths and aged men the breasts are more con­ spicuous, and more like those of femalesj and in those who are of a soft habit of body, and are smooth and not full of veins, and in dark persons also more than fair ones.
tgt_text.4540: Until twenty-one years of age the semen is unpro­ ductive, afterwards it becomes fertile, though boys and girls produce small and imperfect children:
tgt_text.4541: this is also the case with other animals.
tgt_text.4542: Young girls conceive more readily, but after conception suffer more in parturition, and their bodies frequently become imperfect.
tgt_text.4543: Men of violent pas­ sions, and women that have borne many children, grow old more rapidly than others;
tgt_text.4544: nor does there appear to be any increase after they have borne three children.
tgt_text.4545: Women of violent sexual desires become more temperate after they have borne several children.
tgt_text.4547: Women who have attained thrice seven years are well adapted for child-bearing, and men also are capable of.
tgt_text.4550: That which is lumpy begets males;
tgt_text.4551: what is thin and not clotted, females.
tgt_text.4552: The beard also appears on the chin of men at the same period.
tgt_text.4554: THE catamenia appear when the moon is on the wane, from which some persons would argue that the moon is a female, for the purification of women and the waning of the moon occur together, and repletion occurs again in both after the purification and waning.
tgt_text.4555: In few women the catamenia occur every month, but in most at every third month.
tgt_text.4556: Those in whom they continue for only two or three days escape with ease:
tgt_text.4557: it is more difficult for those in whom it continues for a longer time, for they suffer during the whole period.
tgt_text.4558: In some the purification takes place all at once, in others by degrees ;
tgt_text.4559: in all, however, the pain is con­ siderable as long as they are present.
tgt_text.4560: In many wo­ men, when the catamenia are nearly ready to appear, the womb suffers so much from strangulation and disturbance, until they are discharged.
tgt_text.4562: Conception naturally takes place immediately after this discharge in women, and those who do not then con­ ceive, are usually barren.
tgt_text.4563: Some women, however, who have never menstruated, conceive.
tgt_text.4564: Such persons contain in themselves as much of the fluid as is usually left behind after the purification, but not so much as to make its ap­ pearance externally.
tgt_text.4565: Some women in whom the uterus has closed immediately after the purification, conceive even while menstruating, but do not conceive afterwards.
tgt_text.4566: The cata­ menia sometimes occur even in pregnant women.
tgt_text.4567: Such women usually bear imperfect children, and their offspring either do not grow up, or are weakly.
tgt_text.4569: It frequently happens that from the want of sexual intercourse, or from youth and the period of life, or from long abstinence, the uterus descends, and the catamenia occur several times in the month, until they conceive;
tgt_text.4570: after which the parts return to their proper place:
tgt_text.4571: and sometimes even in women with a good habit of body, if the humours are abundant, an effusion of the semen takes place if it is too moist.
tgt_text.4573: It has already been observed that this purification is more abundant in women than in any other creature.
tgt_text.4574: In animals that are not viviparous no symptoms of anything of the kind occur, for this superfluous matter is returned into their own body, for in many the females are superior to the males in size, and in many it is turned to the formation of plates, or scales, or abundance of feathers.
tgt_text.4575: In viviparous ani­ mals with feet, it is turned to the formation of hair and bulk of body (for man is the only animal that is smooth), or of urine;
tgt_text.4576: for in almost all animals this secretion is thick and abundant.
tgt_text.4577: In women, on the contrary, all the superfluous matter of the body is directed to this purification.
tgt_text.4579: The case of the male is the same, for in proportion to his size, man emits more semen than other animals;
tgt_text.4580: (where­ fore, also, man is the smoothest of all animals,) and among men those which abound in humours, and are not very full fleshed, and fair men more than dark ones.
tgt_text.4582: For in those that are full fleshed, the greater part of the secretion goes to the supply of the body, and in the act of sexual intercourse, fair women have naturally more seminal fluid than dark ones.
tgt_text.4583: Liquid and acid foods also increase this kind of intercourse.
tgt_text.4585: It is a sign that women have conceived when the puden.
tgt_text.4587: If the labia are smooth they will not conceive, for it slips out;
tgt_text.4588: nor will they if the labia are thick:
tgt_text.4589: but if there is a sensation of roughness and re­ sistance when touched with the finger, and the labia are thin, they are then adapted for conception.
tgt_text.4590: In order that they may be able to conceive, such women must prepare the uterus, and the contrary that they may not conceive;
tgt_text.4591: for if the labia are smooth they do not conceive:
tgt_text.4592: so that some \ women, in order that the semen may fall outside the uterus, anoint themselves with oil of cedar, or with ceruse, or oil mixed with frankincense.
tgt_text.4594: If it remain seven days, it is evident that conception has taken place, for in this period what are called the out­ pourings take place.
tgt_text.4595: The purification takes place in many women after conception.
tgt_text.4596: Thirty days afterwards in the case of conceiving a female child, and forty in the case of a male.
tgt_text.4597: After parturition, also, the purification lasts a simi­ lar number of days, though it is not exactly the same in all.
tgt_text.4599: In the same number of days after conception the dis­ charge no longer takes its usual course, but is turned towards the mammae, in which the milk begins to make its appearance.
tgt_text.4600: At first the milk appears very small, and like a web in the mammæ.
tgt_text.4601: After conception, the first sensation generally takes place in the iliac region, which immediately appears more full in some persons.
tgt_text.4602: This is more conspicuous in slight persons.
tgt_text.4603: If the child is a male, a movement is usually felt on the right side of the groin, in about forty days ;
tgt_text.4604: if a female, the movement occurs on the left side, in about ninety days.
tgt_text.4605: We must not suppose, however, that an accu­ rate judgment can be formed in this way, for it often happens that the movement is felt on the right side when a female child, and on the left when a male child is conceived.
tgt_text.4606: All these, and such like things, vary in a greater or less degree.
tgt_text.4608: About this period, also, the foetus becomes divided;
tgt_text.4609: it previously existed as an undivided mass of flesh.
tgt_text.4610: If it pe­ rishes within seven days, it is called an effluxion;
tgt_text.4611: if in forty days, an abortion.
tgt_text.4612: The foetus often perishes within this period.
tgt_text.4613: If the male foetus is excluded within forty days, and is put out into any other fluid, it becomes dis­ solved, and disappears.
tgt_text.4614: If placed in cold water, it becomes, as it were, surrounded with a membrane.
tgt_text.4615: When this is taken off, the feetus appears about as large as a large ant.
tgt_text.4616: Its parts are visible, both those of generation, and all the rest;
tgt_text.4617: and the eyes are very large, as in other animals.
tgt_text.4618: If the female foetus perishes within the three months, it generally appears without divisions.
tgt_text.4619: If it survives to the fourth month, the parts appear formed.
tgt_text.4621: The whole completion of the parts is more slow in the female than in the male, and parturition is more frequently delayed to the tenth month.
tgt_text.4622: After birth, females attain to youth, and puberty, and old age, more rapidly than males, and those that have borne many children more rapidly than others, as it was observed before.
tgt_text.4624: WHEN conception has taken place, the uterus usually closes immediately for seven months.
tgt_text.4625: In the eighth month it opens, and the foetus, if properly developed, begins to descend in the eighth month.
tgt_text.4626: If the foetus is not properly deve­ loped, but checked in the eighth month in parturition, women who bear in the eighth month do not exclude it, nor does the foetus advance downwards in the eighth month, and the uterus does not open itself.
tgt_text.4627: It is a sign that it is not properly developed, when it is born before the circum­ stances I have described take place.
tgt_text.4628: 2. After conception, women suffer throughout their whole body, and their sight becomes dim, and they are afflicted with headache.
tgt_text.4629: In some, these symptoms occur very soon, as early as the tenth day;
tgt_text.4630: in others they are delayed, in proportion as they have an abundance or deficiency of super­ fluous matter in their bodies.
tgt_text.4631: Nausea and vomiting often seize upon them, and on those especially in whom the puri­ fications become stagnant, and do not yet fly to the mammæ.
tgt_text.4632: Some women suffer at the commencement of pregnancy, and others in the more advanced stages, when the foetus be­ gins to grow.
tgt_text.4633: Retention of urine also frequently attacks them at last.
tgt_text.4634: 3. Those that are pregnant with a male foetus, usually pass through the time more easily, and retain a better colour throughout.
tgt_text.4635: If a female is conceived, the contrary is the case;
tgt_text.4636: for they are generally more discoloured, and sutler more during the period of gestation.
tgt_text.4637: In many cases the legs swell, and a swollen condition of the flesh is also com­ mono
tgt_text.4638: In some women, however, the condition is contrary.
tgt_text.4639: Pregnant women are apt to have all sorts of fancies, which change very rapidly.
tgt_text.4641: These fancies are strongest when a female is conceived, and there is but little pleasure in their gratification.
tgt_text.4642: In a few women the condition of the body is better during preg­ nancy ;
tgt_text.4643: they suffer most when the hair of the foetus begins to grow.
tgt_text.4644: Pregnant women lose the hair which grows on the parts that are hairy at birth, while it becomes more thick upon the parts on which it appears subsequent to birth.
tgt_text.4646: A male foetus usually moves more freely in the womb than a female, and the "parturition is not so long.
tgt_text.4647: If a fe­ male, the parturition is slower.
tgt_text.4648: The pain in the birth of female children is continuous, and dull;
tgt_text.4649: in the birth of males it is sharp, and far more severe.
tgt_text.4650: Those who, before parturition, have sexual intercourse, suffer less in the pro­ cess.
tgt_text.4651: Sometimes women seem to suffer, not from any pain of their own, but from the turning of the head of the child ;
tgt_text.4652: and this appears to be the commencement of the pain.
tgt_text.4653: Other animals have a single exact period for parturition, for one time is appointed for them all.
tgt_text.4654: The human subject alone varies in this particular, for the period of gestation is seven, eight, or nine months, or ten at the outside, though some have even advanced as far as the eleventh month.
tgt_text.4656: If any are born before the seventh month, they never live.
tgt_text.4657: Those of seven months are the first that are developed, but these are usually weakly, wherefore, also, they wrap them in wool.
tgt_text.4658: Many of these infants have the passages, as the ears and nostrils, imperforate.
tgt_text.4659: As they grow, how­ ever, they assume a proper form, and many of them survive.
tgt_text.4660: In Egypt, and some other places, where the women suffer little pain in parturition, and where they bear many chil­ dren with ease, those even at the end of eight months are capable of living, even although they should be monstrous;
tgt_text.4661: but in such places children born in the eighth month may survive and be brought up.
tgt_text.4662: In Greece, however, few of them survive, and most of them perish;
tgt_text.4663: and people suspect that if any of them survive, the exact period of conception must have been mistaken by the mother.
tgt_text.4665: Women suffer most in the fourth and eighth mouth, and if the foetus dies in the fourth or eighth month, they usually die also;
tgt_text.4666: so that not only children born in the eighth month often perish, but their mothers also perish with them.
tgt_text.4667: In the same way, the period of conception probably is mistaken by those who have been pregnant more than eleven months;
tgt_text.4668: for in these cases the beginning of the conception escapes the notice of females, for frequently after the uterus has been distended with flatulence, women have copulated and conceived, and supposed that the former condition in which they observed the usual symptoms, was the commencement of gestation.
tgt_text.4670: THE human subject also differs from other animals, as to the number of the perfect offspring produced at a birth.
tgt_text.4671: For the human subject differs both from animals which produce but one, and those which produce many;
tgt_text.4672: for, generally speaking, and, in most cases, women have but one child at a time, though cases of twins occur frequently, and in many places, as in Egypt, three or four at a birth have been known in some particular places, as I have observed before.
tgt_text.4673: Five at a birth are the most that have been produced.
tgt_text.4674: This has been observed to take place in many cases, but in one case only have twenty been pro­ duced at four births, for five were born each time, and many of them were reared.
tgt_text.4675: In other animals, if the twins are male and female, there is no more difficulty in rearing and preserving them, than if they were both of the same sex.
tgt_text.4676: In the human subject there are few cases of twins surviving, when one was male and the other female.
tgt_text.4678: The human female and the mare copulate after con­ ception more than any other creatures, for all other females, when they have conceived, fly from the males, except those which, like the hare, become pregnant a second time during gestation.
tgt_text.4679: But the mare, having once conceived, does not form a second foetus, but generally produces a single foal.
tgt_text.4680: In the human subject it happens sometimes, though rarely.
tgt_text.4681: Those which are conceived a long while afterwards never come to perfection, but, from the pain which they cause, destroy the original foetus;
tgt_text.4682: and a case has occurred in which twelve imperfect embryos have been produced at one time.
tgt_text.4683: If the second conception take place soon after the first, they bear and produce the fetus, as if it were a twin.
tgt_text.4684: This, they say, was the case with Iphicles and Her­ cules.
tgt_text.4686: The possibility of the case is manifest, for an adulteress has been known to produce one child like her husband, and another like her paramour;
tgt_text.4687: and a case has occurred of a woman having conceived twins, and then conceived a third child upon them;
tgt_text.4688: and when the proper time came, the twins were born perfect, the other was only a foetus of five months old, which died immediately:
tgt_text.4689: and in another case, a woman produced, first of all, a foetus of seven months old, and then twins, perfectly developed;
tgt_text.4690: the former perished, but the latter survived.
tgt_text.4691: And some women have conceived at the same time as they miscarried, and have ejected one foetus while they bore the other.
tgt_text.4692: In most females, who have cohabited after the eighth month after conception, the child has been born filled with a shining mucous-like substance, and has often appeared full of the food which has been eaten by the mother;
tgt_text.4693: and if she has fed upon food more than usually salt, the child has been born without nails.
tgt_text.4695: THE milk that is produced before the seventh month is useless;
tgt_text.4696: but as soon as the child is alive the milk be­ comes good.
tgt_text.4697: At first it is salt, like that of sheep.
tgt_text.4698: Most women during pregnancy are affected by wine, and if they drink it they become faint and feeble.
tgt_text.4699: The begin­ ning and the ending of the reproductive power in both sexes is marked in the male by the emission of the semen, in the female by the catamenia.
tgt_text.4700: They are not, how­ ever, fertile when these first occur, nor while they are still small and weak.
tgt_text.4701: The period of the commencement of these signs has been mentioned.
tgt_text.4702: In women the cata­ menia usually cease at forty;
tgt_text.4703: but if they pass over this age, they go on to fifty;
tgt_text.4704: and some have even produced children at that period, but none later than this period.
tgt_text.4706: The reproductive function in men usually continues active till they are sixty years old;
tgt_text.4707: if they pass beyond this period, till they are seventy;
tgt_text.4708: and some men have had chil­ dren at seventy years old.
tgt_text.4709: It frequently happens that, when marriages are unfruitful, both men and women become preg­ nant, if the marriage is dissolved and they marry again.
tgt_text.4710: The same thing takes place respecting the birth of male and female children.
tgt_text.4711: For sometimes only children of one sex are produced by a marriage;
tgt_text.4712: and if this is dissolved, and the parents marry again, children of the other sex are produced.
tgt_text.4713: These things also vary with the age of the parents;
tgt_text.4714: for some when young have female children, and when older males, though the contrary sometimes takes place.
tgt_text.4716: The same is the case with the whole of the reproductive function.
tgt_text.4717: For some persons have no children when they are young, but have them afterwards;
tgt_text.4718: others have children at first, but none afterwards;
tgt_text.4719: and there are some women who conceive with difficulty, but when they have conceived bear children;
tgt_text.4720: others conceive easily, but the foetus never comes to maturity.
tgt_text.4721: There are also both men and women who only produce children of one sex, as the story goes of Hercules, who had but one daughter in seventy-two children.
tgt_text.4722: Those who have been barren, and either after great care, or from any other cause, at last conceive, more frequently bear a daughter than a son.
tgt_text.4723: It often happens also that men who have engendered become impotent, and subsequently return to their former condition.
tgt_text.4726: and so also lame and blind parents produce lame and blind children;
tgt_text.4727: and, on the whole, children are often born with anything contrary to nature, or any mark which their parents may have, such as tumours and wounds.
tgt_text.4728: Such marks have often been handed down for three generations;
tgt_text.4729: as if a person had a mark on their arm which was not seen in the son, but the grandson exhibited a dark confused spot on the same, place.
tgt_text.4731: and sound children are generally produced from lame parents;
tgt_text.4732: nor is there any com­ plete certainty in these matters ;
tgt_text.4733: and children resemble their parents or their grandparents, and sometimes they resemble neither.
tgt_text.4734: This is handed down for many gene­ rations ;
tgt_text.4735: as in Sicily, a woman cohabited with an Ethiopian, her daughter was not black, but her daughter's child was so.5.
tgt_text.4736: For the most part the girls resemble their mother, and the boys their father;
tgt_text.4737: though the contrary is often the case, alid the females resemble their father, and the males their mother, and the different parts of the body resemble either parents.
tgt_text.4738: Twins have sometimes no resemblance to each other, but they are generally much alike;
tgt_text.4739: and one woman coha­ bited with a man, and conceived seven days after parturi­ tion, when she bore a child as like her former as if they had been twins.
tgt_text.4740: Some women, as well as other creatures, pro­ duce young resembling themselves, others bear those which resemble the male, as the horse called DicTa in Pharsalia.1.
tgt_text.4741: THE seminal fluid in its emission is preceded by wind.
tgt_text.4742: The manner of its emission exhibits this;
tgt_text.4743: for nothing is expelled to a great distance without pneumatic force.
tgt_text.4744: If the seminal fluid is taken up by the uterus and retained there, it becomes inclosed in a membrane.
tgt_text.4745: For if it is expelled before it becomes articulated, it appears like an ovum inclosed in a membrane, but without any shell, and the membrane, is full of veins.
tgt_text.4746: All animals, whether furnished with fins, feet, or wings, whether viviparous or oviparous, are produced in the same manner, except that the umbilicus in viviparous animals is turned towards the uterus, and in others to the ovum;
tgt_text.4747: and in some cases both ways, as in a certain kind of fish.
tgt_text.4748: Some of them are surrounded by a membrane, others by a chorion.
tgt_text.4749: First of all, the foetus is contained within the last envelope.
tgt_text.4750: Then there is another membrane over this, which is in part united to the matrix and is partly separate, and contains water.
tgt_text.4751: Between these is a watery or sanguineous fluid, which in women is called prophorus.
tgt_text.4753: All animals that have a navel increase by the navel;
tgt_text.4754: and in those which have acetabula the navel is united to the acetabulum;
tgt_text.4755: and in those which have a smooth uterus the navel is united to the uterus upon a vein.
tgt_text.4756: The position of all quadrupeds in the uterus is stretched out;
tgt_text.4757: that of fishes is on the side;
tgt_text.4758: bipeds, as birds, are folded together.
tgt_text.4759: The human foetus lies folded up with its nose between its knees and its eyes upon them, and its ears turned outwards.
tgt_text.4760: All animals are alike in having the head placed upwards at first.
tgt_text.4761: As they grow, the head turns round, and the birth of all animals is naturally with the head forwards;
tgt_text.4762: for even in those that are folded together the presentation of the feet is unnatural.
tgt_text.4763: The embryo of quadrupeds contains excrementitious matter, as soon as it is matured, both fluid and solid.
tgt_text.4764: The latter is contained in the extreme parts of the intestine, the former in the bladder.
tgt_text.4766: If animals have acetabula in the uterus, these aceta­ bula always become smaller as the foetus grows, and at last disappear.
tgt_text.4767: The umbilical cord is a covering for veins, of which the origin is in the uterus.
tgt_text.4768: In those crea tures which have acetabula it originates in them;
tgt_text.4769: in those that have not acetabula it originates in the vein.
tgt_text.4770: In the larger animals, such as the foetus of oxen, there are four veins ;
tgt_text.4772: in very small animals, as in birds, there is but one.
tgt_text.4773: Two veins reach the foetus through the liver, from that part called the gates of the liver, towards the great vein;
tgt_text.4774: and two go to the aorta, where it is divided into two parts;
tgt_text.4775: and there are membranes round each pair of veins, and the umbilical cord surrounds these membranes like a covering.
tgt_text.4776: As the foetus increases, these veins diminish.
tgt_text.4777: The embryo, as it grows, advances into the viscera, where its movements are manifest.
tgt_text.4778: Sometimes it remains rolled up near the pudendum.1.
tgt_text.4779: WHEN the pains of parturition come on, they extend to many and various parts of the body, but especially to one or other of the thighs.
tgt_text.4780: Those who suffer most in the bowels are delivered most rapidly;
tgt_text.4781: those who suffer much in the loins are delivered with difficulty;
tgt_text.4782: those whose pain lies in the subumbilical region, more quickly.
tgt_text.4783: If the child is a male, a liquid, serum-like discharge, of a pale yellow colour, pre­ cedes ;
tgt_text.4784: if a female, this discharge is sanguineous, but still fluid.
tgt_text.4785: Some women have neither during the period of par­ turition.
tgt_text.4787: In other animals parturition is not painful, and it is evident that they suffer but moderately in the pains of labour.
tgt_text.4788: In women the pains of parturition are more violent, especially in those that are inactive or that are not well made in their sides, and are unable to hold their breath.
tgt_text.4789: They also suffer more in parturition, if they breathe in the mean­ time, compelled by the necessity of respiration.
tgt_text.4791: At first a fluid escapes when the fœtus comes to the birth, and the mem­ branes are ruptured;
tgt_text.4792: after this, the embryo is excluded, the uterus being turned, and the uterus being turned inside-out.1.
tgt_text.4793: THE division of the umbilical cord often requires the care.
tgt_text.4795: for by skilfulness she may not only assist in difficult labours, but should attend carefully to the circumstances, and apply the ligature to the umbilical cord of the child;
tgt_text.4796: for if the secundines fall out with the child, the umbilical cord must be bound with a ligature of worsted, and cut above the ligature, and where it is bound it joins together, and that which is joined with it falls off.
tgt_text.4797: If the ligature becomes loose, the child dies from loss of blood.
tgt_text.4798: If the secundines do not come out at once, while they remain within, and the child is outside, the umbilical cord must be tied and divided.
tgt_text.4800: Frequently the child, if weak, has appeared as if born dead, until the umbilical cord was tied, for the blood flowed from the child to the navel and the surrounding parts;
tgt_text.4801: but some skilful midwife being present, by pressure on the navel from within has revived the child, just as if it had been filled with blood from the first.
tgt_text.4802: It has been already observed, that all animals are naturally born with the head forwards.
tgt_text.4803: Chil­ dren also have their hands pressed down against their sides.
tgt_text.4804: As soon as they are born they begin to cry and bring their hands to their mouth.
tgt_text.4805: They emit excrements, some imme­ diately, others very soon, but all in the course of a day.
tgt_text.4806: This excrementitious matter is very abundant, considering the size of the child.
tgt_text.4808: Its colour is like that of blood, and it is black and pitch-like.
tgt_text.4809: Afterwards it becomes milky, for the child immediately draws the breast.
tgt_text.4810: The child never cries before it is entirely in the world, not even though its head is protruded in difficult cases, while the body is within the uterus.
tgt_text.4812: Those women in whom a flooding has preceded the period of delivery are delivered with more difficulty, and if the purifications are small after parturition, and only as much as they are at first, and do not continue for more than forty days, such women are stronger, and more ready for conception.
tgt_text.4813: After children are born, for forty days they neither laugh nor weep when awake, but sometimes do both in their sleep;
tgt_text.4814: nor do they usually feel when they are tickled, but they sleep the greater part of their time.
tgt_text.4815: As they grow, the period ot wakefulness continually increases;
tgt_text.4816: and it is evident that they dream, but it is some time before they remember their imagi­ nations.
tgt_text.4817: There is no difference in the bones of other ani­ mals, but they are all born perfect.
tgt_text.4818: In children the bone called bregma is soft, and does not become strong for some time.
tgt_text.4819: Some animals are born with teeth, but children begin to cut their teeth in the seventh month.
tgt_text.4820: The front teeth naturally appear first, sometimes the upper teeth and some-, times the under.
tgt_text.4821: Children cut their teeth more easily if their nurses have warmer milk.
tgt_text.4822: AFTER parturition and purification women become full of milk;
tgt_text.4823: and in some it not only flows through the nipples but through other parts of the breast, and sometimes from the cheeks;
tgt_text.4824: and if this fluid is not matured nor secreted, but remains full, hard knots are formed, which remain for a long time;
tgt_text.4825: for every part of the breast is so spongy that, if a hair is swallowed with the drink, pain ensues in the breasts, until it either escapes spontaneously with the milk, or is sucked out, this is called τϱιχιᾳ̑ν.
tgt_text.4826: They continue to have milk until they conceive again.
tgt_text.4827: It then ceases, and is quenched in other creatures as well as in the human subject.
tgt_text.4828: The catamenia seldom take place while milk is secreted, though this sometimes occurs in women while nursing.
tgt_text.4829: On the whole, an effusion of fluid seldom takes place from many parts of the body at the same time, and those that have haemorrhoids have usually less purifica­ tion.
tgt_text.4830: In some it takes place through ixiæ (varices), and is secreted from the loins before it reaches -the uterus;
tgt_text.4831: and those who vomit blood when the purification is suppressed suffer no harm.
tgt_text.4832: CHILDREN are very subject to spasms, and especially those that are in a good condition and have abundance of rich milk, or whose nurses are fat.
tgt_text.4833: Wine is injurious in this complaint, and dark-coloured wines more so than those that are pale, and food that is not fluid, and windy aliments, and stoppage in the bowels.
tgt_text.4834: Children with this complaint gene­ rally die before the seventh day:
tgt_text.4835: wherefore also this day has received a name, as if it gave some hope of the recovery of the child.
tgt_text.4836: Children suffer most at the full moon.
tgt_text.4837: Chil­ dren are in great danger when the spasms originate in the back, especially if they are advancing in age.
tgt_text.4839: THE nature, of animals and their mode of reproduction has now been described.
tgt_text.4840: Their actions and mode of life also differ according to their disposition and their food.
tgt_text.4841: For almost all animals present traces of their moral dis­ positions, though these distinctions are most remarkable in man.
tgt_text.4842: For most of them, as we remarked, when speaking of their various parts, appear to exhibit gentleness or ferocity, mildness or cruelty, courage or cowardice, fear or boldness, violence or cunning;
tgt_text.4843: and many of them ex­ hibit something like a rational consciousness, as we re­ marked in speaking of their parts.
tgt_text.4844: For they differ from man, and man from the other animals, in a greater or less degree;
tgt_text.4845: for some of these traits are exhibited strongly in man, and others in other animals.
tgt_text.4848: For as men exhibit art, wisdom, and intelligence, animals possess, by way of com­ pensation, some other physical power.
tgt_text.4849: This is most con­ spicuous in the examination of infants, for in them we see, as it were, the vestiges and seeds of their future disposition;
tgt_text.4850: nor does their soul at this period differ in any respect from that of an animal;
tgt_text.4851: so that it is not unreasonable for animals to present the same, or similar, or analogous appearances.
tgt_text.4852: Nature passes so gradually from inanimate to animate things, that from their continuity their boundary and the mean be­ tween them is indistinct.
tgt_text.4853: The race of plants succeeds imme­ diately that of inanimate objects;
tgt_text.4854: and these differ from each other in the proportion of life in which they participate;
tgt_text.4855: for, compared with other bodies, plants appear to possess life, though, when compared with animals, they appear in­ animate.
tgt_text.4857: The change from plants to animals, however, is gra­ dual, as I before observed.
tgt_text.4858: For a person might question to i which of these classes some marine objects belong;
tgt_text.4859: for many of them are attached to the rock, and perish as soon as they are separated from it.
tgt_text.4860: The pinnæ are attached to the rocks, the solens cannot live after they are taken away from their localities ;
tgt_text.4861: and, on the whole, all the testacea resemble plants, if we compare them with locomotive animals.
tgt_text.4862: Some of them appear to have no sensation;
tgt_text.4863: in others it is very dull.
tgt_text.4864: The body of some of them is naturally fleshy, as of those which are called tethya;
tgt_text.4865: and the acalephe and the sponge entirely re­ semble plants;
tgt_text.4866: the progress is always gradual by-which one appears to have more life and motion than another.
tgt_text.4868: In the vital actions also we may observe the same man­ ner.
tgt_text.4869: For vegetables which are produced from seed ap­ pear to have no other work beyond reproduction;
tgt_text.4870: nor do some animals appear to have any other object in their exist­ ence.
tgt_text.4871: This object then is common to them all;
tgt_text.4872: but as sen­ sation advances, their manner of life differs in their having pleasure in sexual intercourse, in their mode of parturition and rearing their young.
tgt_text.4873: Some of them, like plants, simply accomplish their peculiar mode of reproduction at an ap­ pointed season, and others are diligent in rearing their young;
tgt_text.4874: but as soon as this is accomplished they separate from them, and have no farther communication;
tgt_text.4875: but those that are more intelligent, and possess more memory, use their offspring in a more civilized manner.
tgt_text.4877: The work of reproduction is one part of their life, the work of procuring food forms another.
tgt_text.4878: These two occupy their labour and their life.
tgt_text.4879: Their food differs in the sub­ stances of which it consists, and all the natural increase of the body is derived from food.
tgt_text.4880: That which is natural is pleasant, and all animals follow that which is pleasant to their nature.
tgt_text.4882: ANIMALS are divided according to the localities which they inhabit;
tgt_text.4883: for some animals are terrestrial, others are aquatic.
tgt_text.4884: They also admit of a ternary division, those that breathe air and those that breathe water, one of these classes is terrestrial, the other is aquatic ;
tgt_text.4885: the third class does not breathe either air or water, but they are adapted by nature to receive refreshment from each of these elements;
tgt_text.4886: and some of these are called terrestrial, others are aquatic, though they neither breathe air or water;
tgt_text.4887: and there are other animals which procure their food and make their abode in either of these elements.
tgt_text.4888: For many that breathe air, and produce their young upon the land, procure their food from the water, where they generally make their abode;
tgt_text.4889: and these are the only animals which appear to be doubtful, for they may be arranged either as terrestrial or aquatic animals.
tgt_text.4891: Of those that breathe water, none have feet or wings, nor seek their food on land ;
tgt_text.4892: but many of those that are ter­ restrial, and breathe air, do so ;
tgt_text.4893: some of them so much so, that they cannot live when separated from the water, as those which are called marine turtles, and crocodiles, and hippo­ potami, and seals, and some of the smaller creatures, as the water tortoise and the frog tribe;
tgt_text.4894: for all these are suffocated if their respiration is suspended for any length of time.
tgt_text.4895: They produce their young and rear them on dry land ;
tgt_text.4896: others do so near the dry land, while they reside in the water.
tgt_text.4898: Of all animals the most remarkable in this particular is the dolphin, and some other aquatic animals and cetacea which are of this habit, as the whale and others which have a blowhole ;
tgt_text.4899: for it is not easy to arrange them either with aquatic or terrestrial animals, if we consider animals that breathe air as terrestrial, and those that breathe water as aquatics, for they partake of the characters of both classes;
tgt_text.4900: for they receive the sea and eject it through their blowhole, and air' through their lungs, for they have this part, and breathe through it.
tgt_text.4901: And the dolphin, when captured in nets, is often suffocated, from the impossibility of breathing.
tgt_text.4902: It will live for a long while out of water, snoring and groaning like other breathing animals.
tgt_text.4903: It sleeps with its snout above the water, in order that it may breathe through it.
tgt_text.4905: It is thus impossible to arrange it under both of these contrary divisions, but it would appear that the aquatic ani­ mals must be further subdivided;
tgt_text.4906: for they breathe and eject water for the same reason as others breathe air, for the sake of coolness.
tgt_text.4907: Other animals do this for the sake of food;
tgt_text.4908: for those animals which obtain their food in the water, must also, at the same time, swallow some of the fluid, and have an organ by which they can eject it.
tgt_text.4909: Those creatures which use water instead of air for breathing have gills;
tgt_text.4910: those that use it for food have a blowhole.
tgt_text.4912: The nature of the malacia and malacostraca is the same;
tgt_text.4913: for these swallow water for food.
tgt_text.4915: Those animals which breathe air, but live in the water, and those which breathe water, and have gills, but go out upon dry land and take their food there, belong to two divi­ sions of aquatic animals.
tgt_text.4916: This last division is represented by a single animal called the cordylus (water newt) ;
tgt_text.4917: for this animal has no lungs, but gills;
tgt_text.4918: and it goes on dry land to procure its food.
tgt_text.4919: It has four feet, so that it appears na­ tural that it should walk.
tgt_text.4920: In all these animals nature ap­ pears to be, as it were, turned aside, and some of the males appear to be females, and the females have a male appear­ ance ;
tgt_text.4921: for animals which have but small diversity in particular parts, exhibit great variations in the whole body.
tgt_text.4923: This is evident in castrated animals ;
tgt_text.4924: for if a small portion only of the body is destroyed, the animal becomes a female ;
tgt_text.4925: so that it is plain that if a very minute portion in the original composition of an animal becomes changed, if that portion belongs to the origin of the species, it might become either male or female ;
tgt_text.4926: or, if taken away altogether, the animal might be neuter.
tgt_text.4927: And so, either way, it might become a land or aquatic animal, if only a small change took place it happens that some become terrestrial and others aquatic animals, and some are not amphibious which others are, because in their original generation they received some kind of substance which they use for food.
tgt_text.4928: For that which is natural is agreeable to every animal, as I have said before.
tgt_text.4930: WHEN animals are divided in three ways into aquatic and land animals, because they either breathe air or water, or from the composition of their bodies;
tgt_text.4931: or, in the third place, from their food, their manner of life will be found to agree with these divisions.
tgt_text.4932: For some follow both the com­ position of their bodies and the nature of their food, and their respiration of either water or air.
tgt_text.4933: Others only agree' with their composition and food.
tgt_text.4935: The testacea which are immoveable live by a fluid which percolates through tne dense parts of the sea, and being digested because it is lighter than the sea water, thus returns to its original nature.
tgt_text.4936: That this fluid exists in the sea, and is capable of infiltration is manifest, and may be proved by experiment;
tgt_text.4937: for if anyone will make a thin waxen vessel, and sink it empty in the sea, in a night and a day, it may be taken up full of water, which is drinkable.
tgt_text.4939: The acalephe (actinia) feeds upon any small fish which may fall in its way.
tgt_text.4940: Its mouth is placed in the centre of its body.
tgt_text.4941: This organ is conspicuous in the larger individuals :
tgt_text.4942: like the oyster, it has a passage for the exclusion of its food, which is placed above.
tgt_text.4943: The acalephe appears to resemble the internal part of the oyster, and it makes use of the rock, as the oyster does of its shell.
tgt_text.4944: (The patella also is free, and wanders about in search of food.)4.
tgt_text.4945: Among the locomotive testacea, some are carnivorous, and live on small fish, as the purpura, for this creature is carnivorous, it is therefore caught with a bait of flesh:
tgt_text.4947: The marine turtles live upon shell-fish, for which purpose they have a very powerful mouth;
tgt_text.4948: for if any of them take a stone or any­ thing else, they break and eat it.
tgt_text.4949: This animal leaves the water and eats grass.
tgt_text.4950: They often suffer and perish, when they are dried up as they float on the surface, for they are not able to dive readily.
tgt_text.4952: The malacostraca are of the same nature, for they eat everything;
tgt_text.4953: they feed upon stones and mud, seaweeds and dung, as the rock crabs, and are also carnivorous.
tgt_text.4954: The spiny lobsters also overcome large fishes, and a kind of retribution awaits them in turn, for the polypus prevails over the lobster, for they are not inconvenienced by the shell of the lobster, so that if the lobsters perceive them in the same net with them, they die from fear.
tgt_text.4955: The spiny lobsters overcome the congers, for their roughness prevents them from falling off.
tgt_text.4956: The congers devour the polypi which cannot adhere to them on account of the smoothness of their surface ;
tgt_text.4957: all the ma­ lacia are carnivorous.
tgt_text.4959: The spiny lobsters also live on small fish, which they hunt for in their boles, for they are produced in such parts of the sea as are rough and stony, and in those places make their habitations;
tgt_text.4960: whatever they capture, they bring to their mouth with their double claw, as the crabs do.
tgt_text.4961: When not fright­ ened they naturally walk forwards, hanging their horns down at their sides.
tgt_text.4962: When alarmed they retreat backwards, and extend their horns to a great distance.
tgt_text.4963: They fight with each other like rams with their horns, raising them and striking each other.
tgt_text.4964: They are often seen in numbers as if they were gregarious.
tgt_text.4965: 7. The malacostraca lead this kind of life.
tgt_text.4966: Among the malacia the teuthis and sepia prevail over the large fish.
tgt_text.4967: The polypus generally collects shells which it empties of their contents and feeds upon them, so that those who seek for them find their holes by the shells that are scat­ tered about.
tgt_text.4968: The report that they eat each other is a mistake;
tgt_text.4969: but some have the tentacula eaten off by the congers.1.
tgt_text.4970: ALL fish at the season of oviposition live upon ova;
tgt_text.4971: in the rest of their food they are not all so well agreed, for some of them are only carnivorous, as the selachos, conger, channa, thynnus, labrax, sinodon, amia, orphus, and mu­ ræna;
tgt_text.4972: the trigla lives upon fuci, shell-fish, and mud;
tgt_text.4974: The cephalus lives on mud, the dascillus on mud and dung.
tgt_text.4975: The scarus and melanurus on sea-weed, the salpa on dung and fuci, it will also eat the plant called horehound;
tgt_text.4976: it is the only fish that can be caught with the gourd.
tgt_text.4978: All fish, except the cestreus, eat one another, especially the congers.
tgt_text.4979: The cephalus and the cestreus alone are not carnivorous.
tgt_text.4980: This is a proof of it.
tgt_text.4981: They are never cap­ tured with anything of the kind in their stomach, nor are they captured with a bait made of flesh, but with bread ;
tgt_text.4982: the cestreus is always fed upon sea-weed and sand.
tgt_text.4983: One kind of cephalus which some persons call chelone lives near the land, another is called perseas.
tgt_text.4984: This last feeds upon nothing but its own mucus, for which reason it is always very poor.
tgt_text.4985: The cephalus lives upon mud, wherefore they are heavy and slimy.
tgt_text.4986: They certainly never eat fish, on account of their dwelling in mud;
tgt_text.4987: they often emerge in order to wash themselves from the slime.
tgt_text.4988: Neither will any creature eat their ova, so that they increase rapidly, and when they increase they are devoured by other fish, and especially by the acharnus.
tgt_text.4990: The cestreus (mullet) is the most greedy and insatiable of fish, so that its abdomen is distended, and it is not good for food unless it is poor.
tgt_text.4991: When alarmed it hides its head, as if its whole body were thus concealed;
tgt_text.4992: the sinodon also is car­ nivorous, and eats the malacia.
tgt_text.4993: This fish and the channa often eject their stomachs as they pursue small fish, for their stomach is near the mouth, and they have no oesophagus.
tgt_text.4994: Some are simply carnivorous, as the dolphin, sinodon, chry­ sophrys, the selache and malacia;
tgt_text.4995: others, as the phycis, cobius, and the rock-fish, principally feed upon mud and fuci, and bryum, and what is called caulion, and any matter which may be produced in the sea.
tgt_text.4996: The phycis eats no other flesh than that of the shrimps.
tgt_text.4997: They also frequently eat each other, as I before remarked, and the greater devour the less.
tgt_text.4998: It is a proof that they are carnivorous, that they are captured with bait made of flesh.
tgt_text.4999: 4. The amia, tunny, and labrax generally eat flesh, though they also eat sea-weed.
tgt_text.5000: The sargus feeds after the trigla when the last has buried itself in the mud and departed, for it has the power of burying itself, then the sargus comes and feeds and prevents all those that are weaker than itself from approaching.
tgt_text.5001: The fish called scarus is the only one which appears to ruminate like quad­ rupeds.
tgt_text.5002: Other fish appear to hunt the smaller ones with their mouths towards them, in this way they naturally swim;
tgt_text.5003: but the selachea, dolphins and cetacea throw themselves on their back to capture their prey, for their mouth is placed below them, for this reason the smaller ones escape, or if not they would soon be reduced in number;
tgt_text.5004: for the swiftness of the dolphin and its capacity for food appear incredible.
tgt_text.5006: A few eels in some places are fed upon mud, and any kind of food which may be cast into the water, but gene­ rally they live upon fresh water, and those who rear eels take care that the water which flows off and on upon the shallows in which they live may be clear, where they make the eel preserves.
tgt_text.5007: For they are soon suffocated if the water is not clean, their gills being very small.
tgt_text.5008: For this reason those who seek for them disturb the water.
tgt_text.5009: In the Stry­ mon they are taken about the time of the rising of the Pleiades.
tgt_text.5010: For the water is disturbed at this season by the mud which is stirred up by contrary winds, otherwise it is useless to attempt to obtain them.
tgt_text.5011: When dead, eels do not rise and float on the surface, like other fishes, for their stomach is small;
tgt_text.5012: a few of them are fat, but this is not usually the case.
tgt_text.5014: When taken out of the water, they will live five or six days ;
tgt_text.5015: if the wind is in the north they will live longer than if it is in the south.
tgt_text.5016: If they are removed from the ponds to the eel preserves during the summer they perish, but not if removed in the winter ;
tgt_text.5017: neither will they bear violent changes, for if they are taken and plunged into cold water, they often perish in great numbers.
tgt_text.5018: They are suffocated also if kept in a small quantity of water.
tgt_text.5019: This takes place also in other fish, which are suffocated if kept in a small quantity of water which is never changed, like animals which breathe air when enclosed in a small quantity of air.
tgt_text.5020: Some eels live seven or eight years.
tgt_text.5021: Fresh-water fish make use of food, and devour each other, as well as plants and roots, or anything else that they can find in the mud ;
tgt_text.5022: they generally feed in the night, and during the day dwell in deep holes.
tgt_text.5023: This is the nature of the food of fish.1.
tgt_text.5024: ALL birds with crooked claws are carnivorous, nor are they able to eat corn even when put in their mouths.
tgt_text.5025: All the eagles belong to this class and the kites, and both the hawks, the pigeon hawk namely, and the sparrow hawk.
tgt_text.5026: These differ in size from each other, and so does the trior­ ches.
tgt_text.5027: This bird is as large as the kite, and is visible at all seasons of the year;
tgt_text.5028: the osprey and vulture also belong to this class.
tgt_text.5029: The osprey is as large as the eagle, and ash­ joloured.
tgt_text.5030: There are two kinds of vultures, one small and whitish, the other large and cinereous.
tgt_text.5032: Some of the night birds also have crooked claws, as the nycticorax, owl, and bryas.
tgt_text.5033: The bryas resembles an owl in appearance, but it is as large as an eagle;
tgt_text.5034: the eleos, ægolius, and scops also belong to this class.
tgt_text.5035: The eleos is larger than a domestic fowl, the segolius is about the size of that bird, they both hunt the jay.
tgt_text.5036: The scops is less than the owl;
tgt_text.5037: all three of these are similar in form, and carni­ vorous.
tgt_text.5038: Some that have not crooked claws are carnivorous, as the swallow.
tgt_text.5040: Some birds feed on worms, as the finch, the sparrow, batis, chloris, titmouse.
tgt_text.5041: There are three kinds of titmouse ;
tgt_text.5042: the spizites is the largest, it is as large as the finch.
tgt_text.5043: Another is called the orinus, because it dwells in mountains ;
tgt_text.5045: The third resembles them in everything except its size, for it is very small.
tgt_text.5046: The sycalis also, the megalocoryphus, pyrrhulas, erithacus, hypolaïs, oestrus, ty­ rannis are of this class.
tgt_text.5047: The last of these is the least, it is not much larger than a locust;
tgt_text.5048: it has a purple crest, and is altogether a graceful and well-formed bird.
tgt_text.5049: The bird called anthus also, which is of the size of the finch;
tgt_text.5050: the orospizus is like the finch, and nearly of the same size, it has a blue stripe on its neck, and lives in mountainous places.
tgt_text.5051: The wren also lives upon seeds.
tgt_text.5052: All these and such like birds either partly or entirely live on worms.
tgt_text.5054: These birds, the acanthis, thraupis, and that which is called chrysometris, all live upon thorns, but neither eat worms or any other living creature, and they both roost and feed in the same places.
tgt_text.5055: There are others which feed on gnats;
tgt_text.5056: these live chiefly by hunting for these insects, as the greater and lesser pipe, both of which are by some per­ sons called woodpeckers.
tgt_text.5057: They resemble each other in their cry, though that of the larger bird is the louder, and they both feed by flying against trees.
tgt_text.5058: The celeos also, which is as large as a turtle dove, and entirely yellow;
tgt_text.5059: its habit is to strike against trees;
tgt_text.5060: it generally lives upon trees, and has a loud voice.
tgt_text.5061: This bird generally in­ habits the Peloponnesus.
tgt_text.5062: There is also another called cnipologus, which is small, about the size of the acanthyllis;
tgt_text.5063: its colour is cinereous and spotted, and its voice is weak;
tgt_text.5065: 5. There are other birds which live upon fruit and grasses, as the phaps, phatta, peristera, oenas, and trygon.
tgt_text.5067: The phatta and peristera are always present, the trygon only in summer time;
tgt_text.5068: in the winter it is not seen, for it hides itself in holes.
tgt_text.5069: The œnas is generally seen and captured in the autumn.
tgt_text.5070: The œnas is as large as the peristera but less than the phaps.
tgt_text.5071: It is generally captured, as it is drinking;
tgt_text.5072: it comes to this country when it has young.
tgt_text.5073: All the rest come in the summer, and make their nests here, and all, except the pigeon tribe, live upon animal food.
tgt_text.5075: All birds, as far as food is concerned, are either ter­ restrial or live in the neighbourhood of rivers and ponds, or near the sea.
tgt_text.5076: Those that have webbed feet pass the greater part of their time on the water;
tgt_text.5077: those with divided feet near the water.
tgt_text.5078: Some of these dive for their food, such as live upon plants and do not eat flesh ;
tgt_text.5079: others, as the heron and white heron, live in ponds and rivers.
tgt_text.5080: The latter of these is smaller than the former, and has a flat large bill.
tgt_text.5082: The pelargus also, and the gull, the latter is ash-co­ loured, and the schœnilus, cinclos, pygargus, (and tryngas) this last is the largest of these small birds, for it is of the same size as the thrush ;
tgt_text.5083: all these birds wag their tails.
tgt_text.5084: The calidris also, this bird is variegated and ash-coloured.
tgt_text.5085: The kingfisher also lives near the water;
tgt_text.5086: there appear to be two kinds of this bird, one of which utters its cry as it sits upon the reeds, and the other, which is larger, is silent;
tgt_text.5087: they both have a blue back.
tgt_text.5088: The trochilus also, and the kingfisher and cerylus also live near the sea.
tgt_text.5089: The corona also lives upon animals which are cast on shore, for it is omnivorous.
tgt_text.5090: The white gull also, the cepphus, æthyia, and charadrius.
tgt_text.5092: The heavier web-footed birds inhabit the neighbour­ hood of rivers and ponds, as the swan, duck, phalaris, Colum­ bis, and the boscas, which is like a duck, but smaller;
tgt_text.5093: and the bird called corax, which is as large as the pelargus, but its legs are shorter, it is web-footed and a swimmer, its colour is black;
tgt_text.5094: this last bird perches upon trees, and is the only one of this class that builds its nest in such places.
tgt_text.5095: The great and small goose also, the latter is gregarious, and chenalopex, the aix, and the penelops.
tgt_text.5096: The sea eagle also lives near the sea, and fishes in the waters of lakes.
tgt_text.5098: those with crooked claws seize upon other animals which they can overcome, and upon birds.
tgt_text.5099: They do not, however, devour their own congeners, as fish frequently do ;
tgt_text.5100: ail the tribes of birds drink very little, those with crooked claws do not drink at all, or only a few of them, and these but seldom;
tgt_text.5101: of these the cenchris drinks the most ;
tgt_text.5102: the kite rarely drinks, though it has been observed to do so.
tgt_text.5104: ANIMALS covered with scaly plates, as the lizard and other quadrupeds and serpents, are omnivorous, for they cat both flesh and grass, and serpents lick their prey more than any other animal;
tgt_text.5105: all these creatures, and indeed all with spongy lungs, drink very little, and all that are oviparous are of this kind, and have but little blood.
tgt_text.5106: Serpents are all very fond of wine, so that they hunt the viper by placing vessels of wine in the hedge-rows, and they are captured when intoxicated.
tgt_text.5107: Serpents devour any animal that they may have captured, and when they have sucked out the juice, they reject all the remainder;
tgt_text.5108: nearly all such animals do this, as also the spiders.
tgt_text.5109: But the spiders suck the juice without swallowing the animal.
tgt_text.5111: 2. The serpent swallows any food which maybe presented to it, for it will devour both birds and beasts, and suck eggs..
tgt_text.5112: When it has taken its food it draws itself up, till it stands erect upon its extremity, it then gathers itself up and con­ tracts itself a little, so that when stretched out the animal it has swallowed may descend in its stomach;
tgt_text.5113: it does this because its oesophagus is long and thin.
tgt_text.5114: Phalangia and, serpents can live a long while without food, this may be seen in those that are kept by dealers in medicine.
tgt_text.5116: AMONG viviparous quadrupeds, those that are wild and have pointed teeth are all carnivorous, except some wolves, which, when they are hungry, will, as they say, eat a certain kind of earth, but this is the only exception.
tgt_text.5117: They will not eat grass unless they are sick, for some dogs eat grass and vomit it up again, and so are purified.
tgt_text.5118: The solitary wolves are more eager for human flesh than those which hunt in packs.
tgt_text.5119: 2. The animal which some persons call the glanus and others the hyaena, is not less than the wolf, it has a mane like a horse, but the hair all along its spine is more harsh and thick.
tgt_text.5120: It also secretly attacks men, and hunts them down;
tgt_text.5121: it hunts dogs also by vomiting like men;
tgt_text.5122: it also breaks open graves for the sake of this kind of food.
tgt_text.5124: The bear is also omnivorous, for it eats fruit, and on account of the softness of its body it can climb trees;
tgt_text.5126: it also overturns hives and eats the honey, and it feeds upon crabs and ants, and is car­ nivorous, for its strength enables it to attack not only deer, but wild hogs, if it can fall upon them secretly, and oxen.
tgt_text.5127: For when it meets the bull face to face, it falls upon its back, and when the bull attempts to throw it, seizes its horns with its fore-legs, and biting upon the shoulder of the bull, throws it down.
tgt_text.5128: For a short time it can walk upright on its hind legs.
tgt_text.5129: It eats flesh after it has become putrid.
tgt_text.5131: The lion, like all other wild animals with pointed teeth, is carnivorous;
tgt_text.5132: it devours its food greedily, and swallows large pieces without dividing them ;
tgt_text.5133: it can afterwards, from its repletion, remain two or three days without food.
tgt_text.5135: Its excrement is small, and is not made more than once in three days or thereabouts, and it is dry and hard like that of a dog.
tgt_text.5136: The wind from its bowels has an acrid smell, and its urine is powerfully scented, for which reason dogs smell to trees, for the lion, like the dog, lifts its leg to make water.
tgt_text.5137: It produces also a strong smell when it breathes upon its food, and when its bowels are laid open they emit a strong scent.
tgt_text.5139: Some quadrupeds and wild animals seek their food in the neighbourhood of ponds and rivers, but none of them except the seal live near the sea;
tgt_text.5140: of this class are the crea­ ture called beaver, and the satherium, the satyrium, the otter, and that which is called latax.
tgt_text.5141: This creature is broader than the enydris, and has strong teeth, for it often goes out in the night and with its teeth gnaws off the osiers.
tgt_text.5142: The enydris also will bite men, and they say will not leave its hold till it hears the noise of its teeth against the bone.
tgt_text.5143: The latax has rough hair, the nature of which is between that of the seal and that of the deer.
tgt_text.5144: 1. ANIMALS with pointed teeth drink by lapping, and some that have not pointed teeth, as mice.
tgt_text.5145: Those which have an even surface to their teeth draw in the water as horses and oxen ;
tgt_text.5146: the bear neither draws in the water nor laps it, but gulps it down.
tgt_text.5147: Some birds draw in the water, but those which have long necks imbibe it at intervals, lifting up their heads;
tgt_text.5148: the porphyrion alone gulps it down.
tgt_text.5149: All horned animals, both domestic and wild, and those that have not pointed teeth eat fruits and grass, and are incapable of en­ during hunger, except the dog, and this animal eats fruit and grass less than any other.
tgt_text.5151: The hog eats roots more than other animals, because its snout is well adapted for this operation, it is more adapted to various kinds of food than other animals.
tgt_text.5152: In proportion to its size its fat is developed very fast, for it be­ comes fat in sixty days.
tgt_text.5153: Those who occupy themselves in fatting hogs know how fast they fatten by weighing them when lean;
tgt_text.5154: they will become fat after starvation for three days.
tgt_text.5155: Almost all other animals become fat, after previous starvation.
tgt_text.5156: After three days those who fatten hogs feed them well.
tgt_text.5158: The Thracians fatten them by giving them drink on the first day, then at first they omit one day, afterwards two, three, or four, till they reach to seven days.
tgt_text.5159: These creatures are fattened with barley, millet, figs, acorns, wild pears, and cucumbers.
tgt_text.5160: Both this and other animals with a warm stomach are fattened in idleness, and the sow also by wal­ lowing in the mire.
tgt_text.5161: They prefer different kinds of food at different ages.
tgt_text.5162: The hog and the wolf fight together, a sixth part of its weight when alive, consists of bristles, blood, and fat.
tgt_text.5163: Sows andall other animals grow lean while suckling their young.
tgt_text.5164: This then, is the nature of these animals.
tgt_text.5165: 1. OXEN eat both fruits and grass.
tgt_text.5166: They become fat on flatulent food, as vetches, broken beans, and stems of beans, and if any person having cut a hole in the skin inflates them and then feeds the older cattle, they fatten more rapidly, and either on whole or broken barley, or on sweet food, as on figs and grapes, wine, and the leaves of the elm, and especially in the sunshine and in warm waters.
tgt_text.5167: The horns of the calf, if anointed with wax, may be directed in any way that is de­ sired, and they suffer less in the feet if their horns are rubbed with wax, or pitch, or oil.
tgt_text.5169: Herds of cattle suffer less when moved in frost than in snow, They grow if they are deprived for a long time of sexual intercourse ;
tgt_text.5170: wherefore the herdsmen in Epirus keep the Pyrrhic cattle, as they are called, for nine years without sexual intercourse, in order that they may grow.
tgt_text.5172: The number of these crea­ tures reaches four hundred, and they are the property of the king.
tgt_text.5173: They will not live in any other country, though the attempt has been made:
tgt_text.5175: THE horse, mule, and ass feed upon fruit and grass, but they fatten especially on drinking, so that beasts of burden enjoy their food in proportion to the quantity of water which they drink, and the less difficulty there is of obtain­ ing drink, the more they profit by abundance of grass.
tgt_text.5176: When the mare is in foal, green food causes her hair to be fine, but when it contains hard knots it is not wholesome.
tgt_text.5177: The first crop of Medic grass is not good, nor if any stinking water has come near it, for it gives it a bad smell.
tgt_text.5178: Oxen require pure water to drink, but horses in this respect re­ semble camels.
tgt_text.5179: The camel prefers water that is dirty and thick;
tgt_text.5180: nor will it drink from a stream before it has dis­ turbed the water.
tgt_text.5181: It can remain without drinking four days, after which it drinks a great quantity.
tgt_text.5183: THE elephant can eat more than nine Macedonian me­ dimni at one meal, but so much food at once is dangerous;
tgt_text.5184: it should not have altogether more than six or seven me­ dimni, or five medimni of bread, and five mares of wine, the marls measures six cotylæ.
tgt_text.5185: An elephant has been known to drink as much as fourteen Macedonian measures at once, and eight more again in the evening.
tgt_text.5186: Many camels live thirty years, and some much more, for they have been known to live an hundred years.
tgt_text.5187: Some say that the elephant lives two hundred, and others three hundred years.
tgt_text.5188: 1. SHEEP and goats live upon grass.
tgt_text.5189: Sheep pasture for a. long while in one place without leaving it, but goats change their places very soon, and only crop the top of the grass.
tgt_text.5190: The sheep fatten rapidly with drinking, and for this reason during summer they give them salt, a medimnus to each hun­ dred sheep ;
tgt_text.5191: for in this manner the flock becomes more healthy and fat, and frequently they collect and bring them together for this purpose, that they may mix a great deal of salt with their food;
tgt_text.5192: for when thirsty they drink the more.
tgt_text.5193: And in the autumn they feed them with gourds which they have sprinkled with salt, for this makes them give more milk.
tgt_text.5194: When driven about in the heat of the day they drink more towards evening.
tgt_text.5195: If fed with salt after parturition, the udder becomes larger.
tgt_text.5197: Sheep fatten on green shoots, vetches, and all kinds of grass, and they fatten more rapidly when their food is salted.
tgt_text.5198: They fatten more rapidly if previously starved for three days.
tgt_text.5199: During autumn northern water is better for sheep than southern, and pastures towards the west are good for them.
tgt_text.5200: Long journeys and weariness make them lean.
tgt_text.5201: Shepherds distinguish the strong sheep during winter by the frost adhering to their wool, which is not the case with those that are sick;
tgt_text.5202: for those that are not strong move about in their weakness and shake it off.
tgt_text.5204: The flesh of all quadrupeds which feed in marshy grounds is inferior to that of those which live on high ground.
tgt_text.5205: Sheep with wide tails endure the winter better than those with long tails, and short woolled-sheep better than long-woolled, and those with curly wool are more affected by the cold.
tgt_text.5206: Sheep are more healthy than goats, though goats are the stronger.
tgt_text.5207: The fleece and the wool of sheep which have been devoured by wolves, and garments made of such wool are more subject to vermin than others.
tgt_text.5209: THOSE insects which have teeth are omnivorous, but those which have a tongue only live upon fluids, which they collect from all sources with this organ.
tgt_text.5210: Some of these are omni­ vorous, for they feed upon all kinds of fluids, as the fly.
tgt_text.5211: Others only suck blood, as the myops and oestrus.
tgt_text.5212: Others, again, live upon the juices of plants and fruit.
tgt_text.5213: The bee is the only insect that never touches anything putrid.
tgt_text.5214: It uses no food that has not a sweet taste.
tgt_text.5215: They also take very sweet water, wherever they fall upon any that is pure.
tgt_text.5216: The different kinds of animals then use these kinds of food.1.
tgt_text.5217: ALL the actions of animals are employed either in sexual intercourse, or in rearing their young, or in procuring food for themselves, or in providing against excessive heat and cold, and the changes of the seasons.
tgt_text.5218: For they all have naturally a sensitiveness respecting heat and cold, and, like mankind, who either change their abodes in cold weather, or those who have large estates, pass their summer in cold countries and their winter in warm ones;
tgt_text.5219: so animals, also, if they can, migrate from place to place.
tgt_text.5220: Some of them find protection in their accustomed localities, others are migra­ tory ;
tgt_text.5221: and at the autumnal equinox, escape at the approach of winter, from the Pontus and other cold places;
tgt_text.5222: and in spring retreat again before the approach of summer from hot to cold countries, for they are afraid of excessive heat.
tgt_text.5223: Some migrate from places close at hand, and others from the very ends of the.
tgt_text.5225: The cranes do this, for they travel from Scythia to the marshes in the higher parts of Egypt, from which the Nile originates.
tgt_text.5226: This is the place where the Pygmies dwell;
tgt_text.5227: and this is no fable, for there is really, as it is said, a race of dwarfs, both men and horses, which lead the life of troglo­ dites.
tgt_text.5228: The pelicans also are migratory, and leave the river Strymon for the Ister, where they rear their young.
tgt_text.5229: They depart in great crowds, and those that are before wait for those behind, for in flying over the mountains those behind cannot see the leaders. '3.
tgt_text.5230: The fish also, in the same manner, migrate either from or to the Pontus, and in winter they leave the deep water for the sake of the warmth of the shore, and in summer they escape from the heat by migrating from the shore into deep water.
tgt_text.5231: Delicate birds, also, in winter and frosty wea­ ther, descend from the mountains to the plains, for the sake of the warmth ;
tgt_text.5232: and in summer they return again to the mountains for fear of the heat.
tgt_text.5234: Those that are the most delicate are the first to make the change at each extreme of heat and cold, such as the mackerel migrate sooner than the tunnies, and the quails than cranes ;
tgt_text.5235: for some migrate in August, others in September.
tgt_text.5236: They are always fatter when they migrate from cold coun­ tries, than when they leave warm countries, as the quail is more fat in the autumn than the spring :
tgt_text.5237: and so it happens that they migrate alike from cold countries and from warm seasons.
tgt_text.5238: Their sexual desires are also more violent in the spring, and when they leave warm countries.
tgt_text.5240: Among birds, as it was previously remarked, the crane migrates from one extremity of the earth to the other, and they fly against the wind.
tgt_text.5241: As for the story about the stone, it is a fiction, for they say that they carry a stone as ballast, which is useful as a touchstone for gold, after they have vomited it up.
tgt_text.5242: The phatta and the peleias leave us, and do not win­ ter with us, nor does the turtle;
tgt_text.5243: but the pigeon stays through the winter
tgt_text.5244: The same is the nature of the quail, unless a few individuals both of the turtle and quail remain behind in sunny spots.
tgt_text.5245: The phatta and turtle assemble in large flocks when they depart, and again at the season of their return.
tgt_text.5246: The quails, when they commence their flight, if the weather is fine and the wind in the north, go in pairs, and have a successful voyage.
tgt_text.5247: If the wind is south it goes hard with them, for their flight is slow, and this wind is moist and heavy.
tgt_text.5248: Those that hunt them, therefore, pursue them when the wind is in the south, but not in fine weather.
tgt_text.5249: They fly badly on account of their weight, for their body is large.
tgt_text.5250: They therefore make a noise as they fly, for it is a toil to them.
tgt_text.5252: When they come hither they have no leader, but when they depart hence, the glottis, ortygometra, otus, and cy­ chramus, which calls them together at night, accompany them;
tgt_text.5253: and when the fowlers hear this sound, they know!
tgt_text.5255: The ortygometra in form resem­ bles the birds which inhabit marshes.
tgt_text.5257: tongue which it projects to a great length.
tgt_text.5258: The otus resem­ bles an owl, and has small feathers at its ears.
tgt_text.5259: Some per­ sons call it the nycticorax, it is mischievous and imitative, it is taken like the owl, as it dances from side to side, one or other of the fowlers compassing it about.
tgt_text.5260: On the whole, birds with crooked claws have short necks, broad tongues, and a, capacity for imitation.
tgt_text.5261: And so has the Indian bird, the parrot, which is said to have a tongue like a man.
tgt_text.5262: H becomes the most loquacious when intoxicated.
tgt_text.5263: The crow, the swan, the pelican, and the small goose, are gregarious birds.
tgt_text.5265: IT has already been observed that fish migrate from the deep water to the coast, and from the coast to the deep water, in order to avoid the excesses of cold and heat.
tgt_text.5266: Those that frequent the neighbourhood of the coast are better than those from deep water, for the feeding grounds are better and more abundant.
tgt_text.5267: For wherever the sun strikes the plants are more frequent, and superior, and more delicate, as in gar­ dens, and the black shore-weed grows near the land, and the other kinds rather resemble uncultivated plants.
tgt_text.5268: The neigh­ bourhood of the coast is also more temperate, both in heat and cold, than the rest of the sea;
tgt_text.5269: for which reason the flesh of fish which live near the shore is more compact, while that of fish from deep sea is watery and soft.
tgt_text.5270: The sinodon, cantha­ rus, orphos, chrysophrys, cestreus, trigla, cichla, dracon, calli­ onymus, cobius, and all the rock fish live near the shore.
tgt_text.5271: The trygon, selache, the white congers, the channa, erythrinus, and glaucus inhabit deep water.
tgt_text.5272: The phagrus, scorpius, the black conger, the muræna, and coccyx occupy either situa­ tion indifferently.
tgt_text.5274: They vary also in different places;
tgt_text.5275: as in the neighbour­ hood of Crete the cobius and all the rock fish are fat.
tgt_text.5276: The tunny also becomes good again after Arcturus, for it is not tormented by the oestrus after that period;
tgt_text.5277: for which reason also it is inferior during the summer.
tgt_text.5278: In lakes near the sea also there are several kinds of fish, as the salpa, chrysophrys,­ trigla, and nearly all the rest.
tgt_text.5279: The amia also is found in such situations as in the vicinity of Alopeconnesus, and in the lake of Bistonis there are many fish.
tgt_text.5280: Many of the coliæ do not enter the Pontus;
tgt_text.5281: but they pass the summer and rear their young in the Propontis, and winter in the Ægean.
tgt_text.5282: The thynnus, pelamis, and amia enter the Pontus in the spring and pass the summer there, and so do nearly all the rhyades and the gregarious fish.
tgt_text.5283: Many fish are gregarious, and gregarious fish have a leader of the shoal.
tgt_text.5285: They all enter the Pontus for the sake of the food (for the pasture is more abundant and superior, on account of the fresh water), and for fear of the large creatures, which are smaller there;
tgt_text.5286: and except the phocona and dol­ phin, there is no other found in the Pontus;
tgt_text.5287: and the dolphin is small, but when we leave the Pontus we find a larger dolphin.
tgt_text.5288: They enter this sea for the sake of food and rear­ ing their young;
tgt_text.5289: for the situation is better for this purpose, and the fresh sweet water nourishes the young fry.
tgt_text.5290: When they have reared their young, and the fry begin to grow, they migrate immediately after the Pleiades.
tgt_text.5291: If the south wind-blow during the winter, they leave the place more;
tgt_text.5293: but with a north wind they swim faster, for then the wind helps them along.
tgt_text.5294: The small fry is captured in the.
tgt_text.5295: neighbourhood of Byzantium, for they make no long stay in the Pontus.4.
tgt_text.5296: The other fish are seen both in their egress and ingress.
tgt_text.5297: The trichia is only seen as it enters, and is not observed, to leave again;
tgt_text.5298: and if one is captured at Byzantium, the fisher­ men purify their nets, for it is unusual for them to return.
tgt_text.5300: these are the only fish that swim up into the Ister, and when this river divides they swim down into the Adriatic.
tgt_text.5302: for the converse happens here, and they are never captured entering the Adriatic, but as they leave it.
tgt_text.5304: The tunnies, as they enter, swim with their right side to the shore, and leave with their left side to the shore;
tgt_text.5305: and some persons say that they do this because they see better with their right eye, and their sight is naturally dim.
tgt_text.5306: The rhyades move during the day, and in the night remain quiet and feed, unless the moon is bright, in which-case they con­ tinue their journey and do not rest themselves.
tgt_text.5307: And some persons engaged about the sea say that after the winter solstice they do not move, but remain quiet wherever they may be till the equinox.
tgt_text.5309: The coliæ are taken as they enter, but not as they return.
tgt_text.5310: The best are taken in the Propontis before the breeding season.
tgt_text.5311: The other rhyades are captured more frequently as they leave the Pontus, and are then in perfect tion.
tgt_text.5312: Those that swim near the shore are the fattest when captured;
tgt_text.5313: and the farther they are away, the more lean they if are;
tgt_text.5314: and frequently, when the south wind blows, they swim out in company with the coliæ and mackerel, and are taken lower down rather than at Byzantium.
tgt_text.5315: This is the nature of their migrations.
tgt_text.5316: 1. LAND animals have also the same disposition for con­ cealment.
tgt_text.5317: For in winter they all hasten to conceal them­ selves, and appear again when the season becomes warmer.
tgt_text.5318: Animals conceal themselves to guard against the excesses of temperature.
tgt_text.5319: In some the whole race is concealed ;
tgt_text.5320: in others only a part of them.
tgt_text.5321: All the testacea conceal them­ selves, as those which are marine, the purpura, whelk, and all that class;
tgt_text.5322: but the state of concealment is more con.
tgt_text.5323: spicuous in those which do not adhere to rocks ;
tgt_text.5324: for these also conceal themselves, as the pectens.
tgt_text.5325: Some have an operculum on their exterior, as the land snails;
tgt_text.5326: and the alteration of those that are not free is inconspicuous.
tgt_text.5327: They do not all conceal themselves at the same period ;
tgt_text.5328: for the snails are torpid during the winter, the purpura and whelk for thirty days under the dog star, and the pectens at the same period.
tgt_text.5329: Most of them conceal themselves in very cold and very hot weather.
