tgt_text.5330: 2. Almost all insects become torpid, except those which dwell in the habitations of men, and those that perish and do not survive for a year.
tgt_text.5331: They are torpid in the winter.
tgt_text.5332: Some conceal themselves for a good while, others only in the coldest days, as the bees, for these also conceal them­ selves.
tgt_text.5333: This is shown by their not touching the food which is prepared for them;
tgt_text.5334: and if any of them creep out, they appear transparent, and plainly have nothing in their sto­ mach.
tgt_text.5335: They remain at rest from the setting of the Pleiades until the spring.
tgt_text.5336: Animals pass their torpid state in warm places, and in the spots they are accustomed to inhabit.
tgt_text.5338: MANY sanguineous animals become torpid, as those which are furnished with scales, the serpent, lizard, gecko, and the river crocodile, during the four winter months in which they eat nothing.
tgt_text.5339: Other serpents conceal themselves in the earth, but the viper lies hidden among stones.
tgt_text.5340: Many fish also become torpid, especially the hippurus and coracirius during the winter;
tgt_text.5341: for these alone are never taken but at certain seasons, which never vary.
tgt_text.5342: Almost all the rest an taken at all seasons.
tgt_text.5343: The lamprey, orphus, and conger con ceal themselves.
tgt_text.5344: The rock fish conceal themselves in pairs as the cichla, cottyphus, and perea, the male with the female in which way also they prepare for their young.
tgt_text.5346: The tunny conceals itself during winter in deep places, and they become fattest at this season.
tgt_text.5347: The season of capturing them commences with the rising of Pleiades and continues to the end of the setting of Arcturus.
tgt_text.5348: All the rest of their time they remain quiet in concealment.
tgt_text.5349: few of these are taken during the period of their concealment and so are some other hybernating creatures, if they are disturbed by the warmth of their abode or the unusual mildness of the season.
tgt_text.5350: For they come out a little from their holes to feed, and also when the moon is full.
tgt_text.5351: Most fish are better tasted during the period of concealment.
tgt_text.5352: The primades bury themselves in the mud.
tgt_text.5353: This is shown by their not being taken, or their seeming to have a great deal of mud on their backs and their fins pressed down.
tgt_text.5355: In spring, however, they begin to move and come to the shore to copulate and deposit their ova.
tgt_text.5356: At this season they are captured full of ova, and then also they appear to be in season, but are not so good in autumn and winter.
tgt_text.5357: At the same season also the males appear to be full of melt.
tgt_text.5358: When their ova are small they are taken with diffi­ culty;
tgt_text.5359: but as they grow larger many are taken when they are infested by the oestrus.
tgt_text.5360: Some fish bury themselves in sand, others in mud, with only their mouths above the surface.
tgt_text.5361: Fishes usually conceal themselves only in the winter.
tgt_text.5362: The malacostraca, the rock fishes, the batus, and selache only in, the most severe weather.
tgt_text.5363: This is shown by the difficulty of capturing them in cold weather.
tgt_text.5365: Some fish, as the glaucus, conceal themselves in sum­ mer time;
tgt_text.5366: for this fish hides itself for sixty days in the summer time.
tgt_text.5367: The onus and the chrysophrys hide them­ selves.
tgt_text.5368: The reason for supposing that the onus hides itself for a long while appears to be that it is captured at long intervals;
tgt_text.5369: and the influence of the stars upon them;
tgt_text.5370: and especially of the dog-star, appears to be the cause of their hiding themselves in summer time, for the sea is then dis­ turbed.
tgt_text.5371: This is most conspicuous in the Bosphorus ;
tgt_text.5372: for the mud is thrown up, and the fish are thus brought to the surface;
tgt_text.5373: and they say that, when the bottom is disturbed, more fish are often taken in the same cast the second than the first time;
tgt_text.5374: and after much rain animals make their appearance which before were either not seen at all or but seldom.
tgt_text.5376: MANY kinds of birds also conceal themselves, and they do not all, as some suppose, migrate to warmer climates;
tgt_text.5377: but those which are near the places of which they are permanent inhabitants, as the kite and swallow, migrate thither;
tgt_text.5378: but those that are farther off from such places do not migrate, but conceal themselves;
tgt_text.5379: and many swallows have been seen in hollow places almost stripped of feathers;
tgt_text.5380: and kites, when they first showed themselves, have come from similar situations.
tgt_text.5381: Birds with crooked claws, and those also with straight claws, conceal themselves indiscri­ minately ;
tgt_text.5382: for the stork, blackbird,1 turtle dove, and lark hide themselves, and by general agreement the turtle dove most of all, for no one is ever said to have seen one during the winter.
tgt_text.5383: At the commencement of hybernation it is very fat, and during that season it loses its feathers, though they remain thick for a long while.
tgt_text.5384: Some of the doves conceal themselves;
tgt_text.5385: others do not, but migrate along with the swal­ lows.
tgt_text.5386: The thrush and the starling also conceal themselves, and among birds with crooked claws the kite and, the owl are not seen for a few days.
tgt_text.5388: AMONG viviparous quadrupeds the porcupines and bears hybernate.
tgt_text.5389: It is evident that the wild bears conceal them­ selves ;
tgt_text.5390: but there is some doubt whether it is on account of the cold or from any other cause, for at this season both the males and females are so fat that they cannot move easily.
tgt_text.5391: The female also produces her young at this season, and hides herself until the cubs are of an age to be led forth.
tgt_text.5392: This she does in the spring, about three months after the solstice, and she continues invisible for at least forty days.
tgt_text.5393: During fourteen days of this period they say that she does not move at all.
tgt_text.5394: For more than this period afterwards she remains invisible, but moves about and is awake.
tgt_text.5395: A pregnant bear has either never or very rarely been captured;
tgt_text.5396: and it is quite plain that they eat nothing during the whole of this period;
tgt_text.5398: and if they are captured, their stomach and entrails appear to be empty;
tgt_text.5399: and it is said that, because nothing is presented to it, the intestine sometimes adheres to itself;
tgt_text.5400: and, therefore, at their first emergence, they eat the arum, in order to open the entrail and make a passage through it.
tgt_text.5402: The dormouse hvbernates in trees and is then very fat, and the white Pontic mouse.
tgt_text.5403: (Some hybernating animals cast their old age, as it is called.
tgt_text.5404: This is the outer skin and the coverings at the period of birth.)
tgt_text.5405: It has al­ ready been observed, that among viviparous animals with feet there is some doubt as to the cause of the hybernation of bears;
tgt_text.5406: but almost all animals with scales hybernate and cast their old age;
tgt_text.5407: that is, all that have a soft skin and no shell, as the tortoise;
tgt_text.5408: for both the tortoise and the emvs belong to the class of animals with scales;
tgt_text.5409: but all such as the gecko, lizard, and especially the serpents, cast their skins ;
tgt_text.5410: for they do this both in the spring, when they first emerge, and again in the autumn.
tgt_text.5412: The viper also casts its skin both in the spring and autumn, and is not, as some persons say, the only serpent that does not cast its skin.
tgt_text.5413: When serpents begin to cast their skin, it is first of all separated from their eyes ;
tgt_text.5414: and to those who do not know what is about to happen they appear to be blind.
tgt_text.5415: After this it is separated from the head, for first of all it appears entirely white.
tgt_text.5416: In a night and day the whole of the old skin is separated from the commence­ ment at the head to the tail;
tgt_text.5417: and when cast it is turned in­ side out, for the serpent emerges as the infant does from the chorion.
tgt_text.5419: Insects which cast their skins do it in the same way as the silpha, empis, and the coleoptera, as the beetle.
tgt_text.5420: All creatures cast it after birth;
tgt_text.5421: for in viviparous animals the chorion is separated, and in the vermiparous, as bees and locusts, they emerge from a case.
tgt_text.5422: The grasshoppers, when they cast their skins, sit upon olives and reeds.
tgt_text.5423: When the case is ruptured, they emerge, and leave a little fluid behind them, and after a short time they fly away and sing.
tgt_text.5425: Among marine creatures the carabi and astaci cast their skins either in spring or autumn, after having depo­ sited their ova;
tgt_text.5426: and carabi have been sometimes taken with a soft thorax, because their shell was ruptured, while the lower part, which was not ruptured, was hard.
tgt_text.5427: For the process is not the same in them as in serpents.
tgt_text.5428: The carabi remain in concealment for about five months.
tgt_text.5429: The crabs also cast their old skin, certainly those which have soft shells;
tgt_text.5430: and they say that those which have hard shells do the same, as the maia and graus.
tgt_text.5431: When they have cast their shells, the new shells are first of all soft, and the crabs are unable to walk.
tgt_text.5432: They do not cast their skins once only, but frequently.
tgt_text.5433: I have now described when and how animals conceal themselves, and what creatures cast their skin, and when they do so.1.
tgt_text.5434: ANIMALS are not all in good health at the same season, nor in the same degrees of heat and cold.
tgt_text.5435: Their health and diseases are different at different seasons in various classes, and on the whole are not alike in all.
tgt_text.5436: Dry weather agrees with birds, both in respect of their general health and the rearing of their young, and especially with pigeons;
tgt_text.5437: and wet weather, with few exceptions, agrees with fish.
tgt_text.5438: On the con­ trary, showery weather generally disagrees with birds, and dry weather with fish;
tgt_text.5439: for, on the whole, abundance of drink does not agree with birds.
tgt_text.5441: For the birds with crooked claws, generally speaking, as it was before remarked, do not drink.
tgt_text.5442: But Hesiod was ignorant of this circumstance;
tgt_text.5443: for in relating the siege of Nineveh he represents the presiding eagle of the' augury drinking.
tgt_text.5444: Other birds drink, but not much;
tgt_text.5445: neither do any other oviparous animals with spongy lungs.
tgt_text.5446: The sickness of birds is manifest in their plumage;
tgt_text.5447: for it is uneven, and­ has not the same smoothness as when they are well.
tgt_text.5449: The generality of fish, as it was observed, thrive the most in rainy years;
tgt_text.5450: for not only in such seasons do they obtain a greater supply of food, but the wet weather agrees with them as with the plants that grow on land;
tgt_text.5451: for potherbs, even if watered, do not grow so well as in wet weather.
tgt_text.5452: The same is the case with the reeds that grow in ponds;
tgt_text.5453: for they never grow, as we may say, except in rainy weather.
tgt_text.5455: And this is the reason why so many fish migrate every summer into the Pontus;
tgt_text.5456: for the number of rivers which flow into it render the water fresh, and also bring down a supply of food, and many fish also ascend the rivers, and flourish in the rivers and lakes, as the amia and mullet.
tgt_text.5457: The cobii also become fat in the rivers;
tgt_text.5458: and on the whole, those places which have the largest lakes furnish the most excellent fish.
tgt_text.5460: Of all kinds of water, summer showers agree best with fish ;
tgt_text.5461: and if the spring, summer, and autumn have been wet, a fine winter.
tgt_text.5462: And to speak generally, if the season is healthy for mankind, it will be the same for fish.
tgt_text.5463: They do not thrive in cold places.
tgt_text.5464: Those which have a stone in their head, as the chromis, labrax, scioena, and phagrus, suffer most in the winter;
tgt_text.5465: for the refrigeration of the stone causes them to freeze and be driven on shore.
tgt_text.5467: Abundant rain confers health on most fish;
tgt_text.5468: but the contrary is the case with the mullet and cephalus, which some call marinus;
tgt_text.5469: for if there is a great supply of rain water, they soon become blind.
tgt_text.5470: The cephali are particu­ larly liable to this disease in the winter;
tgt_text.5472: When captured they are lean, and at last perish altogether.
tgt_text.5473: They do not, however, appear to suffer so much from the wet as from the cold;
tgt_text.5474: for in other places, and especially in the swamps in the neighbourhood of the Argive Nauplia, many are found blind in severe weather, and many also are taken with white eyes.
tgt_text.5476: The chrysophrys also suffers from the cold;
tgt_text.5477: the arach­ nas from the heat, which makes it lean.
tgt_text.5478: Dry seasons agree better with the coracinus than with any other fish, and for this reason, because it is generally warm in dry weather.
tgt_text.5479: Particular localities are favourable to different species, as either the neighbourhood of the land, or the deep waters to those which only frequent one of these localities, or parti­ cular places to those which frequent both.
tgt_text.5480: There are especial places in which each of them thrive;
tgt_text.5481: but, gene­ rally speaking, they prefer places full of sea weed;
tgt_text.5482: for those which inhabit places with plenty of food are generally found to be fatter;
tgt_text.5483: for those that eat fuel obtain plenty of food, while those that are carnivorous find an abundant supply of fish.
tgt_text.5485: They are also affected by northern and southern aspects, for the long fish thrive best in northern situations, and in northern places in the summer time more long fish than flat fish are taken in the same locality.
tgt_text.5486: The tunny and xiphia suffer from the oestrus, at the rising of the dog- star, for both these fish at this season have beneath their fins a little worm which is called oestrus, which resembles a scorpion, and is about the size of a spider;
tgt_text.5487: they suffer so much from this torment that the xiphias leaps out of the sea as high as the dolphin, and in this manner frequently falls upon ships.
tgt_text.5489: The tunny delights in warm weather more than any other fish, and they resort to the sand near the sea-shore for the sake of the warmth, and there they float on the surface ;
tgt_text.5490: the small fish are safe because they are overlooked, for large fish pursue those of a moderate size.
tgt_text.5491: The greater-portion of the ova and melt are destroyed ..... by the heat, for whatever they touch they entirely destroy.
tgt_text.5493: The greatest number of fish are taken before sunrise and after sunset, or just about sunrise and sunset, for the casts made at this period are called seasonable.
tgt_text.5494: For this reason the fishermen take up their nets at this time, for the sight of the fish is then most readily deceived.
tgt_text.5495: During the night they remain quiet, and at mid-day, when the light is strong, they see very well.
tgt_text.5496: 11. Fish do not appear to be subject to any of those pesti­ lential diseases which so often occur among men and quad­ rupeds, as the horse and ox, and other animals, both domestic and wild.
tgt_text.5497: They appear, however, to suffer from ill health, and the fishermen consider that this is proved by the capture of some lean, and apparently weak individuals, and others that have lost their colour, among a number of fat ones of the same kind.
tgt_text.5498: This is the nature of sea-fish.
tgt_text.5500: No pestilential disease attacks river and pond fish, though some of them are subject to peculiar diseases, as the glanis, from its swimming near the surface, appears to be star-struck by the dog-star, and it is stupefied by loud thunder.
tgt_text.5501: The carp suffers in the same way, but not so severely.
tgt_text.5502: The glanis, in shallow water, is often destroyed by the dragon-serpent.
tgt_text.5503: In the ballerus and tilon a worm is produced, under the influence of the dog-star, which makes them rise to the surface and become weak, and when they come to the surface they are killed by the heat;
tgt_text.5504: a violent dis­ ease attacks the chalcis, which is destroyed by a number of lice, which are produced under its gills;
tgt_text.5505: no other fish appear to be subject to such a disease.
tgt_text.5507: Fishes are poisoned with the plant called mullein, for which reason some persons capture them by poisoning the waters of rivers and ponds;
tgt_text.5508: and thePhoenicians poison the sea in the same way.
tgt_text.5509: There are two other plans which are adopted for the capture of fish;
tgt_text.5510: for since fish avoid the deep parts of rivers in cold weather (for even otherwise the river water is cold), they dig a ditch through the land to the river, which they cover over with grass and stones so as to resemble a cave, with one opening from the river, and when the frost comes on they capture the fish with a basket.
tgt_text.5511: The other mode of fishingis practised both in summer and winter.
tgt_text.5512: In the middle of the stream they raise a structure with faggots and stones, leaving one part open for a mouth;
tgt_text.5513: in this a basket is placed, with which they catch the fish, as they take away the stones.
tgt_text.5514: 14. Rainy years agree with all the testacea except the pur­ pura;
tgt_text.5515: this is a proof of it, if placed near the mouth of a river, they take the fresh water, and die the same day.
tgt_text.5516: The purpura will live about fifty days after it has been taken.
tgt_text.5517: They are nourished by each other, for a plant like a fucus or moss grows upon their shells.
tgt_text.5518: They say that whatever is cast to them for food is done for the sake of weight, that they may weigh the more.
tgt_text.5519: 15. Dry weather is injurious to other testacea, for it renders them fewer in quantity and inferior in quality, and the pectens become more red.
tgt_text.5520: In the Pyrrhæan Euripus the pec­ tens perish, not only from the instrument with which the fishermen scrape them together, but also from dry weather.
tgt_text.5521: The other testacea thrive in wet weather, because it makes the sea-water fresher.
tgt_text.5522: The cold of the Pontus and of the rivers that flow into it renders bivalve shells rare.
tgt_text.5523: The uni­ valves, however, are frozen in cold weather.
tgt_text.5524: This is the nature of aquatic animals.
tgt_text.5526: AMONG quadrupeds, swine suffer from three diseases, one of these is called sore throat, in which the parts above the jaws and the branchia become inflamed;
tgt_text.5527: it may also occur in other parts of the body, and frequently seizes upon the foot, and sometimes the ear.
tgt_text.5528: The neighbouring parts then be­ come putrid, until it reaches the lungs, when the animal dies ;
tgt_text.5529: the disease spreads rapidly, and the animal eats nothing from the period of the commencement of the disease, be it where it will.
tgt_text.5530: The swineherds have no other remedy but the excision of the part before the disease has spread far.
tgt_text.5532: There are two other diseases which are both called craura.
tgt_text.5533: One of them consists in a pain and weight in the head, with which many of them are afflicted ;
tgt_text.5534: the other is an excessive alvine discharge.
tgt_text.5536: They relieve the former by the application of wine to the nostrils, and washing them with wine.
tgt_text.5537: Recovery from this disease is difficult, for it generally carries them off on the third or fourth day.
tgt_text.5539: They suffer particularly from sore throat, when the summer bears abundantly, and they are fat.
tgt_text.5540: The fruit of the mulberry is good for them, and abundant washings with warm water, and scarification beneath the tongue.
tgt_text.5541: If the flesh of swine is soft, it is full of small lumps (chalazæ) about the legs, neck, and shoulders;
tgt_text.5542: for in these parts the chalazæ are most frequent.
tgt_text.5543: If there are but a few, the flesh is sweet;
tgt_text.5544: if many, it becomes very fluid and soft.
tgt_text.5546: Those which have these chalazæ are easily distinguished;
tgt_text.5547: for they exist in the greatest numbers under the tongue, and if the hair is plucked from their mane it appears bloody underneath.
tgt_text.5548: Those which have chalazæ cannot keep their hind legs still.
tgt_text.5549: They are not thus affected as long as they suck.
tgt_text.5550: The grain called tipha, which also forms excel­ lent food, is the remedy for the chalazæ.
tgt_text.5551: Vetches and figs are useful both fcr fattening and rearing pigs;
tgt_text.5552: and on the whole their food should not be all of one sort, but varied ;
tgt_text.5553: for swine, like other animals, derive advantage from a change in their food ;
tgt_text.5554: and they say that at the same time their food ought to inflate them, and to cover them both with flesh and fat.
tgt_text.5555: Acorns are good for their food, but make their flesh watery;
tgt_text.5556: and if they eat too many while pregnant, they produce abortions, as sheep also do;
tgt_text.5557: for these animals evidently suffer this from eating acorns.
tgt_text.5558: The swine is the only creature that we know of which has chalazæ in its flesh.
tgt_text.5559: 1. DOGS suffer from these diseases which have received these names, lytta, cynanche, podagra.
tgt_text.5560: The lytta produces mad­ ness, and they infect every creature which they bite, except mankind, with the same disease.
tgt_text.5561: This disease is fatal to dogs and to any other animal they may bite except man.
tgt_text.5562: The cynanche also is fatal to dogs ;
tgt_text.5563: and there are compara­ tively few which recover from the podagra.
tgt_text.5564: Camels also are seized with lytta.
tgt_text.5565: (The elephant does not appear to suffer from any other infirmity except flatulency.)2. Gregarious oxen suffer from two diseases, one called podagra, the other craurus.
tgt_text.5567: but it is not fatal, nor do they lose their hoofs.
tgt_text.5568: They derive benefit from their horns being smeared with warm pitch.
tgt_text.5569: When attacked with craurus, their breathing becomes warm and thick.
tgt_text.5570: Fever in mankind is the same as craurus in cattle.
tgt_text.5571: It is a sign of this disease, when they hang down their ears and will not eat.
tgt_text.5572: It soon proves fatal, and when dissected, their lungs appear putrid.
tgt_text.5574: HOUSES when grazing are free from all diseases except podagra;
tgt_text.5575: from this they suffer, and sometimes lose their hoofs, which grow again as soon as they are lost, and the loss of the hoof usually takes place as soon as the first recom­ mences its growth.
tgt_text.5576: It is a sign of the disease when the right testicle throbs, or when a wrinkled hollow place appears a little below the middle of the nose.
tgt_text.5577: Horses that are brought up in a domestic state suffer from several other diseases;
tgt_text.5578: they are attacked with a disorder in their bowels, and it is a sign of the disease when they drag their hind legs up to their fore legs, and keep them under in such a way that they almost strike together:
tgt_text.5579: if they go mad after having ab­ stained from food for several days, they are relieved by bleeding and castration.
tgt_text.5580: 12. The tetanus is another disease of horses, which is thue recognised;
tgt_text.5581: all the veins, and the head and neck are extended, and their legs are stiff when they walk;
tgt_text.5582: the horses also become full of corrupt matter.
tgt_text.5583: They are also attacked by another disease in which they are said to have the crithia ;
tgt_text.5584: l the soft­ ness of the roof of the mouth, and heated breath, are the signs of this disease, which is incurable, unless it stays of its own accord.
tgt_text.5585: Another disease is called nymphia,2 which is relieved by the sound of a flute ;
tgt_text.5586: it causes them to hang down their heads, and when anyone mounts they rush for­ ward until they run against something.
tgt_text.5587: The horse is always dejected if afflicted with madness ;
tgt_text.5588: this is a sign of it, if it lays down its ears upon its mane, and then draws them forward, and pants and breathes hard.
tgt_text.5590: These also are incurable if the heart is affected.
tgt_text.5591: It is a sign of this disease if the animal suffers from relax­ ation.
tgt_text.5592: And if the bladder alters its position, difficulty in making water is a sign of this disease;
tgt_text.5593: it draws up the hoofs and loins.
tgt_text.5594: It is also fatal for the horse to swallow the sta­ philinus, which is of the same size as the spondyla.
tgt_text.5595: The bite of the shrew mouse is injurious to other animals also;
tgt_text.5596: it causes sores, which are more severe if the creature is preg­ nant when it bites, for the sores then break.
tgt_text.5597: If they are not pregnant, the animal does not perish.
tgt_text.5598: The creature called chalkis by some persons and zygnis by others, inflicts either a fatal or very painful bite.
tgt_text.5599: It resembles a small lizard, and is of the same colour as the serpent called the blind worm.
tgt_text.5601: And, on the whole, those who understand horses say that both these animals and sheep suffer from all the in­ firmities with whIch mankind is afflicted.
tgt_text.5602: The horse, and every other beast of burden, is destroyed by the poison of sandarach.
tgt_text.5604: It is dissolved in water and strained.
tgt_text.5605: The pregnant mare casts her young with the smell of a lamp going out.
tgt_text.5606: This also happens to some pregnant women.
tgt_text.5607: This is the nature of the diseases of horses.
tgt_text.5609: The hippomanes, as it is called, is said to be produced upon the foals ;
tgt_text.5610: the mares when they have bitten it off lick the foal and cleanse it.
tgt_text.5611: The fables on this subject have been in­ vented by women and charmers.
tgt_text.5612: It is, however, agreed that mares before parturition eject the substance called polion.
tgt_text.5614: Horses recognise again the voices of any with which they may have fought.'
tgt_text.5615: They delight in meadows and marshes, and drink dirty water;
tgt_text.5616: and if it is clean, they first disturb it with their hoof, and then drink and wash them­ selves.
tgt_text.5617: And on the whole, the horse is an animal fond of water, and still more fond of moisture ;
tgt_text.5618: wherefore, also, the nature of the river-horse is thus constituted.
tgt_text.5619: In this respect the ox is very different from the horse, for it will not drink unless the water is clean, cold, and unmixed.
tgt_text.5621: ASSES only suffer from one disease, which is called melis, which first attacks the head of the animal, and causes a thick and bloody phlegm to flow from the nostrils.
tgt_text.5622: If the disease extends to the lungs, it is fatal;
tgt_text.5623: but that which first attacks the head is not so.
tgt_text.5624: This animal cannot bear cold, for which reason there are no asses in the vicinity of the Pontus and in Scythia.1.
tgt_text.5625: ELEPHANTS suffer from flatulent diseases, for which reason they can neither evacuate their fluid or solid excre­ ments.
tgt_text.5626: If they eat earth they become weak, unless used to such food.
tgt_text.5627: If it is accustomed to it, it does no harm.
tgt_text.5630: When attacked with this complaint, they are cured by giving them warm water to drink, and hay dipped in honey to eat;
tgt_text.5631: and either of these remedies will stop the disease.
tgt_text.5632: When fatigued for want of sleep, they are cured by being rubbed on the shoulders with.
tgt_text.5633: salt and oil, and warm water.
tgt_text.5634: When they suffer from pain in the shoulders, they are relieved by the application of roasted swine's flesh.
tgt_text.5635: Some elephants will drink oil, and some will not;
tgt_text.5636: and if any iron weapon is - struck into their body, the oil which they drink assists in its expulsion;
tgt_text.5637: and to those which will not drink it, they give wine of rice cooked with oil.
tgt_text.5638: This, then, is the nature of quadrupeds.
tgt_text.5640: INSERTS generally thrive when the year is of the same kind as the season in which they were born, such as the spring, moist and warm.
tgt_text.5641: Certain creatures are produced in beehives, which destroy the combs, and a little spinning worm, which destroys the wax.
tgt_text.5642: It is called clerus, or by some persons pyraustes.
tgt_text.5643: This creature produces a spider­ like animal like itself, which causes sickness in the hive, and another creature like the moth, which flies round the candle.
tgt_text.5644: This produces a creature filled with a woolly sub­ stance.
tgt_text.5645: It is not killed by the bees, and is only driven out by smoking it.
tgt_text.5646: A kind of caterpillar also, which is called teredo, is produced in the hives.
tgt_text.5647: The bees do not drive it away.
tgt_text.5648: They suffer most from diseases when the woods produce flowers infected with rust, and in dry seasons.
tgt_text.5649: All insects die when plunged in oil, and most rapidly if their I head is oiled, and they are placed in the sun.1.
tgt_text.5650: ANIMALS also differ in their localities :
tgt_text.5651: for some are en­ tirely absent from some localities which exist in others, though small and shortlived, and not thriving.
tgt_text.5652: And fre­ quently there will be a great difference even in adjoining places, as the grasshopper is found in some parts of Milesia, and is absent from those in the immediate vicinity.
tgt_text.5653: And in Cephalenia a river divides the country, on one side of which the grasshopper is found, and not on the other.
tgt_text.5655: In Poroselene a road divides the country, on one side of which the weasel is found, and not on the other.
tgt_text.5656: In Boeotia there are many moles in the neighbourhood of Orchomenus, but in the adjoining Lebadian district there are none, nor if they are imported, are they willing to bar­ row.
tgt_text.5657: If hares are taken into Ithaca they will not live, but are seen dead on the sea coast, turned in the direction in which they were brought.
tgt_text.5658: In Sicily the hippomyrmex is not found, and in Cyrene there were formerly no croak­ in-, frogs.
tgt_text.5660: In all Libya there is neither wild boar, nor stag, nor wild goat.
tgt_text.5661: And in India, Ctesias, who is not worthy of credit, says, there are neither domestic nor wild swine ;
tgt_text.5662: but the exsanguineous and burrowing tribes are all large.
tgt_text.5663: In the Pontus there are no malacia, nor all the kinds of tes­ tacea, except in a few places ;
tgt_text.5664: but in the Red Sea all the testacea are of a great size.
tgt_text.5665: In Syria there are sheep with tails a cubit, in width, and the ears of the goats are a span and four lingers, and some of them bring their ears down to the ground:
tgt_text.5666: and the oxen, like the camels, have a mane upon the point of the shoulder.
tgt_text.5667: In Lycia the goats are shorn as the sheep are in other places.
tgt_text.5669: In Libya the homed rams are born at once with horns, and not the males only, as Homer says, but all the rest also.
tgt_text.5670: In the part of Scythia near the Pontus, the contrary is the case, for they are born without horns.
tgt_text.5671: And in Egypt some of the cattle, as the oxen and sheep, are larger than in Greece, and others are smaller, as the dogs, wolves, hares, foxes, ravens, and hawks.
tgt_text.5672: Others are nearly of the same ' size, as the crows and goats.
tgt_text.5673: This difference originates in the food which is abundant for some, and scarce for others.
tgt_text.5674: For the wolves, hawks, and carnivorous creatures food is scarce, for there are but few small birds.
tgt_text.5675: For the dasypus and others which are not carnivorous, neither the hard nor soft fruits are of any long continuance.
tgt_text.5677: The temperature is also very influential;
tgt_text.5678: for in Illy­ ria, Thrace, and Epirus, the asses are small.
tgt_text.5679: In Scythia, and Celtic countries, they do not occur at all, for in these places the winter is severe.
tgt_text.5680: In Arabia the lizards are more than a cubit long, and the mice are much larger than those which inhabit our fields, their fore legs being a span long, and their hind legs as long as from the first joint of the finger ....6.
tgt_text.5681: In Libya, the serpents, as it has been already remarked, are very large.
tgt_text.5682: For some persons say that as they sailed along the coast, they saw the bones of many oxen, and that it was evident to them that they had been devoured by the serpents.
tgt_text.5683: And as the ships passed on, the serpents attacked the triremes, and some of them threw themselves upon one of the triremes and overturned it.
tgt_text.5684: There are more lions in Europe, and especially in the country between the Ache­ lous and the Nessus.
tgt_text.5685: In Asia there are leopards which are not found in Europe.
tgt_text.5687: On the whole, the wild animals of Asia are the fiercest, those of Europe the boldest, and those of Libya the most varied in form ;
tgt_text.5688: and it has passed into a proverb that Libya is always producing something new.
tgt_text.5689: For the want of water brings many heterogeneous animals together at the drinking places, where they copulate and produce young, if their periods of gestation happen to be the same, and their size not very different.
tgt_text.5690: The desire of drinking makes them gentle to each other, for they differ from the animals of other countries, in wanting to drink more in winter than in sum­ mer ;
tgt_text.5691: for on account of the great want of water during the summer they are habituated to do without water;
tgt_text.5692: and if the mice drink they die.8.
tgt_text.5693: Other animals are produced by the intercourse of heterogeneous creatures, as in Cyrene the wolves copulate with the dogs, and produce young;
tgt_text.5694: and the Laconian dogs are bred between a dog and a fox.
tgt_text.5695: They say that the In­ dian' dogs are derived from the tiger and the dog;
tgt_text.5696: not di­ rectly, but from the third mixture of the breeds;
tgt_text.5697: for they say that the first race was very fierce.
tgt_text.5698: They take the dogs and tie them up in the desert.
tgt_text.5699: Many of them are devoured, if the wild animal does not happen to desire sexual inter­ course.
tgt_text.5700: 1. DIFFERENT localities produce a variety of dispositions, as mountainous and rough places, or smooth plains.
tgt_text.5701: They are more fierce and robust in appearance in mountains, as the swine of Athos;
tgt_text.5702: for the males of those which inhabit the plains cannot endure even the females of the other kind:
tgt_text.5703: and different situations have great influence on the bite of wild animals.
tgt_text.5704: All the scorpions about Pharus and other places are not painful, but in Caria and other localities they are frequent, and large, and fierce, and their sting is fatal to either man or beast, even to sows, which are but little influ­ enced by the bite of other creatures, and black sows are more easily affected than others.
tgt_text.5705: The swine die very soon after being stung, if they come near the water.
tgt_text.5706: 2. The bite also of serpents varies much;
tgt_text.5707: for in Libya the asp is found, from which they form a septic poison, which is incurable.
tgt_text.5708: In the plant silphium is found a small serpent, for the bite of which a remedy has been discovered in a small stone, which is taken out of the tomb of one of the ancient kings:
tgt_text.5709: this they drink dipped in wine.
tgt_text.5710: In some parts of Italy the bite of the gecko is found to be fatal.
tgt_text.5711: If one poisonous animal eats another, as, if a viper eats a scorpion, its bite is the most fatal of all.
tgt_text.5712: The saliva of a man is hostile to most of them.
tgt_text.5713: There is one small serpent, which some persons call hierus, which is avoided even by large serpents.
tgt_text.5714: It is a cubit long, and appears rough.
tgt_text.5715: Whatsoever it bites imme­ mediately becomes putrid in a circle round the wound.
tgt_text.5716: There is also a small serpent in India, the only one for which there is no remedy.
tgt_text.5718: ANIMALS also differ in being in good condition or not during gestation.
tgt_text.5719: The testacea, as the pectens and the ma­ lacostraca, as the carabi and such like, are best when preg­ nant;
tgt_text.5720: for this word is also used of the testacea.
tgt_text.5721: For the malacostraca have been observed both in the act of copula­ tion and oviposition ;
tgt_text.5722: but none of the testacea have ever been seen so occupied.
tgt_text.5723: The malacia, such as the teuthis, sepia, and polypus, are most excellent when pregnant;
tgt_text.5724: and almost all fish are good during the early part of the period;
tgt_text.5725: but as the time advances some are good and some not so.
tgt_text.5728: The form of the female is round, that of the male longer and broader.
tgt_text.5729: And when the period of gestation commences in the females, the males become black and variegated, and are not fit to eat.
tgt_text.5730: Some persons call them tragi at this period.
tgt_text.5731: Those which are called cottyphus and cichla also change their colour;
tgt_text.5732: and the caris also changes at this season and some birds, which are black in spring and afterwards become white.
tgt_text.5734: The phycis also changes its colour;
tgt_text.5735: for it is white at all other seasons, and variegated in the spring.
tgt_text.5736: This is the only sea fish that, as they say, makes a nest in which it deposits its ova.
tgt_text.5737: The mænis, as it was before ob­ served, and the smaris also change their colours, and from being white in summer become black.
tgt_text.5738: This is particu­ larly conspicuous about the fins and gills.
tgt_text.5739: The coracinus is best when pregnant, and so is the mænis.
tgt_text.5740: The cestreus, labrax, and nearly all creatures that swim are inferior at this season.
tgt_text.5742: There are a few which are good, whether pregnant or not, as the glaucus.
tgt_text.5744: and old tunnies are not even fit for salting, for much of the flesh is dissolved.
tgt_text.5745: The same thing also happens with other fish.
tgt_text.5746: The older fish are distinguished by the size and hardness of their scales;
tgt_text.5747: an old tunny has been taken which weighed fifteen talents, and the length of the tail was two cubits and a span.
tgt_text.5749: River and pond fish are most excellent, after depositing their ova and semen, and recovering their flesh.
tgt_text.5750: Some of them, however, are good while pregnant, as the saperdis;
tgt_text.5751: and others bad, as the glanis.
tgt_text.5752: In all the male is better than the female;
tgt_text.5753: but the female glanis is better than the male.
tgt_text.5754: Those which they call female eels are better than the males.
tgt_text.5755: They call them females, though they are not so, but only differ in appearance.
tgt_text.5757: THE dispositions of obscure and short-lived animals are less easily observed than those of long-lived animals;
tgt_text.5758: for they appear to have a certain inclination towards each na­ tural affection of the soul, such as prudence and folly, courage and cowardice, mildness and cruelty, and such other habits.
tgt_text.5759: Some also, which have the sense of hearing, appear to be capable of a certain degree of instruction and disci­ pline, both from one another and from mankind, for they not only distinguish the difference of sounds but also of signs.
tgt_text.5761: And in all animals in which there is a distinction of the sexes nature has given a similar disposition to the males and to the females.
tgt_text.5762: This is most conspicuous in man, and the larger animals, and in viviparous quadrupeds;
tgt_text.5763: for the disposition of the female is softer, and more tameable and submissive, and more ingenious;
tgt_text.5764: as the females of the Lace­ demonian dog are more gentle than the males.
tgt_text.5765: In the Molossian race of dogs, those employed in hunting differ in no respect from other dogs;
tgt_text.5766: while those employed in fol­ lowing sheep are larger and more fierce in their attack on wild beasts.
tgt_text.5767: A mixture of the Molossian and Lacedemonian races is both braver and more capable of enduring fatigue.
tgt_text.5769: The females of all animals are less violent in their passions than the males, except the female bear and pardalis, for the female of these appears more courageous than the male.
tgt_text.5770: In other animals the females are more soft and insi­ dious, less simple, more petulant, and more active in the care of their young.
tgt_text.5771: The disposition of the males is opposed to this;
tgt_text.5772: for they are more passionate and fierce, more straight- forward, and less invidious.
tgt_text.5773: The vestiges of these disposi­ tions exist, as we may say, in all, but are more conspicuous in those which have the strongest moral habits, and most of all in mankind;
tgt_text.5774: for the nature of the human subject is the most complete, so that these habits appear more conspicuous in mankind than in other animals.
tgt_text.5776: Wherefore women are more compassionate and more readily made to weep, more jealous and querulous, more fond of railing, and more contentious.
tgt_text.5777: The female also is more subject to depression of spirits and despair than the male.
tgt_text.5778: She is also more shameless and false, more readily deceived, and more mindful of injury, more watchful, more idle, and on the whole less excitable than the male.
tgt_text.5779: On the contrary, the male is more ready to help, and, as it has been said, more brave than the female;
tgt_text.5780: and even in the malacia, if the sepia is struck with a trident, the male comes to help the female, but the female makes her escape if the male is struck.
tgt_text.5782: ANIMALS often fight with each other, particularly those which inhabit the same places and eat the same food;
tgt_text.5783: for when food becomes scarce, congeners fight together.
tgt_text.5784: They say that seals which occupy the same locality will fight, the males with the males and the females with the females, until one party is either killed or ejected by the other, and their cubs also will fight in the same way.
tgt_text.5785: All animals also will fight with carnivorous creatures, and these will fight with other animals, for they feed upon living creatures ;
tgt_text.5786: for which reason augurs observe the disputes and agreements of animals, considering that their disputes betoken war, and their agreements peace with each other.
tgt_text.5788: When supplied with plenty of food, animals that are naturally afraid of man and fierce appear to submit them­ selves to him, and to conduct themselves quietly towards each other.
tgt_text.5789: The care which is taken of animals in Egypt demonstrates this circumstance;
tgt_text.5790: for even the fiercest crea­ tures live together, when they have food enough, and are not in any want;
tgt_text.5791: for they become tame from the supply of their wants which they receive, as the crocodiles are tamed by the priests by the care which is bestowed on their food.
tgt_text.5792: The same thing may be observed in other countries and in their different parts.
tgt_text.5794: The eagle and the dragon are enemies, for the eagle feeds on serpents.
tgt_text.5795: The ichneumon and the spider are also enemies, for the ichneumon hunts the spider.
tgt_text.5796: Among birds the pœcilis and the lark and the wood-pecker and chloreus are enemies, for they eat each others' eggs.
tgt_text.5797: The crow and the owl also are enemies;
tgt_text.5798: for at mid-day the crow, taking advantage of the dim sight of the owl, secretly seizes and devours its eggs, and the owl eats those of the crow during the night;
tgt_text.5799: and one of these is master during the day, the other during the night.
tgt_text.5800: The owl and orchilus are enemies;
tgt_text.5801: for the latter eats the eggs of the owl.
tgt_text.5802: During the day other birds fly round the owl, which is called astonishing it," and as they fly round it pluck off its feathers.
tgt_text.5803: For this reason fowlers use it in hunting for all kinds of birds.
tgt_text.5805: The presbys contends with the weasel and crow, for they eat its eggs and young.
tgt_text.5806: The turtle and pyrallis are foes, for their food and mode of life are the same.
tgt_text.5807: The celeus and libyus, kite and raven are enemies;
tgt_text.5808: for the kite, from the superiority of its claws and flight, can take from the raven anything it may have caught, so that their food is the cause of their enmity also.
tgt_text.5809: Those that obtain their food from the sea also are foes, as the brenthus, larus, and harpa.
tgt_text.5810: The triorches is a foe to the toad and the serpent;
tgt_text.5811: for the triorches eats the others.
tgt_text.5812: The turtle and chloreus are foes, for the chloreus kills the turtle, and the crow kills the bird called typanus.
tgt_text.5813: The little owl and all other birds with crooked claws eat the calaris, from whence their enmity arises.
tgt_text.5815: The gecko and the spider are enemies, for the gecko eats spiders.
tgt_text.5816: The pipe is a foe to the heron, for it de.
tgt_text.5817: yours the eggs and young of the heron.
tgt_text.5818: Enmity also exists between the ægithus and the ass;
tgt_text.5819: for the ass frequents thorny places, that it may scratch its sores, and by this means, and when it brays it overturns the eggs and young of the ægithus, for they fall out of the nest from fear of the noise, and the bird, to revenge this injury, flies upon the ass and inflicts wounds.
tgt_text.5820: The wolf is the enemy of the ass, bull, and fox;
tgt_text.5821: for being a carnivorous animal, it attacks both oxen, asses, and foxes.
tgt_text.5822: The fox and circus are enemies for the same reason;
tgt_text.5823: for the circus having crooked claws, and being carnivorous, attacks and inflicts wounds with its claws.
tgt_text.5825: The raven is an enemy to the bull and ass, for it flies round them and strikes their eyes.
tgt_text.5826: The eagle and the heron are foes, for the eagle has crooked claws and attacks it, and the other dies in defending itself.
tgt_text.5827: The æsalon is a foe to the vulture, and the crex to the coleus, blackbird, and chlorion, which some persons fabulously say derives its origin from a funeral pile, for it destroys both themselves and their young.
tgt_text.5828: The sitta and trochilus are foes to the eagle, and the eagle, as well for this reason, as because it is carni­ vorous, is a foe to them all.
tgt_text.5830: The anthus is the enemy of the horse, for it drives the horse from its pasture, for the anthus also feeds on grass;
tgt_text.5831: it is dim-sighted and not quick;
tgt_text.5832: it imitates the voice of the horse, which it frightens by flying at it, and drives it from its pasture;
tgt_text.5833: if the horse can seize upon it, he will kill it.
tgt_text.5834: The anthus lives near rivers and marshes ;
tgt_text.5835: it is of a fine colour, and lives well.
tgt_text.5836: The ass attacks the colota, a creature which lives in the manger, and prevents it from eating, by making its way into its nostrils.
tgt_text.5838: There are three kinds of heron, the black, the white sort, and the one called asterias;
tgt_text.5839: of these, the black rests and copulates with difficulty, for it utters a cry, and, as they say, bleeds from the eyes during coition, and the process of parturition is severe and painful;
tgt_text.5840: it attacks creatures which injure it, as the eagle, for it seizes upon it, and the fox, for this creature attacks it during the night, and the lark, which steals its eggs.
tgt_text.5842: The serpent is an enemy to the weasel and the hog, for if the weasel and serpent live in the same house they both require the same kind of food;
tgt_text.5844: The æsalon is a foe to the fox, for it strikes and pecks it, and destroys its young, for it has crooked claws.
tgt_text.5845: The raven and the fox are friendly, for the raven also attacks the æsalon, and so they help each other in the attack.
tgt_text.5846: The little owl and the æsalon are mutual foes, for both have crooked claws.
tgt_text.5847: The little owl and the swan attack the eagle, and the swan often comes off victorious.
tgt_text.5848: Of all birds the swans are most disposed to devour1 each other.
tgt_text.5850: Some animals are always ready to attack each other, and others, as mankind, only at particular times.
tgt_text.5851: The ass and the acanthis are foes, for the latter feeds entirely on thorns, but the former only when they are tender.
tgt_text.5852: The an- thus, acanthis, and ægithus are foes, and it is said that the blood of the anthus and ægithus will not mix.
tgt_text.5853: The crow and heron are friends, and so are the schoenion, lark, laëdus, and celeus, for the celeus lives by the side of rivers and thickets, but the laedus lives among rocks and moun­ tains, and is fond of the place in which it lives.
tgt_text.5854: The piphinx, harpa, and kite are friends;
tgt_text.5855: the fox and the ser­ pent also, for both live in holes ;
tgt_text.5856: and the blackbird and the turtle.
tgt_text.5857: 11. The lion and jackal are foes, for both are carnivo­ rous, and live on the same substances.
tgt_text.5858: Elephants also fight fiercely with each other, and strike with their tusks ;
tgt_text.5859: the conquered submits entirely, and cannot endure the voice of the victor:
tgt_text.5860: and elephants differ much in the courage they exhibit.
tgt_text.5861: The Indians use both male and female ele­ phants in war, though the females are smaller and far less courageous.
tgt_text.5862: The elephant can overthrow walls by striking them with its large tusks;
tgt_text.5863: it throws down palm trees by striking them with its head, and afterwards putting its feet upon them, stretches them on the ground.
tgt_text.5865: Elephant-hunting is conducted in the following way:
tgt_text.5866: men mount upon some tame courageous animals;
tgt_text.5867: when they have seized upon the wild animals they command the others to beat them till they fail from fatigue.
tgt_text.5868: The elephant-driver then leaps upon its back and directs it with a lance ;
tgt_text.5869: very soon after this they become tame and obedient.
tgt_text.5870: When the elephant-drivers mount upon them they all become obedient, but when they have no driver, some are tame and others not so, and they bind the fore legs of those that are wild with chains, in order to keep them quiet.
tgt_text.5871: They hunt both full-grown animals and young ones.
tgt_text.5872: Such is the friendship and enmity of these wild animals originating in the supply of food, and the mode of life.
tgt_text.5874: SOME fish are gregarious and friendly together, others that are less gregarious are hostile.
tgt_text.5875: Some are gregarious while they are pregnant, others during the season of parturition.
tgt_text.5876: On the whole, the following are gregarious:
tgt_text.5877: the tunny, mœnis, cobius, box, saurus, coracinus, sinodon, trigla, muræna, anthia, eleginus, atherinus, sarginus,belona, (mecon,) teuthus.
tgt_text.5879: Some of these are both gregarious, and live in pairs, for all the others pair together ;
tgt_text.5880: and some are gregarious at particular seasons, as it has been said, while they are pregnant, and others in the season of depositing their ova.2.
tgt_text.5881: The labrax and cestreus, though most hostile, will at certain seasons congregate with each other, for not only do congeners congregate together, but all those which feed upon the same kind of food, where it is abundant.
tgt_text.5882: The cestreus and the conger often survive after having been de­ prived of their tail up to the anus, for the cestreus is eaten by the labrax, and the conger by the muræna.
tgt_text.5883: The stronger are hostile to the weaker, for the strong fish eat the others.
tgt_text.5885: IT has been already observed, that the dispositions of animals vary in cowardice, mildness, courage, gentleness, intelligence, and folly.
tgt_text.5886: The disposition of sheep, as I have said before, is foolish, and without sense;
tgt_text.5887: they are the most cowardly of all animals, and steal away into desert places for no purpose, and in winter often escape from their fold.
tgt_text.5888: When overtaken by a snow-storm, they will not get away, unless the shepherd drives them, but will stay behind and perish, unless the shepherds carry off the males, when the rest will follow.
tgt_text.5890: If a person takes any of the goats by the beard (which is like hair), all the rest stand by as if infatuated, and look at it.
tgt_text.5891: Sheep will sleep in colder places than goats, for sheep are more quiet, and are ready to submit themselves to man­ kind.
tgt_text.5892: Goats do not bear the cold so well as sheep.
tgt_text.5893: Shep­ herds teach sheep to come together when they make a noise, and if any of them is left behind and does not join the flock when it thunders, it will cast its young, if pregnant;
tgt_text.5894: where­ fore, when a noise is made, they will collect together in their sheds according to their custom.
tgt_text.5895: (Bulls are destroyed by wild beasts, if they wander away from their herd.)
tgt_text.5896: Sheep and goats lie down to rest separately in their races, and when the sun begins to descend, the shepherds say that the goats do not lie down with their faces to each other, but they turn their backs upon each other.
tgt_text.5898: Cows pasture in herds, and in companies, and if one of them wanders to a distance, all the rest follow, so that the herdsmen, if they do not find her, immediately examine all the herds.
tgt_text.5899: Mares in herds, if one of them happens to die, will bring up her foal among them, and the whole race of horses appears to have warm natural affections, of which the following is a proof:
tgt_text.5900: the barren mares will take away the foals from their mothers, and treat them with affection, though they soon die for want of milk.
tgt_text.5902: OF all wild quadrupeds, the deer appears to be one of the most prudent in producing its young by the wayside (where wild beasts do not come, for fear of men);
tgt_text.5903: as soon as the young is born, the dam eats the chorion, and runs to the plant called seselis, which she eats, and having so done, returns to her kid.
tgt_text.5904: She then leads her kid to the station, to which it may learn to retreat in case of danger;
tgt_text.5905: this is usually a chasm in a rock with a single entrance, which they say that it stays and defends.
tgt_text.5906: When the male gets fat (which usually happens in the autumn) he does not show himself, but gets out of the way, for his fat makes him an easy prey.
tgt_text.5907: He sheds his horns in difficult and scarcely accessible places, from whence arises the proverb, " where the stag sheds its horns," for they are afraid of being seen, as if they had lost their means of defence.
tgt_text.5908: It is said that the left horn never has been seen, for he conceals it as if it had some medicinal power.
tgt_text.5910: When a year old they have no horns, but only a com­ mencement, as it were a sign of what is to be ;
tgt_text.5911: this is short, and covered with thick down.
tgt_text.5912: When two years old, they have straight horns, like sticks, for which reason they are called pattalia (from παττάλος, a stake).
tgt_text.5913: In the third year their horns are divided.
tgt_text.5914: In the fourth year they become rough.
tgt_text.5915: In this manner they are regularly developed till they are six years old.
tgt_text.5916: After this age their horns are al.
tgt_text.5917: ways the same, so that their age cannot be distinguished by them.
tgt_text.5918: Old stags, however, are recognised by two- signs;
tgt_text.5919: some of them have no teeth at all, others only a few;
tgt_text.5920: and they never have the defensive part of the horn, that part of the growing horn which bends forwards, with which they defend themselves, this the old stags never possess, but all the increase of their horns is upwards.
tgt_text.5922: They cast their horns every year about the month of April.
tgt_text.5923: When they cast their horns they hide themselves during the day, as it has been already observed.
tgt_text.5924: They con­ ceal themselves in thickets, to protect themselves from the flies.
tgt_text.5925: During this period they feed (in the thickets) during the night, until their horns are grown.
tgt_text.5926: They are produced at first under the skin, and are covered with down.
tgt_text.5927: When they grow they expose them to the sun, that the horn may be matured and hardened.
tgt_text.5928: When they cease to give them pain if rubbed against trees, they leave such places, for they are confident in their means of defence.
tgt_text.5929: An Achainian stag1 has been taken with a considerable quantity of green ivy growing on its horns as in green wood, for the horns are tender when first produced.
tgt_text.5931: When the stags are bitten by the phalangium or any such creature, they collect together a number of crabs and eat them.
tgt_text.5932: It appears to be wholesome for mankind to drink the same substance, but it is not pleasant.
tgt_text.5933: The females, as soon as their young are born, eat the chorium, and it is not possible to obtain it, for they seize upon it before it can fall to the ground;
tgt_text.5934: it appears to have some medicinal properties.
tgt_text.5935: The females are captured by the sound of the pipe and by singing, and they are charmed by singing.
tgt_text.5936: When two persons go out to capture them, one shows himself, and either plays upon a pipe, or sings, and the other strikes behind, when the first gives him the signal;
tgt_text.5937: when the ears of the deer are erect, it hears quickly, and cannot be deceived, as it may be if they hang down.
tgt_text.5939: WHEN bears are in flight, the v drive their cubs before them, or take them up and carry them.
tgt_text.5940: When nearly overtaken, they climb up into trees.
tgt_text.5941: When they first come from their hiding place they eat the arum, as it has been already ob­ served, and gnaw the trees as if they were cutting teeth.
tgt_text.5942: Many ether animals also prudently provide themselves with remedies, for they say that the wild goats in Crete, when struck with an arrow, seek out the dittany, for this plant assists in working the arrow from their body.
tgt_text.5944: And dogs, when they are ill, provide themselves with an emetic from a certain kind of grass.
tgt_text.5945: The panther, when it has eaten the poison called pardalianches,1 seeks for human ordure, for this relieves it.
tgt_text.5946: This poison also will kill lions, the hunters, therefore, suspend ordure in a vessel from the trees, in order that the animal may not wander far from them ;
tgt_text.5947: for the panther jumps at it and attempts to seize it, and dies before it can reach it.
tgt_text.5948: They say that the panther is aware that its peculiar scent is grateful to other wild animals, and that it preys upon them in concealment, and when deer approach near, it catches hinds.
tgt_text.5950: The Egyptian ichneumons, when they see the serpent called the asp, do not attack it until they have invited others to assist.
tgt_text.5951: They roll themselves in mud as a protection against its blows and wounds ;
tgt_text.5952: they first bathe in water and then roll themselves on the ground.
tgt_text.5953: When the crocodile gapes, the trochilus flies into its mouth, to cleanse its teeth ;
tgt_text.5954: in this process the trochilus procures food, and the other per­ ceives it, and does not injure it;
tgt_text.5955: when the crocodile wishes the trochilus to leave, it moves its neck that it may not bite the bird.
tgt_text.5956: When the tortoise has eaten a viper, it afterwards eats origanum;
tgt_text.5958: A person who had often seen this done, and had observed that when the tortoise had tasted the origanum it went back to the viper, gathered all the origanum, and when this was done, the tortoise died.
tgt_text.5960: The weasel eats the herb rue before it attacks a serpent, for the smell of this herb is obnoxious to serpents.
tgt_text.5961: When the draco has eaten much fruit, it sucks the juice of the bitter lettuce;
tgt_text.5962: it has been seen to do this.
tgt_text.5963: When dogs are troubled with worms, they eat the green tops of corn.
tgt_text.5964: When the pelargus or any other bird has been wounded in flight, they feed upon marjoram, and many persons have seen the locust2 settle upon the neck of serpents with which it was contending.
tgt_text.5965: The weasel also appears prudent in the way in which it attacks birds, for it kills them in the same manner as wolves kill sheep ;
tgt_text.5966: it will fight also with serpents, and especially with those that hunt mice;
tgt_text.5967: for the weasel pursues the same animals.
tgt_text.5969: Observations have been frequently made on the instinct of the hedgehog, for when the north and south winds change, those that dwell in the earth alter the position of the en­ trance of their burrows ;
tgt_text.5970: those which are kept in houses alter their position from wall to wall, so that they say that in Byzantium there was a person who obtained the character of predicting the change of the weather, from observations made on the hedgehog.
tgt_text.5971: The ictis is about the size of a small Maltese dog;
tgt_text.5972: in the thickness of its hair, its appearance, its white belly, and the cunning of its disposition, it re­ sembles the weasel;
tgt_text.5974: it attacks hives of bees, for it is very fond of honey;
tgt_text.5976: its penis, as it has been already observed, is bony, and ap­ pears to be a remedy for stranguary in the human subject;
tgt_text.5979: MANY animals in their mode of life appear to imitate mankind, and one may observe greater accuracy of intellect in small than in large animals;
tgt_text.5980: as the manufacture of its dwelling by the swallow is remarkable among birds;
tgt_text.5981: it has the same method of combining chaff with mud, for it mixes the mud with straw, and if mud is not to be found, it dips in the water and rolls itself in the dust;
tgt_text.5982: it uses straw in making its nest as men use it, for it places the largest at the bottom, and makes it commensurate with its own bulk;
tgt_text.5983: both the male and female labour in support of the young.
tgt_text.5984: They feed each in turn, observing by some agree­ ment the one which was first fed that none may receive food twice;
tgt_text.5985: at first they turn the dung out of the nest, but as the young birds increase in size, they teach them to turn themselves, so as to eject their excrement out of the nest.
tgt_text.5987: There are some observations which may be made on pigeons, for they will not pair with many mates, nor do they forsake their first companion, unless they become widowed.
tgt_text.5988: The care and anxiety of the male at the time of parturition are remarkable, for if the pain causes the hen to feel languid when near the nest, he beats her and drives her in.
tgt_text.5989: When the young are hatched, the parent provides salt earth, which is injected into the open mouth of the young birds, as a pre­ paration for the reception of food.
tgt_text.5990: When it is time for them to leave the nest, the male copulates with them all.
tgt_text.5992: In this manner they have usually a great affection for each other.
tgt_text.5993: Some females will copulate with males that are not their own mates.
tgt_text.5994: This bird is contentious, they fight together, and attack each other's nests, though not fre­ quently, for although they are beaten when at a distance, they will fight to the last when near their nests ;
tgt_text.5995: it appears to be characteristic of the pigeon, phaps, and turtle not to lean back when they drink, unless they have had sum­ cient.
tgt_text.5996: The turtle and phatta aways remain faithful to the same male, and will not permit another to approach them, and the male and female share the labour of incubation.
tgt_text.5997: The male and female are not easily distinguished, except by their internal structure.
tgt_text.5998: 4. The phatta is long-lived, they have been known to live for twenty-five or thirty years, some even forty years;
tgt_text.5999: their claws grow when they become aged, and pigeon breeders cut them off, and in no other respect are they in­ ferior when aged.
tgt_text.6000: The turtle and the pigeon, if they have been blinded by those who use them as decoy birds, will live eight years.
tgt_text.6001: The partridge lives fifteen years, the phaps and the turtle always build in the same places.
tgt_text.6003: On the whole, males also live longer than females, but in these birds they say that the males die before the females;
tgt_text.6004: this conclusion is derived from the observation of those which are brought up in houses for decoy birds.
tgt_text.6005: Some persons say that cock-sparrows only live for one year, con­ sidering this as a proof, that early in the spring there are no birds with black beneath the chin ;
tgt_text.6006: but they have it after­ wards, as if none of the former birds had survived.
tgt_text.6007: The hen-sparrows have a longer life, for these are taken among the young birds, and are easily known by the hard portion about their bills.
tgt_text.6008: The turtle lives during the summer in cold places, and during the winter in warm places.
tgt_text.6009: The finch lives during the summer in warm places, and in cold places during winter.
tgt_text.6011: THE heavy birds do not make nests, for it does not agree with their mode of flight, as the quail, partridge, and all such birds ;
tgt_text.6012: but when they have made a hole in the smooth ground (for they never produce their young in any other place), they collect together some thorns and sticks for a defence against the hawks and eagles, and there lay their eggs and incubate.
tgt_text.6013: As soon as the young are hatched, they lead them out, because their slow flight prevents them from procuring food for them.
tgt_text.6014: The quail and partridge shelter their young under their wings, like the domestic fowl.
tgt_text.6016: They do not lay and incubate in the same place, lest any one should discover the place while they sat there for a long while;
tgt_text.6017: and when any one in hunting falls upon the nest, the partridge halts before him, as if she could be taken, and draws him after her in the hopes of capture, until all the young ones have had time to escape, and after she flies back and recalls them to their nest.
tgt_text.6018: The partridge does not lay less than ten eggs, and often sixteen.
tgt_text.6019: As it has been already observed, it is a bird of an evil and cunning dispo­ sition.
tgt_text.6020: In the spring they separate with singing and fight­ ing into pairs with the females which each may happen to take.
tgt_text.6021: The partridge being a bird of violent passions, it tries to prevent the female from incubation by rolling and break­ ing the eggs, if it can find them.
tgt_text.6022: The female, opposing this artifice by another, lays her eggs as she runs, and often, from her desire of laying, she drops her eggs wherever she may be, if the male is present;
tgt_text.6023: and, that they may all be preserved, she does not return to them.
tgt_text.6024: If she is ob­ served by men, she leads them away from her eggs as from her young ones, and shows herself just before them until they are drawn away from the nest.
tgt_text.6026: When the hen has escaped for incubation, the cocks crow and fight together.
tgt_text.6028: The vanquished in the combat follows his conqueror who alone has intercourse with him;
tgt_text.6029: and if any one is overcome by a second, or by any chance one, the victor has secret inter­ course with him.
tgt_text.6030: This does not take place always, but only at certain seasons of the year.
tgt_text.6031: The quail does the same, and domestic fowls also;
tgt_text.6032: for when a new one is offered in the temples, where they are kept without the females, all in turn are united with it.
tgt_text.6033: Tame partridges have sexual inter­ course with wild ones, and strike and insult them.
tgt_text.6035: The leader of the wild partridges attacks the partridge used in fowling, and goes out crowing as if he would fight.
tgt_text.6036: When he is taken in the trap, the other goes out and crows, in the same manner.
tgt_text.6037: If the partridge used for fowling is cock, they behave in this way;
tgt_text.6038: but if it is a female, and she calls, the leader answers her call;
tgt_text.6039: and all the rest rise up and beat him, and drive him away from the female, because he attends to her instead of themselves.
tgt_text.6040: For this reasor he often comes silently, that the others may not hear his voice and come out to fight him.
tgt_text.6041: And some experienced fowlers say that the male approaches the female in silence that the other males may not hear him and compel him tc fight them.
tgt_text.6042: The partridge not only calls, but also utters a shrill cry and other sounds.
tgt_text.6044: And it often happens, when the hen is sitting, that i she sees the male approaching the decoy bird, she will get up from her nest, and remain in his way, that he may have intercourse with her, and not be drawn away by the decoy bird.
tgt_text.6045: Partridges and quails have such violent sexual desires that they will fall upon the fowlers and often perch upon their heads.
tgt_text.6047: THIS is the mode of the sexual intercourse of the par­ tridge, and the way in which they are caught, and the nature of the rest of their crafty disposition.
tgt_text.6048: Quails, and partridges, and some other birds make their nest upon the ground, as it has been already observed.
tgt_text.6049: Of such birds the lark, wood­ cock, and quail do not perch upon trees, but upon the ground.
tgt_text.6051: The woodpecker does not settle upon the ground, but it strikes trees in order to drive out the worms and flies which they contain, and it picks them up with its tongue as they emerge.
tgt_text.6052: Its tongue is wide and large.
tgt_text.6053: It walks upon the trees in any position, even beneath the branches, like the gecko.
tgt_text.6054: It has claws stronger than those of the colœus, which provide for its safety in climbing trees;
tgt_text.6055: for it fixes them in the bark as it walks up the trees.
tgt_text.6056: There is one kind of woodpecker less than the blackbird, covered with small red spots, and another kind larger than the blackbird, and a third kind nearly as large as the domestic hen.
tgt_text.6057: It builds its nest upon trees, as it has been already observed, both on olive and other trees;
tgt_text.6058: and it feeds upon ants and worms which live in trees.
tgt_text.6059: It hunts for worms so diligently that they say it hollows out the trees so much as to throw them down.
tgt_text.6060: A tame bird has been known to place an almond in a crack in wood, to prepare it for the stroke of its bill, and break it with three blows, in order to eat the kernel.
tgt_text.6061: MANY prudent actions appear to be performed by cranes for they travel great distances, and fly at a great elevation, in order that they may see farther;
tgt_text.6062: and if they see clouds and wintry weather, they descend and rest themselves.
tgt_text.6063: They have also a leader in front;
tgt_text.6064: and in the rear are those which give a signal by whistling, so that their voice may be heard.
tgt_text.6065: When they settle on the ground, the rest sleep with their head under the wing, first on one foot, then on the other;
tgt_text.6066: but the leader watches with his neck stretched out, and when he sees anything he gives a signal by his cry.
tgt_text.6067: The pelicans, which inhabit the rivers, swallow large smooth shells with their drink, and when they have been digested in the first part of their stomach, they vomit them up, in order that they may pick out and eat their flesh when they open their valves.
tgt_text.6069: THE habitations of wild birds are contrived with relation to their mode of life and the preservation of their young.
tgt_text.6070: Some of them are kind to their young and careful of them :
tgt_text.6071: others are of a different disposition.
tgt_text.6072: Some manage well in their mode of life:
tgt_text.6074: Some dwell in clefts, and holes, and in rocks, as the birds called charadrius.
tgt_text.6075: This bird is faulty both in its colours and its voice.
tgt_text.6076: It appears during the night, and escapes in the day time.
tgt_text.6077: 2. The hawk also builds in precipitous places;
tgt_text.6078: and al­ though it is carnivorous, it does not devour the heart of the bird it has killed.
tgt_text.6079: Some have observed this with respect to the quail and thrush, and others with other birds.
tgt_text.6080: There is also a change in their mode of hunting their prey, for they do not seize them in the same way in summer and in winter.
tgt_text.6081: It is said that no one has ever seen the young or the nest of the carrion vulture.
tgt_text.6082: Wherefore Herodorus, the father of Brison the sophist, says that they come from some distant elevated land, using this proof, that many of them ap­ pear suddenly, but where they come from is not intelligible to any one.
tgt_text.6083: The reason is this, they make their nest ii 1 inaccessible rocks, and the bird is not an inhabitant of many countries.
tgt_text.6084: It produces one egg or two at the most.
tgt_text.6085: 3. Some birds dwell in mountains and in woods, as the hoopoe and brenthus.
tgt_text.6086: This bird has a good habit of life am a good voice.
tgt_text.6087: The trochilus dwells in thickets and holes
tgt_text.6088: It is taken with difficulty, for it is swift in flight, and its disposition is weak;
tgt_text.6089: but its mode of life is good, and it is artful.
tgt_text.6090: It is also called presbys and basileus.
tgt_text.6091: Wherefore also they say that it fights with the eagle.1.
tgt_text.6092: THERE are some which live near the sea, as the cinclus
tgt_text.6093: In disposition this bird is cunning and difficult of capture.
tgt_text.6095: It appears to be lame, for its hinder parts are weak.
tgt_text.6096: All birds with webbed feet live near the sea, or near rivers and ponds, for their nature teaches them to seek what is advantageous for them.
tgt_text.6097: Many of those with divided feet live near waters and marshes, as the an thus in the neighbourhood of rivers.
tgt_text.6098: Its colour is beautiful, and its mode of life good.
tgt_text.6099: The diver lives near the sea, and when it plunges into the sea it remains as long a time as it would take a man to walk over a pleth­ rum of ground.
tgt_text.6100: This bird is less than a hawk.
tgt_text.6101: 2. The swan also is web-footed, and lives in ponds and marshes.
tgt_text.6102: Its manner of life and disposition is good, and so is its mode of rearing their young and its old age.
tgt_text.6103: If an eagle attacks the swan, it defends itself and comes off victo­ rious, but will not commence the fight.
tgt_text.6104: Swans have the power of song, especially when near the end of their life;
tgt_text.6105: for they then fly out to sea, and some persons, sailing near the coast of Libya, have met many of them in the sea sing­ ing a mournful song, and have afterwards seen some of them die.3.
tgt_text.6106: The cymindis is seldom seen, for it inhabits mountains.
tgt_text.6107: It is black, and about the size of the hawk called pigeon hawk.
tgt_text.6108: Its form is long and slight.
tgt_text.6109: (It shines with a metallic lustre, wherefore also it is called chalcis.)
tgt_text.6111: wherefore Homer writes in the Iliad, " the bird which the gods call chalets, and mortals cymindis."
tgt_text.6112: (Some persons say that the hybris is the same bird as the ptynx.)
tgt_text.6113: This bird does not show itself in the day-time because its sight is dim;
tgt_text.6114: but it hunts its prey during the night like the eagle.
tgt_text.6115: It fights so fiercely with the eagle that both are often taken alive by the shepherds.
tgt_text.6116: It lays two eggs, and builds in rocks and caverns.
tgt_text.6117: Cranes fight so fiercely with each other that these also are taken alive by the shepherds while they are fighting.
tgt_text.6118: The crane lays two eggs.1. THE jaychanges its voice frequently, for it utters a different one, as we may say, almost every day;
tgt_text.6120: it makes its nest upon trees, of hair and wool;
tgt_text.6121: when the acorns fall, it conceals and stores them up.
tgt_text.6122: Many persons have reported that the stork is fed by its young, and some people say the merops also, and that they are fed by the young, not only in their old age, but as soon as the young birds are able to do so, and that the parents remain within the nest;
tgt_text.6123: in appearance, this bird is green beneath the wings, and blue above, as the kingfisher, and its wings are red at the extremity.
tgt_text.6124: It lays six or seven eggs in the autumn, in muddy caverns, and digs as much as four cubits into the ground.
tgt_text.6126: The bird called chloris from being yellow beneath, is of the size of the lark, and lays four or five eggs;
tgt_text.6127: it makes its nest of symphytum, which it pulls up by the root, and lines it with straw, hair, and wool.
tgt_text.6128: The blackbird and jay do the same, and line their nests with the same ma­ terials ;
tgt_text.6129: the nest of the acanthyllis is also artfully con­ structed, for it is folded together like a ball of flax, and has a small entrance.
tgt_text.6130: And the natives of those places say that there is a cinnamon bird, and that they bring the cinnamon from the same places as the bird, and that it makes its nest of it.
tgt_text.6131: It builds its nest in lofty trees and among their branches, but the natives of the country tip their arrows with lead, with which they destroy the nests, and then pick out the cinnamon from the other material.
tgt_text.6133: THE halcyon is not much larger than a sparrow;
tgt_text.6134: its colour is blue and green, and somewhat purple ;
tgt_text.6135: its whole body is composed of these colours as well as the wings and neck, nor is any part without every one of these colours.
tgt_text.6136: Its bill is somewhat yellow, long, and slight;
tgt_text.6137: this is its ex­ ternal form.
